PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.
Death of Mr A. A. Armstrong, O.B.E., M.C.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR A. A. ARMSTRONG, O.B.E., M.C.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death yesterday of Mr A. A. Armstrong, member for Riverina from 1965 to 1969, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and family in their bereavement.

I express just a few words personally and as a member of the National Country Party and, indeed, of the Government parties referable to the shock at the sudden death of Bill Armstrong. It is a shock that brings to all of us who had the opportunity of knowing Bill Armstrong a realisation that we have lost a good friend and, indeed, a very fine Australian.

Bill Armstrong had a long and distinguished career in the community in which he lived. He served the community through his efforts in the world of politics as well as in many other fields. He was a very well-known and well-liked member in the Federal seat of Riverina. He served there, as I have said, from 1965 until 1969. Bill Armstrong had a distinguished career in the Army. He served in the 38th Australian Infantry Battalion in 1939 and 1940 and then in the Australian Imperial Force until the conclusion of the war. He was mentioned in despatches. He was decorated with the Military Cross.

Bill Armstrong was born in 1909 in Deniliquin which was his home base for the entire passage of his life. I believe that he was a person who really had no enemies in the entire world in which he moved. He was a man who made a point of understanding every other body's point of view. I think in doing that he was a great example to all of us. Not only had he a wide range of interests in the social, political and economic circumstances and development of the community but also he was a very keen sportsman. Among his close attentions in that field was his determination that the Melbourne Cup should start on time and with no undue advantage anywhere in the field. I understand that he was the starter of that famous Australian event on no fewer than 21 occasions.

There are many things that I could say about Bill Armstrong and his family-his wife whom I have known very well for years, his daughter and his three sons. I do not propose to speak for the length of time that his passing really deserves but I take this opportunity of again offering not only my own very sincere consideration and condolences but also those of my party, and indeed of the Government, to his wife, his daughter and his three sons. I can only hope that the measure of their grief will be in some way relieved by the knowledge of the massive army of friends and the good will that Bill Armstrong was able to establish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join Senator Scott in expressing my personal sympathy and that of members of my party and this Government to the widow and family of Bill Armstrong upon his death. Those of us who knew him would join with Senator Scott in commenting that he had a very warm personality and a quiet and gentle strength. In Shakespeare's words, he was a man. He served in both peace and war with great distinction. He served not only at the local shire level but also in this Parliament, in the other place. He served in World War II with particular distinction and was awarded the Military Cross for bravery. I suppose that the most important thing that one can say about a person is that we are the poorer for his passing. We had in him a warm friend, someone from whom we gained in friendship in the journey of life. In expressing our sympathy, we say to his family that he will be long remembered by us.

—I wish to associate the Parliamentary Labor Party as represented in the Senate with the expressions of admiration for the life of Mr Armstrong. I do not think there is anything that I can add to what has been said, particularly by Senator Scott. We share the belief in the great contribution that he made to his country and to the Parliament and we express our condolences to his wife and family.

—I join those who have already spoken in extending my personal thoughts and those of my party about Mr Armstrong. I have nothing to add to the eulogies about him that have been delivered by Senators Scott, Sir John Carrick and Button, except to give him perhaps the highest accolade that an Australian can give to another: He was a damn good bloke. Everyone will mourn his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join others who have spoken of the sad passing of Bill Armstrong. My experience and knowledge of Bill could be summed up as follows: He was widely consulted for his expertise in pastoral interests. He was highly regarded as someone who had a very broad experience in and a vast knowledge of that important area of activity in Australia. In the Army he was decorated for his bravery. In what I think was one of the proudest of his achievements-his work as the starter, amongst other things, of the Melbourne Cup for over 20 years-he was praised for his impartiality, his accuracy and his competence. I can only subscribe to what Senator Chipp has said: As a friend, he was a very good bloke.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 125 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation.
We agree that:
(1) PVR will aggravate the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding .
(2) PVR will not enhance Australia's access to improved plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
(3) PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
(4) PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interests not responsible to the Australian people.
(5) The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament:
(1) refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR,
(2) calls for a public enquiry into the impact of existing overseas PVR schemes on the Australian seed industry and the international seed trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. there is a lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on plant variety rights;
2. there is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietorial rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered;
3. there is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the plant diversity;
4. there is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed stocks;
5. evidence suggests that plant varietal rights legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the tax payer, and

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament ensure;
(i) that information be made freely available to allow full and informed public discussion of the issues involved.
(ii) that the Government undertake to carry out an analysis of the costs and benefits involved to the various sectors of Agriculture and the Nation as a whole.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. There is lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on plant variety rights.
2. There is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietorial rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered.
3. There is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the existing plant diversity.
4. There is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed stocks.
5. Evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the tax payer.
6. Evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australian resources.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament defer introducing the legislation until full and informed public discussion of the issues involved has taken place.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery today of Mr Laurie Wilkinson and Mr Ron Maunsell. Both of these gentlemen served for many years with great distinction in this chamber. I extend to both of them a very cordial and warm welcome to Canberra today.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it true that estimates of the Budget blowout are going as high as $1. 4 billion? Does this not support the view of commentators that the Budget strategy is falling apart and is 'in tatters'? Has the Minister also noted the statements by Australia's two largest institutional investors-the Australian Mutual Provident Society and the National Mutual Life Association-that their investment divisions are being forced to live from day to day because of Australia's confused economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the question, I have not seen the statements but, of course, I have recently reread the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report on Australia which says that compared with other countries in the Western world Australia's performance is remarkably good. The Budget has suffered some setbacks. As the result of some continued industrial strife in Bass Strait, the volume of production of crude oil there has fallen to the extent that this year the shortfall in revenue will be perhaps some $220m. Of course, that is a very large amount. It is also necessary to meet the Academic Salaries Tribunal's increases and the recommendations of Mr Justice Coldham's Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay on Defence Force salaries. Overall the Budget deficit has increased but the Government is busy seeking to contain any increase in it and is making a number of reductions in expenditure so that the deficit will be kept to a minimum.

—For those who are interjecting, I point out that every increase in the deficit puts the Government into a position where it must borrow more and therefore puts more pressure on interest rates. Therefore one hopes that there will be bilateral support in this Parliament for the smallest possible deficit and encouragement for the Government in its attempts to achieve that end.

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to the introduction of the crude oil import parity pricing in 1978. Will the Minister advise whether that policy has been effective? If it has, what savings have been made? Further, recognising the importance of primary production to Australia's export trade and the fact that fuel is an integral cost in primary production, can the Minister advise how our fuel prices now compare with those of our major trading partners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one would expect with energy matters coming within my portfolio, of course I have a brief on both the matters raised; and, as honourable senators would expect, I am keenly interested to know what savings are made and how Australian prices for oil and gasoline compare with overseas prices. Import parity pricing has been a marked success. It has been commended by the International Energy Agency as being essential. The Agency has said that any country which sets out to have a proper energy policy must have, as its basis, the pricing of its petroleum products at world scarcity prices, and that in fact is what import parity pricing means. If one were to assume that the demand for crude oil and petroleum products, say over the three fiscal years since the introduction of import parity pricing, had continued at the average rate for the past, that is the 4 per cent which Australia experienced in the 10 years to 1977-78, the saving would be of the incredible order of 75 million barrels of oil compared with the historic rate of consumption. To put it another way, if petroleum consumption growth in that 10 years-an increase of 4 per cent per annum-had been maintained, then we would have had to get 75 million barrels more out of Bass Strait. That is some six months supply. Quite clearly, there have been enormous savings. With the consent of the Senate I would be happy to incorporate in Hansard a comparative table of the prices of petroleum fuel in Australia and other countries. I seek leave to incorporate that table in Hansard .

ANSWER.PARA: * Indicates a change in a country's local retail price since last statement. All other changes are due to fluctuations in the exchange rate.
(a) International retail prices quoted are based on latest information received from Australian Overseas Posts.

(b) DNDE estimate based on latest available CPI price data for six State Capitals, subsequent Petroleum Products Pricing Authority determinations, and allowance for discounts. The automotive LPG price is based on an indicative sample.
(c) LPG use is either insignificant or not used for automotive purposes.
Note: Prices have been converted for most countries at 6 January 1982 exchange rates.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: EXEMPTION FROM CUTBACKS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether it is true that, as he stated some weeks ago, the Department of Social Security is being exempted from the general cutbacks in the Public Service for the rest of this financial year. If it is not true, where are there to be cutbacks? Will these be particularly in the area of overtime? If overtime is to be cut, in what areas will this happen? How does the Minister expect that this will affect the processing of pensions, benefits and family allowances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —To take the last part of the honourable senator's question first, I do not anticipate there being any effect on the processing of pensions and benefits. That, of course, is an important and primary obligation of my Department. I would not wish to see any action taken by the Government, and the Government would not wish to see any action taken, which would interfere with meeting that primary obligation. In common with all other departments, the Department of Social Security was asked to exercise all possible restraint in its discretionary outlays and that includes overtime. There was a temporary freeze on unused funds while essential needs were assessed. I should point out that on the very weekend that that occurred, or on the weekend following that occurring, overtime was worked to meet those commitments that I mentioned earlier in my answer, namely, ensuring that pensions and benefits were paid on time. It was made clear from the outset that funds would be made available to enable pensions and benefits to be paid on time. In fact action is currently in train to secure the release of further amounts needed to maintain essential operations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department does not rely heavily on overtime for its operation although some is essential. The salary provision in the Budget was $175,100,000 and the provision for overtime was a modest $2.9m. In terms of the total operations of the Department that figure is relatively small. But it is a fact that at times overtime needs to be worked in such areas as computer operations to ensure that the very large number of payments that are made weekly by the Department can be made at the right time for pensioners and beneficiaries. I noticed one report in the Sydney Morning Herald which said:
Meanwhile, Deborah Hope reports from Canberra that the payment of pensions and other welfare benefits will be severely disrupted by the overtime freeze in the Department of Social Security-
according to the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association.

I am sorry that reports of that sort should be repeated in the Press as they may cause unnecessary concern to pensioners and beneficiaries. I ask the media, if the union makes statements like that to it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which newspaper was that?

—The Sydney Morning Herald. I ask the media to think of the welfare of pensioners and beneficiaries and to check such reports with me or my Department before they are published. In fact there will be some minor effect on my Department. Currently there are discussions between my Department and the Department of Finance about areas where there might be possible savings between now and the end of the year. There is the possibility of some small administrative savings. There is the possibility of some minor slippage in subsidy payments where that will not break obligations or inconvenience the operation of organisations that are expecting those payments. The overall effect on a total Budget in excess of $10 billion will be minuscule.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister answered the second part of my question first but failed to answer the first part of the question. I asked whether it is a fact that he stated some weeks ago that the Department of Social Security was being exempted from the general cutbacks in the Public Service for the rest of this financial year. What was the basis of that statement? Why has his Department not been exempted as he stated it would be?

—There will certainly be no cutbacks in the Public Service in terms of numbers, if that is the point of the honourable senator's question. As far as the operations of my Department are concerned, there will be no cutbacks in areas which affect the clients of my Department.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that currently the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment is dealing with a reference referred to it by the Senate concerning pesticides and herbicides and their effect on human health? The Senate has requested the Committee to deal with Vietnam veterans and the problems associated with agent orange and other herbicides. I ask: Firstly, in view of Press reports describing the recent Repatriation Review Tribunal decision in favour of Mrs Lorraine Simpson as an historic ruling that would open up the flood gates of claims from veterans, can the Minister advise the Senate of the implications of this decision for the manner in which the Repatriation Commission will examine such claims? Secondly, should claims for disabilities attributed to exposure to chemicals be now accepted, what will be the implication, if any, for the epidemiological studies on Vietnam veterans by the Commonwealth Institute of Health? Thirdly, the decision of the Repatriation Review Tribunal on the Simpson case notes on several occasions the absence of representatives of the Repatriation Commission during the hearing. Can the Minister explain the absence of the Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm the facts. A decision was handed down last Thursday by the Repatriation Review Tribunal in the case of Mrs Simpson who claimed that her husband's death caused by a malignant lymphoma was the result of his war service. It is important to note that the Tribunal did not make a finding that there was a definite proven link between any exposure of Mr Simpson during service in Vietnam to agent orange or any other toxic chemical. Mr Simpson's death, due to lymphoma, was caused in circumstances which I will describe in a moment. I wanted to make that point clear because there is some doubt in the minds of people who may be concerned about their own state of health because of the kind of media reporting that occurred over this decision. In fact, it could give an impression that new evidence was brought forward in the Tribunal to indicate some kind of link between chemicals and the kind of health problems that were suffered by Mr Simpson.

ANSWER.PARA: I stress that in this case the Repatriation Review Tribunal applied the onus of proof provisions contained in the Repatriation Act which require a determining authority to grant a claim unless satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that there are insufficient grounds for so doing. Of course, this is a matter which has in recent times been subject to contest in the High Court of Australia and which is now well settled in the law.

Senator Jessop raises the point of whether this is an historic ruling. One has to acknowledge that this has not yet been established for the purposes of either legal inquiry or scientific inquiry. Consequently, claims which may be put forward by individual Vietnam veterans will proceed in the normal way through the repatriation appeals system. Should these claims that have been put forward be further accepted, that will be a matter for future concern of the Repatriation Commission and other bodies. As to the effect upon the epidemiology study of the Commonwealth Institute of Health, quite clearly the Government's intention, as I have recently announced, is to pursue the scientific questions involved in this matter with utmost speed. Consequently, as I announced a week or two ago, we have undertaken certain new measures to ensure that we get early answers to that question.

In regard to the latter part of Senator Jessop's question regarding the absence of Repatriation Commission officials during the Repatriation Review Tribunal hearing, I point out that this is of course a matter of decision of the Repatriation Commission. It is an independent statutory authority. It has been designed by this Parliament to be outside political or other interference. Beyond that, I understand that the reasons in this case were simple. On the file which was presented to the Repatriation Review Tribunal during its hearing were three clearly very substantial, important and, might I say, well qualified reports from experts in the treatment of cancer, and in particular lymphoma, who stated that in their opinions there was no connection between toxic chemical exposure and malignant lymphoma. Therefore, no particular reason was seen to appear at the Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of either Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle as Minister for Finance or as a member of the Cabinet or of Senator Sir John Carrick as Leader of the Government in the Senate, and again, or as a Cabinet Minister. I refer to the decision of the Premiers Conference last Friday to set up a working party to examine the future role of the Loan Council. I ask either Minister: Will she or he categorically deny that any decision has been taken by the Cabinet or part of the Cabinet to relinquish Loan Council control over State government borrowing programs? Can the Senate have an absolute assurance that the Federal Government has no intention of relinquishing its control over public sector borrowing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question, the answer is unequivocally yes, we can give that assurance. No decision was made by the Government to relinquish control in the Loan Council. As to the second question, the Government felt that a Loan Council that had been functioning since 1927 needed to have some review. There were a considerable number of borrowing changes in the public and private sectors over that period. A number of commercial ventures now entered into by State and local government bodies had not been entered into before. Whilst the Government asserts its primary national responsibility for the economy and, therefore, for money supply as an instrument of the economy, it could foresee that there might be some changes in the procedures and the practices that could be beneficial to both. But the Commonwealth Government, in whatever should be pursued, will keep the primary responsibility before it; that is, it accepts that it has this national responsibility for the economy and, therefore, for the overall money supply. It will have that in its mind. Nevertheless, it believes that, as I said, because of particular borrowing changes that have happened in the past few years it is well worth having a second look at the general procedures.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. What is the present situation with regard to the somewhat controversial Finniss River Aboriginal land claim in the Northern Territory? Has the Minister come to a conclusion? If so, can he advise the Senate of the outcome?

—The Finniss River claim is one of several which are awaiting determination by me. I think the Borroloola claim is not yet completed. The Alligator Rivers claim is not yet determined. The Finniss River claim is awaiting determination. I tabled in an interim typewritten form last June the Aboriginal Land Commissioner's report on the Finniss River claim and later this week during the tabling of papers will bring down the final printed form with the maps and the other documents which are required. Some appeals have been made to the High Court of Australia on certain matters which go to these claims. There is a question as to the weight which the Commissioner should give to questions of detriment being argued before the High Court. There is also a question as to the status of grazing licences and whether they represent alienation of land. I will not be in a position to make a determination on the Finniss River claim, a complete determination on the Alligator Rivers claim or a final determination on Borroloola until these matters have been determined. As soon as the High Court has made its judgment on these matters I will be in a position to go back and to make the judgment to which the honourable senator refers.
—When does it go before the High Court?
—Very soon.

—I ask whether the Minister representing the Minister for Health has seen the report in yesterday's Daily News that 11 houses at Capel in the south of Western Australia have background radiation levels, due to mineral sand mining, above those acceptable to all international authorities. What will be the role of the Federal Government in ensuring that the health of people in the area is safeguarded, or is this purely a Western Australian matter where the well-being of people has long been a minor consideration of that State Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Health may seek to add to my answer. It so happens that I am responsible for radioactive materials. I am advised that this situation refers to radioactive monazite residues from sand mining at Capel which is 170 kilometres south of Perth. The situation there, I am advised, is similar to that encountered recently in Byron Bay, New South Wales. A radiation level of 0.1 millirems an hour is recognised by the International Commission for Radiation Protection-that is, the ICRP-as the threshold level for public health investigation. The radiation levels at Byron Bay range from 0.1 to 0.6 millirems an hour; that is, 100 to 600 microrems . The New South Wales Minister for Health has explained that 1,200 hours' exposure would give the equivalent in radiation of two chest x-rays.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it perfectly clear, as I have said in the Senate before, that I do not seek to minimise the effect of any radioactivity. If I give the Senate the comparative figures I do so to enable some understanding of the nature of the problems. It is not to say that because one would need to have 1,200 hours' exposure something ought not to be done. I want to make that abundantly clear. The advice I have is that at the Byron Bay level one would need 1,200 hours exposure to get the equivalent radiation of two chest x-rays. Again, chest x- rays are elective. Exposure to radioactivity from these materials could be compulsory. I make the point that there is a duty to keep down the amount of non -elective radioactivity. If the figures cited for Capel are correct the radiation hazard will be of a similar order to Byron Bay. We understand that the Western Australian State X-ray Laboratory surveyed the area in 1981 and has reported to the Western Australian Minister for Health. If there is any further information that either Senator Baume or I could add for the honourable senator we would be keen to obtain it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I am concerned about the role of the Federal Government in all things radioactive. I wonder whether, in actual fact, what the Minister has now told me means that he is purely and simply leaving the matter to the State Government to monitor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been informed by me that the Atomic Energy Act is under total review and that discussions are in continuous process with the States to define a new Commonwealth Act for the future and State and Commonwealth roles. The sovereignty situation is quite clear with regard to these kinds of matters. In everyday life the States are handling industrial and medical isotopes in very large quantities. At those levels the States are responsible. For example, nobody doubts that it was the responsibility of the State to act to remove the contaminated soil at Hunters Hill. I think that nevertheless puts in perspective the fact that the Commonwealth accepts that it has a responsibility in Australia for significant radioactivity. It has a responsibility particularly for movement of radioactive material between the States and overseas. I imagine that in these cases in question the States would assert their responsibilities. Since they are day by day handling these kinds of matters and these kinds of mining procedures-sand mining is a mining procedure- it would be a State responsibility. I emphasise that in the discussions preceding the formulation of the Atomic Energy Act there will be an attempt to define clearly the responsibilities of the States and the Commonwealth.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SOCIAL WELFARE: REPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare titled 'Another Side to the Drug Debate . . . a Medicated Society?' was tabled in May 1981. Can the Minister inform the Senate when he will be in a position to announce the Government's decisions on the Committee's recommendations?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PETER BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware of the report to which the honourable senator has referred, having had some part in its preparation while being a member of that Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chipp-Who chaired it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp asks who chaired the Committee. I simply say that at the time the report was presented the Committee was chaired by Senator Walters, with great distinction. The response to the Senate has to follow Cabinet consideration. I understand that this is imminent. Once that is complete it will be possible to come back to the Senate with a statement for honourable senators.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Is it a fact that one-third of all the Community Youth Support Scheme projects in Tasmania will miss out on funding when the current extension runs out this week? If so, can the Minister tell me why? If it is not a fact, what is the true position? Can the Minister tell me what is the total funding to be made available to CYSS projects in Tasmania from now on? How does that figure compare with the amount made available up to now?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Dame MARGARET GUILFOYLE

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has made any statement with regard to the CYSS projects but in discussion with my Department on the matter a day or so ago I was advised that the great majority of all CYSS projects had reapplied under the new guidelines that were recently announced and that the Department expected that the very great majority of them would be eligible for continued funding under the new arrangements. Representatives of the Department of Finance and the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs at present are discussing their departments' additional estimates. Some accommodation will need to be made for the whole of the latter Department's programs.

INTERJECT.PARA: It will be recalled that there was a global allocation for training and other programs and that some supplementary funding was given for CYSS until the end of February. We are now determining what will be the requirements of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. It will then be for that Department to decide within its global allocation and any additional funds that are given the requirements of the CYSS projects which are finally approved. From the discussion I had I think that the figure of one-third for the number of Tasmanian projects not likely to have their funding continued is not correct. I understand that the very great majority of them have reapplied and are likely to be eligible for continued funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. I refer the Minister to recent reports of calls for the Federal Government to interfere in an agreement, entered into under an Act of Parliament, between the Western Australian Government and the Ashton Joint Venture partners in respect of the mining, marketing and processing of diamonds recovered from mining tenements in Western Australia. Were the exploration and mining tenements pursuant to the Diamond (Ashton Joint Venture) Agreement Act 1981 granted under the Western Australian Mining Act by the Western Australian Government, which has exclusive authority over the land? Is the agreement under the Diamond (Ashton Joint Venture) Agreement Act 1981 between the Western Australian Government and the Ashton Joint Venture partners the only government agreement required to be entered into directly for the mining, marketing and processing of the diamonds? Is it a fact that the Western Australian Government, under the agreement, is entitled to have independent assessors value the diamonds? Is it a fact that any agreements or arrangements which the Ashton Joint Venture partners enter into for the processing and marketing of the diamonds are subject to the approval of the Western Australian Government? Will the Minister give a firm undertaking that the Federal Government will not introduce export controls on the diamonds? Finally, is it a fact that no substantial or firm proposal has been presented to the Western Australian Government for ratification by the partners?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —There are six aspects of the honourable senator's question. I will just sketch the picture as I see it at the moment. The conclusion of the Ashton Joint Venture marketing study, which has been a wide- ranging and complicated task, is to be welcomed by everyone as a further step towards large scale production of diamonds in Australia. I give honourable senators some idea of the magnitude of the venture so that the question can be appreciated: The Ashton Joint Venture has already spent $60m on exploration and evaluation of the deposits and initial capital outlay on the mine and plant is estimated at something like $300m, a figure which will increase with later expansion.

INTERJECT.PARA: There are several points to be noted about the proposal to sell diamonds. At this stage it is a recommendation to the AJV partners; no conclusion has been reached. Secondly, AJV would have the right to retain gem diamonds for cutting and polishing in Australia, which AJV intends to undertake at the earliest opportunity. Thirdly, AJV would market 25 per cent of other production in its own right. The sorting of all production, which is skilled and labour intensive, is to be done in Australia. Against that background my understanding is that the answer to the first part of the honourable senator's question is that this was a granting of a mining permit by the Western Australian Government, and the subsequent questions all concern relationships between the State Government and the mining partners. Of course, the Commonwealth Government has export control powers as latent powers which could be used if that were felt necessary, but those powers are used only on rare occasions. It has to be understood that in the first place the partners are people highly experienced in commercial industrial matters who understand the true value of resources and how to get the true value for a resource of Australia. So one can understand that they would not willingly underprice or undersell a resource.

That is the background. The agreement is not at this moment fully concluded. It is a complex matter because many of the diamonds are of industrial quality rather than of gem standard. There is a depressed price for diamonds in the world today and, therefore, it is a complex matter to arrive at a commercial deal. If there are futher aspects that my colleague in another place would like to add to the answer I will direct the honourable senator's attention to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Inasmuch as the agreement provides that the Western Australian Government will attract a royalty of 22.5 per cent above zero profit or 7.5 per cent of free on board revenue per year, and as the Western Australian Government has a right to its own assessment, is it a reasonable and fair proposition that the Western Australian Government will ensure that the diamonds are valued at an accurate and proper reflection of the world prices in the interests of its own revenue?

—I have never seen a Federal or State government willingly forgo revenue, whether it be tax revenue or royalty revenue. The only people whom I have seen deliberately forgo revenue for the Australian people are the honourable senators opposite. State governments that attract royalties are very earnest in their endeavours to ensure that the highest possible market price is achieved because that increases their revenue.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the importation and use in Australia of the chemical 2-nitropropane, a coating agent? Is it the case that the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration has found this substance to be carcinogenic and particularly toxic to the liver? Is this chemical in widespread use in the printing and paint industries, thus posing a severe health threat to workers in these industries? Is it also the case that it has been used in the processing of vegetable oil and to line water tanks in Western Australia and that this could be a source of widespread public exposure? What steps will the Government take to ensure that carcinogenic substances such as this are not used in the work place or released into the environment, thus endangering the health of thousands of Australians?

—I am interested in the question asked by Senator Childs. I do not think he indicated in his question the source of his information. That would be helpful to the Minister whom I represent. I am aware of the substance 2 -nitropropane but am not aware of the occupational health risks which he has attributed to it. If, as he suggests, it is hepatotoxic, it would join a large number of chemicals that have this property. Honourable senators will be aware of the numerous occupational health hazards arising from chemicals. I note that he talked about its use in the processing of vegetable oil. I remember that there was a concern some years ago about one of the monomers of vinyl chloride which was also used to coat containers. Perhaps it would be of assistance if Senator Childs made available the material he holds. I will then pass it on to my colleague and we will undertake to give it most serious consideration.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister of Primary Industry been drawn to the apprehension of an American tuna boat in Papua New Guinean waters by authorities of that country for contravention of its 200-mile economic zone legislation? Does Australia support the action taken by New Guinea? Would similar action be taken by Australia in similar circumstances?

—Australia has the same claim to territorial waters as does New Guinea and imposes much the same restrictions. We have licensing agreements which license American fishing boats to use Australian waters. Licensed boats, of course, are not subject to any interference. In the event that unlicensed fishing boats operate in Australian waters, they will be treated in the same manner as the boat to which Senator Archer referred.

DEBATE.TITLE: COST OF FEDERAL CABINET MEETING IN BRISBANE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware of a report in the latest issue of Inside Canberra which discloses that the Federal Cabinet meeting due to take place in Brisbane on 1 March will cost taxpayers approximately half a million dollars? Can the Minister give the Senate a correct estimate of the costs involved in holding the Cabinet meeting in Brisbane? Finally, at a time of stringent cutbacks in most areas of government expenditure , will the Prime Minister seriously consider cancelling the meeting in view of the exorbitant costs involved?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that all the residents of Queensland will take note of what I regard as a very quaint question. The Whitlam Government used to meet in Queensland too, and no doubt incurred expense. The belief of this Government is that it is useful for the Cabinet to meet at least once a year in States other than Victoria and New South Wales, where frequent meetings are held ; that is, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania. This gives the people the opportunity to meet Ministers and to meet--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chipp-Come off it. How many people would meet the Ministers?

TALK.START.PARA: —It so happens that the opportunity is taken for various delegations to meet Ministers when it is known that they will all be there. Of course, associated with these Cabinet meetings is a public reception at which leaders of various community groups come together with the Ministers. A cross-section of some 400 or 500 community leaders do, in fact, meet the Ministers and have the opportunity to express their views to them, however briefly. I am not aware that it would cost half a million dollars to take Cabinet to Brisbane. The fact is that the Government believes that it is a valuable thing. I am quite sure that the people of Queensland believe that it is a worthy thing for the Government to take its Cabinet to Brisbane and to have the opportunity of contact with the people of Queensland.

—Can the Minister representing the Prime Minister confirm that, under the tax sharing arrangements in place between the Commonwealth and the States, the declared intention of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to block the Government's sales tax measures will result in further major cuts in the funds which the States were expecting this year and the risk of further cuts in other areas of Federal Government spending? Can the Minister give the Senate some idea of the extent of the money involved?

—What Senator Reid said is true. In the recent agreement between the Premiers and the Commonwealth it was agreed that tax sharing should be based not on personal income tax only but on the total quantum of tax. The percentage of total tax that is broken up among the States is 20.72 per cent now, instead of 38.7 per cent of personal income tax as was the case in the past. It follows therefore that if, as will happen if the sales tax measures are blocked this year, there is a loss to revenue of $132m there will be a loss of $27.4m to the States. Indeed, with a $330m loss of revenue in a whole year there will be a loss to the States of $68.4m. These are large figures in terms of State revenue. The States will be deprived of that revenue for their various purposes by the defeating of the sales tax legislation.

—My question follows the question asked by Senator Reid. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Is it not a fact that this Government promised that any sales tax legislation would be introduced in conjunction with personal income tax relief? Is it not also a fact that the total additional amount of personal tax revenue gained by this Government this year will be in the order of $5,000m?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no understanding that there was a direct promise that sales tax would be introduced and that personal income tax would be cut.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Button-Well, you had better get it because it is on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite Senator Button to produce the record. The fact is that this Government indicated that, whilst the Australian people were relatively highly taxed by world standards in personal income tax, they were taxed relatively lightly, by world attitudes, in indirect tax. It was considered desirable to spread the burden in that way. The Government hoped that it might be able to bring about personal income tax cuts. But two or three things have happened. Firstly, the denial by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats of $330m in a full year will, of course, make it so much harder. I repeat the figures supplied by the Department of the Treasury: The prospective loss of sales tax revenue for the full year next year will be $330m; for this year it will be $132m. Therefore, in fact, the action of the Labor Party and the Democrats will reduce the ability of the Government to reduce income tax. Equally, the industrial strife that occurs, for example in Bass Strait, reduces income and so reduces the capacity of the Government to reduce income tax. The Government wants to introduce cuts in personal income tax, but the Government sees as its overriding responsibility the reduction of the deficit so as to bear down on inflation and interest rates. It would be one thing to give back nominal income tax cuts but the creation of a bigger deficit would add to inflation and therefore take away the real purchasing power of money. The Government regards the control of monetary policy as a primary responsibility.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister answer the second part of the question which he has been asked on three occasions in the past 10 days? Is it not a fact that the additional revenue increase from personal income tax gained by the Fraser Government this year will be in the order of $5,000m, as distinct from $330m for sales tax?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the precise figure but I will accept that if it is--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chipp-You have precise figures on everything else.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very happy to get the precise figure. I have said I am willing to accept Senator Button's figure. Nevertheless, that amount is on the revenue side of the Budget and even with those many thousands of millions of dollars a deficit is still created. So if one wants to use that money-in part or whole-to give back personal income tax one has one of three things to do: Impose other forms of taxation, cut back expenditure or blow out the deficit. They are the choices. We are not willing to blow out the deficit at all, unlike the Labor Government that had a deficit of $3.4 billion. Because of that and our attitude to money management we are bearing down on interest rates and inflation ahead of other responsibilities.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Thomas. Order! I have asked the Senate on previous occasions to extend courtesy when I call the next honourable senator to ask his or her question. This courtesy also should be extended to replies by Ministers.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, is similar to a question I asked on 22 October last year. Concern is still being expressed that by positioning the proposed domestic satellite over New Caledonia instead of over the Western Australia-Northern Territory border the quality of the signal received from the satellite will be insufficient to guarantee a perfect reception to all parts of Western Australia in all atmospheric conditions. Will the Minister give me an assurance that a final decision on the positioning of the satellite will not be made until it has been established beyond any doubt that the position is the optimum one for all Australians?

—I recall the honourable senator asking a question last year . I cannot be quite certain that it was on 22 October. I accept Senator Thomas's assurance that that is the date. I recall advising him at that time that the positioning of the satellite which was, I think, 160 degrees east would in fact give a stronger net signal in Western Australia than the previous intention which was to place the satellite directly over Australia. I gave some technical argument at that time which supported that assertion. I know of no new information to suggest that that is not still correct. In fact, placing the satellite east of Australia may concentrate the signal going to Western Australia. However the honourable senator asks whether we will make quite certain that that information is correct. I will ask the Minister whom I represent for that assurance and will make that information available to the honourable senator. Of course I am sure that the Minister will make it available to us.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Knowing, as we do, how deeply respectful this Government always is of the views of Sir Billy Snedden, I ask: Does the Government accept the view of Sir Billy reported in this morning's Press that the Executive, especially in the person of the Governor-General, has too much power relative to the legislature, that another 1975-type constitutional crisis is inevitable sooner or later and that when it does come Australia is destined to become a United States-type republic? I further ask him whether or not the Government accepts this particular scenario, what is it doing to advance the cause of constitutional reform by less spectacular means? In particular, what is the future of the proposal for a further session of the Australian Constitutional Convention this year, as endorsed of course by the Senate last Thursday night, in light of the failure of last Friday's Premiers Conference to reach that item on its agenda?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator DURACK

TALK.START.PARA: —I have very little knowledge of Sir Billy Snedden's views, although I did gain some cursory knowledge of them from reading the Press this morning. On such a serious matter I would really like to have the opportunity of studying his views, although, as I said, I think he was making forecasts of what might happen rather than expressing any belief of his that that is what ought to happen. However, without studying his views, I am not able to make even that judgment.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Evans has introduced into the Senate a Bill to make major constitutional changes. The Government has not yet considered what position it will take in relation to that legislation, although I am hopeful that it will be able to deal with that matter shortly. If Senator Evans wishes, as no doubt he does, to bring the matter on for debate in the Senate, I do not wish to say anything further in relation to the matter; it will be very seriously debated in this chamber in the near future. As we know, the Constitutional Convention was placed on the agenda for the Premiers Conference last Friday but that item was not reached. In those circumstances, I am giving consideration to what the next step should be in ascertaining the views of the States. The Premiers of course will be meeting again. I have not yet decided whether to wait until then or whether to try to activate some attention to the subject by the Premiers before they meet again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. With the dramatic fall in the spot prices for petroleum and the oversupply by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries forcing prices down, can we expect these price reductions or declines to be reflected in prices to the Australian motorist?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —The fall in the real price of oil over the past year or so has resulted in a fall in the real price of oil and oil products to the Australian motorist because the price of oil has gone up by less than the rate of inflation. The situation is that, as the result of a number of initiatives- first of all, a decision by the International Energy Agency members to reduce their purchases of oil considerably; secondly, very big conservation measures, particularly in countries such as America and Japan; and thirdly, Saudi-Arabia's increase of output-a temporary glut of oil, oil products and, indeed, products such as liquefied petroleum gas has been brought about. I say 'temporary' because nothing alters the fact that oil is a finite resource and is being used at a rate that, in the course of the decades ahead, will virtually exhaust it. It is a temporary glut added to by recessive characteristics in countries throughout the world.

INTERJECT.PARA: Another significant situation which is occurring is that Iran and Iraq, which have been at war, face serious balance of exchange problems. Iran in particular is producing oil on to world markets at a discounted price below the price of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries. This may sound good news to those who, in the short term, want cheaper oil but there is some considerable danger to the stability of quite a number of countries if there should be economic or political instability within OPEC. I cannot tell, therefore, whether the Saudi-Arabian market price will remain where it is at the moment, at $34, or whether it will move.

When I was in Saudi-Arabia one month or six weeks ago Sheik Yamani foreshadowed that he thought the price would hold, that there would be no upward movement of the oil price in OPEC this year, and that he felt that next year there would be an upward movement in the price of OPEC oil but not as great as the rate of inflation. He considered the possibility of some reduction in the volume of Saudi-Arabian output in order to stabilise the situation. At this moment it is a very delicate situation, contributed to by Iran's discounting. There are quite a number of oil producing countries whose output at this moment is at the minimum which, in their judgment, is required for the maintenance of their economies and their general living standards. So we could get some destabilisation.

If the price of oil stays as it is or falls slightly this year then, of course, there will be a fall in price in real terms. The price in Australia is geared to the Saudi-Arabian market price and, therefore, would move with it. It is significant now to look at what has happened and to reflect upon what members of the Australian Labor Party used as claims in scare tactics some 14 months ago, before the last elections. They tried to frighten the people but the very reverse of what they claimed would happen has happened. No one can say what might happen in the long term because a judgment has to be made as to the stability or otherwise of the Middle East. But we will be fixing our price according to the Saudi-Arabian light crude market price.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether the calendar of main economic events attached to the celebrated Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development survey of Australia shows that various official interest rates, which had been held steady for many months before the October 1980 election, went up in the week after that election and went up again no fewer than six times between 13 November and 17 December after the Queensland election was also out of the way. Will he give an assurance that the Government is not again delaying interest rate rises until after the Lowe by-election and Victorian election are out of the way?

—The Government, in its determination of interest rates , is very sensitive and susceptible to the advice of the Reserve Bank Board and the Department of the Treasury. My instinct is that in general terms that advice has been observed over the period. It may be that there has been some variation of a minor scale but, to my memory, the Government has departed little, if at all, from the advice that it has had. The decision-making of the Government on interest rates, therefore, has been done without regard to election campaigns because the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Department of the Treasury are not so influenced. On the other hand, the completely irresponsible prediction of the Premier of New South Wales that interest rates would rise to 18 per cent was made with full regard to elections. I was delighted to see it condemned by virtually every responsible economist and senior businessman in Australia. So the Government is acting responsibly. If electioneering comments are made, they are made by the Australian Labor Party.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I assume that the Western Australian Premier is equally as irresponsible as the Premier of New South Wales since he made exactly the same prediction. My supplementary question refers to Senator Sir John Carrick's statement that the advice of the Reserve Bank of Australia is observed by the Government generally with respect to interest rates. I ask whether one of the occasions on which the advice was not observed is the one referred to on page 8 of the Reserve Bank's latest annual report in which it states that there were protracted differences of opinion between the Bank and the Government regarding interest rate policy between September and December of 1980-in other words, the period to which I referred- and that those differences of opinion were not finally resolved until December 1980.

—I have nothing to add to the answer that I have given. The discussions that occur between the Reserve Bank and the Government, except with regard to statutory reporting, are, as with all governments, confidential. I repeat that the discussions, apart from the statutory requirements, are confidential. We have observed those conditions all the time as, indeed, have previous governments.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Dame MARGARET GUILFOYLE

TALK.START.PARA: — On 18 February I advised that I would provide the Senate with further information concerning Press reports which suggested a link between the United States contingent to the Sinai Multinational Force of Observers and the United States rapid deployment force. Prior to these reports, assurances had been received from the United States that no part of the Sinai peacekeeping force, including the United States component, would have any association with the rapid deployment force. The Government, nevertheless, sought further clarification from Washington. In response to this request, the United States Government has provided specific details of the legislation passed by the United States Congress setting out the conditions for the United States participation in the MFO. This legislation takes the form of a United States Senate-House joint resolution. It states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Members of the United States armed forces, and United States civilian personnel , who are assigned, detailed, or otherwise provided to the Multinational Force of Observers may perform only those functions or responsibilities which are specified for United Nations forces and observers in the Treaty of Peace and in accordance with the Protocol.
In commenting on the joint resolution, the report of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs stated:

Paragraph 3 (of the Joint Resolution) stipulates that members of the United States armed forces assigned to the MFO may not perform any functions or responsibility not specified in the Egyptian/Israeli Peace Treaty for United Nations force and observers and in the protocol. Article VI of the Annex 1 to the Treaty of Peace specified those functions to be supervision of the implementation of Annex 1 of the Treaty and employment of best efforts to prevent violation of its terms. Specified arrangements set forth in that Annex are: operation of check points, reconnaissance patrols, and observation posts along the international boundary between Egypt and Israel, and at various points in the Sinai; periodic verification of the implementation of the provisions of the Annex; additional verification activities at the request of either Egypt or Israel; and arrangements insuring the freedom of navigation through the Strait of Tiran.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs notes that it is a matter of regret that either intentionally or through ignorance attempts have been made to confuse the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very last part of an answer I gave to a question from Senator Jessop today I indicated that in the case of Mrs Simpson the Repatriation Review Tribunal had before it the expert advice of three independent experts and that they had stated there was no link between lymphoma and exposure to toxic chemicals. Upon reflection, I feel I should make it clear that in fact the experts all concluded that the very great weight of evidence was against there being any link, but that while there was the remotest prospect that such a link existed that remote prospect could not be definitely ruled out.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY LIBRARY: BILLS DIGEST INFORMATION SERVICE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 16 February, Senator McLaren raised a question concerning the Bills Digest Information Service provided by the Legislative Research Service of the Department of the Parliamentary Library. I undertook to discuss the point with senior officers of the Library. I have done this and have had lengthy discussions with the Acting Parliamentary Librarian, the head of the Legislative Research Service and two other senior officers of the Legislative Research Service.

INTERJECT.PARA: It is the aim of the Library to have a digest prepared for all Bills, and every effort is made to do this. On those occasions when a digest is not prepared it is as a result of the pressure of urgent work for honourable senators and members. This pressure is a result of a continuing rise in the number of requests year after year being handled by a staff whose number is static over the same period. In addition, the Legislative Research Service prepares general background work in the form of basic papers and current issue briefs, writes papers for delegations of parliamentarians proceeding overseas and prepares material for the Estimates Committee of the House of Representatives. When a digest is not prepared, therefore, it is as a result of the exigencies of the time and has no other origin. In 1981 some digests were not prepared, most of them being in respect of government measures.

The submission to which Senator McLaren referred is an internal document. I assure the honourable senator that Mr Speaker and I will do our best to have the staff ceiling of the Parliamentary Library raised for the year 1982-83. The problem is one which attracted considerable discussion in Senate Estimates Committee A on 15 September last when the estimates of the Parliamentary Library were under examination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In conformity with Standing Order 408, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Can you give the chamber some indication of the subject matter, in accordance with the practice we have adopted?
—Yes, it is a matter concerning two motions which were in my charge in the Senate on Thursday night and which have been misreported in the Canberra Times.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I will be brief. I refer to an article in the Canberra Times of Friday, 19 February headed 'In Parliament Yesterday'. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . notice of motion relating to the Prime Minister's occupancy of The Lodge (Senator McLaren) moved and postponed;

Honourable senators who were in the chamber know that that motion was carried unanimously. That is recorded in the Journals of the Senate. The report in the Canberra Times dealing with the other matter reads:
. . . notice of motion relating to telephone service for previous Governor- General (Senator McLaren) adjourned;

Those honourable senators who were in the chamber and who took part in the vote know that that motion also was passed unanimously. In another part of the Canberra Times of the same day there is a small paragraph which states that both motions were carried. People who might not have read that but have read the report of the parliamentary proceedings could have been misled. I want to correct those two reports concerning the proceedings of the Senate as they related to me.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the first report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee has met to consider all Bills which were before each House of the Parliament at the commencement of these sittings, and now presents its report on the clauses of Bills which have come before the Senate and which the Committee considers may fall within the terms of reference included in the resolution of the Senate of 19 November 1981. The Committee was greatly assisted in its consideration of the Bills by Professor Dennis Pearce, Professor of Law at the Australian National University, whom the Committee appointed, with your approval, Mr President, as its counsel, from 1 December 1981 to 30 June 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: In this first report to the Senate, the Committee has given a brief outline of its method of operation so far. Given the experimental nature of the Committee, however, the procedures described are not intended to be definitive, and the Committee would welcome any suggestions from senators before it is required to report to the Senate, before 30 June 1982, on its work and the need, if any, for a separately constituted committee.

For the information of honourable senators, I also table a document entitled ' Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest', which includes the Committee's preliminary views on proposed laws on which the Committee has not yet reported to the Senate . As the Digest indicates, the Committee invites any senator who wishes to do so to draw matters to the attention of the Committee under its terms of reference. Copies of the Digest are being delivered to honourable senators.

The report draws the attention of the Senate to some 29 clauses of 9 Bills presently before the Senate and it does so in accordance with our terms of reference. This is quite apart from clauses of other Bills which we have preliminarily examined and which will be reported on when those Bills come before this House after passage in the House of Representatives. The significance of this reporting process should not be exaggerated. The present report contains nothing of a sensational or dramatic nature but does reveal a number of provisions that ought to be scrutinised carefully by the Senate in the light of our terms of reference.

Where there are doubts about the clause's intention or its drafting or where it may be a matter of policy on the part of the Government, but this is not revealed in the second reading speech and other documents, nonetheless we feel it is desirable to draw the problems to senators' attention so that they may appreciate and resolve the issue, where necessary. If, on investigation, the clause appears to come within our terms of reference, we will normally report it to the Senate.
I believe the report demonstrates a valuable role to be performed in the legislative process and will be of practical assistance to the Senate in its examination of the legislation now before it.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS (PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to amend in two respects the International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1963, to enable Australia to meet certain treaty obligations.

The first amendment (dealt with in Clauses 2 to 5 of the Bill) is achieved by making individual amendments to a number of Sections of the Act. The need for this amendment has arisen from the terms of an agreement which is to be concluded between Australia and the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources which we expect will set up its headquarters in Hobart, in early 1982.

Under the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources, which was concluded at a Conference in Canberra in May 1980 and which Australia ratified on 6 May 1981, Australia agreed to accord the Commission and its staff certain privileges and immunities as required by international practice. International practice also requires that a person attending a conference convened by the Commission as a representative of a member country be accorded privileges and immunities. These privileges and immunities for both staff of the Commission and representatives of member countries can be accorded under the 1963 Act as it stands.

In the case of the Convention, however, not only countries may become parties but also regional economic integration organisations, such as the European Communities, may accede once the Convention has entered into force. In addition, representatives of regional organisations and international organisations in which Australia participates might be invited to attend meetings in Australia of the organs set up under the Convention.

When the 1963 Act was drafted it was not contemplated that international organisations, as well as countries, would become members of other international organisations. It is necessary, therefore, to expand the power to make regulations under the Act so that representatives of international organisations attending the Commission's conferences in Australia may be accorded similar privileges and immunities to those accorded to the representatives of member countries.

The Bill makes a number of amendments to the principal Act to achieve this. In effect, every reference in the Act to representatives of countries will be extended to include a reference to representatives of certain prescribed international organisations.

The representatives of certain international organisations only will be eligible to be accorded privileges and immunities under the Bill. The international organisations are those of which Australia is a member and those which the Bill describes as ''overseas organizations'' such as the European Communities, of which Australia cannot become a member because the organisations are composed of countries in a particular geographical region. For the Act to apply to an international organisation it must be so declared by regulations under the Act.

At the same time, the definition of ''international conference'' is amended so that it will include not only a conference attended by representatives from Australia and representatives from another country, but also by representatives from a prescribed international organisation. This will enable Australia in future to accord the appropriate privileges and immunities to those representatives.

The second amendment (dealt with in Clause 6 of the Bill) will enable Australia to implement by regulation a taxation obligation under two specific agreements- one establishing the Common Fund for Commodities and the other establishing the Asian Development Bank. Those agreements provide, among other things, that foreign experts and committee members be accorded exemption from Australian income tax when visiting or working in Australia.

As the Act now stands, there is no provision in the Fifth Schedule which would enable regulations to be made to grant income tax exemption to persons in those categories. Clause 6 of the Bill will amend the Fifth Schedule of the Act to include such a provision.

If the Bill is passed, regulations will be made as soon as practicable to accord this exemption. I understand from the Treasurer that exemption will be extended under present taxation policy to experts and committee members involved in the work of an organisation only if the Agreement establishing the organisation specifically permits Australia to tax Australian citizens working for that organisation, regardless of their employment status or location. This is the case with the Common Fund and the Asian Development Bank.

This measure should not be significant in terms of revenue forgone. The exemption is likely to be available in respect of few organisations in the future and the total number of persons involved should be small.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will give effect to the Government's decision to establish the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR), which the Minister for Foreign Affairs announced in his statement to the House on 20 August 1981.
It may assist honourable senators in their understanding of this proposal if I again briefly explain the essential background.

Australia is one of the world's leading agricultural countries. Our agricultural production has long exceeded our own requirements and our agricultural exports have been and continue to be a major source of Australia's wealth. As a result we are perhaps a little complacent on the subject of food security. At no time since our very early history have we needed to be concerned about where our basic food supply and other agricultural products are to come from or whether we will have enough. Certainly we have had good years and bad years but these have affected only our relative wealth-not whether we will have enough to eat.

That is not, however, the situation in many other countries of the world. It is one of the major tragedies of our times that each year millions still die simply because they do not have enough to eat. As the Prime Minister recently mentioned at CHOGM ''lack of adequate food probably affects 250 million people in the Commonwealth and maybe 500 million worldwide''.

Again the Prime Minister alluded to this problem when he stated that ''world per capita food production declined in 1980 for the second year running and the carry-over of cereal stocks at the end of 1980-81 was at the lowest level for about five or six years''.

The international community has recognised this situation since the end of the Second World War and tried to deal with it through a number of programs. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation and the World Food Program ( both substantially supported by Australia) are visible proof of international concern.

More recently, in 1971, the international community established the Consultative Group for International Agricultural Research (CGIAR) which is an association of countries, international and regional organisations and private foundations dedicated to supporting a system of 13 international agricultural research centres around the world.
