In our region the best known of these is IRRI , the International Rice Research Institute, in the Philippines. The achievements of these centres are already very considerable, but a great deal more needs to be done by the international community to achieve food security. By food security I mean nutritionally adequate food supplies and effective food storage and distribution.

The Brandt Commission Report spells out the need for a continuing major effort for many years to come. The Harries Report on Australia's relations with the Third World re-emphasises this point. Commonwealth Heads of Government also identified the lack of food security as one of the major issues facing many countries of the developing world.

The agricultural surpluses we and other developed countries produce can never be a long-term solution to the food security problem, no matter how concessional the terms upon which food aid is provided. For developing countries to improve their situation and to produce more themselves will require the introduction or discovery of techniques and plant and animal strains which make more efficient use of available land resources.

Mr President, Australia is uniquely placed to assist developing countries in the area of agriculture. We are recognised as having particular expertise and experience in agricultural research and development over a wide range of climatic and environmental conditions, from dryland farming to tropical livestock and agricultural production.

In 1980-81 our spending under the aid program on agricultural research and related activities was estimated to have been about $12 million. This is quite significant. It was however, based to a considerable extent upon ad hoc requests for assistance from aid recipient governments. While the activities supported were each worthwhile in themselves they lacked co-ordination. The reason this was so, Mr President, is that no mechanism presently exists to foster a more systematic approach.
There are other factors that inhibit the most effective application of Australian expertise to the agricultural problems of developing countries.

The lack of an effective mechanism within Australia for systematically identifying the agricultural problems of developing countries, including the identification of those areas of research which warrant Australia's support;

The lack of a satisfactory mechanism for marshalling the collective expertise of bodies such as universities, State Departments of Agriculture, CSIRO and suitably competent private individuals and organisations to assist in solving the identified problems;
The failure of Australian laboratories to provide support for scientists engaged in agricultural research in developing countries;

The reluctance of the Australian research system to give proper credit to research performed in developing countries by Australian scientists, who are therefore disadvantaged compared with scientists who remain in Australia to pursue more recognised lines of research.

Research in industrialised countries tends to be concentrated on those agricultural commodities that are important to their own economies. Consequently , little attention is given to new ideas and techniques specifically related to agricultural production in developing countries. This is a limiting factor to increased food production in the developing countries.

In order to overcome these difficulties, consideration has been given to how to develop an expanded, better co-ordinated and more identifiable Australian effort , aimed at achieving nutritional self-sufficiency in developing countries. After very widespread consultation within the Australian scientific community and with other interested parties, the Government has decided to establish the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research.
Mr President, I turn now to the particular provisions of the Bill before the Parliament.

The functions of the Centre, as set out in Clause 5 of the Bill, are to mobilise and expand Australia's research capacity so as to assist developing countries in agriculture and related areas. The Centre will provide what is not currently available-namely a capacity to fund research by Australian persons and institutions specifically to benefit developing countries.

At this point I should emphasise that the Centre will not itself engage in research activities. It will not attempt to emulate or duplicate the resources of existing institutions, and indeed it will be expressly debarred from becoming a research institution in its own right. It will, however, be charged with contracting research work to appropriate bodies of the kind to which I referred earlier, i.e. universities, State departments of agriculture, CSIRO and suitably competent private individuals and organisations.

Honourable senators will note that the Bill does not attempt to define the term 'agriculture' for the purposes of the legislation, but instead indicates that the term will be specified by regulation. I should state, therefore, the Government's view on this point. In short, the Government sees no activity that has as its objective the production of a commodity that grows on or depends upon the land, or lives in or depends upon the water, as being excluded from the Centre's possible attention. The regulations will therefore define the term in the broadest possible way and will not confine the Centre to that discipline we know as 'agriculture' to differentiate it from other forms of land use.

Nor will the Centre's activities be confined to arranging research to be undertaken solely by Australian persons or institutions (although all the research contracts it enters into will be with Australian persons or institutions). A key element of the research programs the Centre commissions will be the involvement in them of developing country scientists and institutions. Collaborative arrangements of this kind will be fundamental to the success of the work commissioned by the Centre.

There is no reference in the functions of the Centre to a responsibility to arrange training. This is no oversight. Clearly the training of agricultural research scientists from developing countries is of basic importance to the development of their own indigenous research capacity. Provision already exists, however, within the development training programs conducted by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau (ADAB) for Australia to provide assistance with the formal academic training of scientists from developing countries.

The Centre will have no responsibility for extension programs through which the results of its research could be applied in the field. Again, Mr President, this is no oversight. Extension activities normally require the commitment of significant resources and often the active involvement of the host government. While the Centre will be able to develop and promote close contacts with and between research institutes, it is not appropriate that it deal directly with foreign governments. The Australian Development Assistance Bureau is an agency which has precisely this mandate on behalf of Australia, and it is that agency which should pursue the matter of extension programs in the context of the aid program for which it is responsible.

The Centre's activities will result in the need for projects to implement research findings in the field. Accordingly there will need to be close liaison between the Centre and the Bureau to enable such projects to be developed and funded.

This has been provided for formally by the inclusion of the Director of ADAB on both the Policy Advisory Council and the Board of Management of the Centre in an ex officio capacity. In addition, the Centre is expected to be located close to the Bureau and its support services will be provided, in common with those of the Bureau, by the appropriate areas of the Department of Foreign Affairs. This will ensure adequate communication between the two organisations so that the successful results of the Centre's activities are backed up where necessary by appropriate extension programs.

I turn now to the staffing of the Centre. ACIAR's administrative expenses will be kept to a minimum. As already explained all research work will be contracted out. However, the Centre will require the capacity to identify needs and priorities for agricultural research in developing countries, prepare briefs and commission contracts for research and to monitor critically progress of the research and the contracts under which it is conducted. I envisage that the Centre will eventually need a staff of about ten. Although they will be employed under the Public Service Act, they may be recruited from outside the Commonwealth Public Service while remaining fully within the Centre's own control.

Clearly the operation of the Centre, working under the constraints of the long term nature of agricultural research and the long lead time required to obtain results, calls for flexibility, stability in funding arrangements and, above all , staff of such stature as to command respect among scientists in Australia and in developing countries.
The chief executive officer of the Centre-its Director-will be critical to its success and will need to be a person of outstanding ability, recognised for his professional and managerial capacities.

In the consultations we have had that have led to the establishment of the Centre, a consistent and strongly expressed preference by the Australian scientific community has emerged for the Centre to be a small statutory body. The success of ACIAR will depend on the enthusiastic co-operation of the scientific community and this will be assured with a statutory body with firm funding commitments. ACIAR will be responsible to the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

The Government has, of course, in reaching this decision recognised the potential for statutory authorities, once established, to lead a life of their own and to continue after the need for them has disappeared. The Government has guarded against this eventuality in three ways. First, the Centre's internal administration will be managed through the Department of Foreign Affairs. This means that a close, direct and continuous oversight will be maintained on resources required to administer the Centre. Second, the Centre is to have a finite life of twelve years. Clauses 43 and 44 require that the Centre should cease to operate after that period unless amending legislation is introduced by the Government, i.e. a so called ''sunset provision''. In order that the Government can reach a decision in this matter, it is proposed that the need for the Centre as well as its operations and effectiveness be reviewed in the tenth year. The review should be completed in sufficient time to enable a copy of the report of the review to be tabled before the expiration of the period of twelve years. Third, the funds of the Centre will be handled through a Trust Fund within the public account and under the provisions of the Audit Act.

These elements of the legislation, together with the more normal controls requiring the Centre to submit annual reports, estimates of expenditure, financial statements, annual Parliamentary appropriation of funds and Ministerial power of direction, will ensure that the Centre functions in accordance with the Government's objectives.

The Centre will have a Policy Advisory Council that will be representative of developed and developing country expertise. The Council will be so constituted as to ensure Australian control but at the same time provide developing countries with a real opportunity to influence the Centre's activities. This is an innovation of great importance which has already attracted favourable international comment.

The Council will meet at least once a year and members will be selected on the basis of the contribution individual members will be able to make to the work of the Centre and to provide a balance between disciplines and skills. The term of office will be up to three years. Membership will be rotated to bring in fresh skills and expertise and to ensure the continuing relevance of the Council to the changing needs of developing countries.

The Council will consist of 17 Ministerially appointed members, One of whom will be its President, as well as the Directors of the Centre itself and ADAB in their official capacities. While in a minority, a substantial number will be representative of developing countries or other overseas research institutions. The majority of Council members will thus be representative of Australian institutions and organisations, in particular the Universities, State Departments of Agriculture and the CSIRO. My colleagues, the Ministers for Primary Industry and Science and Technology, will each nominate one member of the Council.

The composition of the Policy Advisory Council reflects Australia's determination to direct the Centre's attention specifically and directly to the needs of developing countries. The Centre will not become a means of supplementing the funding of Australian institutions engaged on agricultural research related to Australia's problems. Other avenues for funding this already exist.

In recognition of the importance of the Centre's role, the Government has decided to establish an interim council pending passage of the legislation that will formally establish the Centre. The Minister for Foreign Affairs is grateful to Sir John Crawford for agreeing to chair the Interim Council and to the other members, whose appointment he announced on 6 October, for agreeing to serve on it.

In addition to the Policy Advisory Council, the Bill provides for the establishment of a Board of Management which will be responsible to the Minister for the conduct of the affairs of the Centre. It is proposed that the Board should consist of the President of the Council, the Directors of ACIAR and ADAB, all ex officio, and three other members appointed by the Governor-General from among the members of the Council. One of these the Governor-General will appoint as Chairman.

Mr President, ACIAR will benefit both giver and receiver. While its primary purpose is to assist developing countries, Australia too will gain in the following ways: enhance contact between our agricultural scientists and their overseas colleagues; the increased information Australia will have at its disposal on the agricultural problems of developing countries; by strengthening the links between Australian and overseas scientists and institutions; and finally some of the solutions the research sponsored by the Centre produces, will be of direct and practical benefit to Australia even though that may not have been the original intention.

Mr President, the Government believes that ACIAR represents an important new element in our assistance to developing countries. It is already being seen internationally as a practical demonstration of Australia's concern for and commitment to one of the major objectives of the North-South dialogue-the achievement by developing countries of greater self-reliance in agricultural production and increased food security.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide an underwriting arrangement to support, if necessary, returns to producers of Dried Sultana Grapes in the 1982 to 1986 seasons inclusive. The arrangement is acceptable to the Dried Vine Fruits industry. At the Industry's request, it is to apply only to sultanas, which account for about 85 per cent of the production of Dried Vine Fruits.

A Stabilization Scheme for Dried Vine Fruits has been in existence for most seasons since 1964. The latest arrangement, which applied to dried sultanas of the 1978 to 1980 seasons, was terminated at industry request late in 1980 when it became evident that very favourable export prices in those seasons had made Government support unnecessary.

Export prices for Dried Vine Fruits are highly volatile, and respond to variations in supplies from the main exporting countries. A major crop failure, as in the United States of America in 1978, can trigger off large rises in world prices. On the other hand, abundant supplies can develop quickly, leading to keen price competition. World production in 1980-81 was relatively high and further big crops in 1981-82 in several major producing countries of the northern hemisphere have brought a sharp reduction in world prices.
Export returns in the next several seasons may therefore be below levels in recent years, although it is difficult to forecast the extent and duration of such a situation.

The domestic market absorbs about one third of our production of dried sultanas . While, in future, sales and prices on this market should be maintained, the possibility of import competition is likely to ensure that any rise in home market prices will be moderate.
The industry and the Government are however concerned that the income position of Australian producers could be vulnerable, if an abrupt worsening of conditions on world markets should occur.
The Government has therefore decided to implement an underwriting arrangement to provide a measure of security for producers against sudden, large falls in world prices.

The arrangement, which the Government has prepared after full consultation with the industry, will afford security for producers but will not insulate them from market price signals, which might be indicating that fundamental changes should be made to the structure of production and trade.
The industry has given the Government an undertaking that it will not seek, during the life of the arrangement, any increase in the import tariff on sultanas.

The underwriting arrangement is based on the Government guarenteeing minimum returns per tonne from production in the 1982, 1983 and 1984 seasons equal to 90 per cent of the average of net returns per tonne to packers in the preceding two seasons and the estimated net return for the current season. In 1985 and 1986 seasons, the guaranteed minimum return will be 95 per cent of the three year average net return.
If the net return for a season is less than the guaranteed level, an underwriting payment, equal to the difference, would be made in respect to the total production in that season.
The provision for the guaranteed minimum return to be set at 90 per cent in the first three seasons reflects the very high export prices which the industry has enjoyed in recent seasons.

As I have said, the determination of the three year average return requires an estimate to be made of the average return for the current season. This is to be determined by the Minister for Primary Industry after consideration of advice and information provided by the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

The Administration of the underwriting arrangement is to be vested in the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. In this regard the Bill provides that the Corporation shall comply with any direction the Minister might give it in relation to the exercise of its existing powers under the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Act 1978 concerning the determination of prices below which sultanas may not be exported.

The underwriting arrangement embodied in this Bill is similiar to systems which the Government has introduced for the wheat, dairy and apple and pear industries . It is consistent with the export pricing policies which the Government has developed for those industries.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Walsh) adjourned.

That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to speak on the first reading of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills. A major livestock industry problem to which scientific research has failed to produce a complete solution is cattle tick infestation. The damage wreaked upon the cattle industry by tick is well documented. Reproductive performance and growth rates are very seriously inhibited and with severe infestations mortality rates can be high, especially in young animals. An Australian Institute of Agricultural Science report of 1979 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Parasites--
That is, parasites of cattle-
cause serious economic losses, the most serious is the cattle tick.

Eradication of this parasite is technically feasible in individual herds but only if repeated and completely clean musters can be achieved. Even where that feat is feasible it is a laborious and costly process for cattle producers. The law in New South Wales, for example, requires the owner of an infected herd to dip the entire herd, under supervision, every three weeks for a period of nine months. Moreover, all properties immediately adjoining the infected property must go through the same procedures even though no ticks have been detected. The cheapest and most effective means of avoiding that costly and uncertain eradication program is to quarantine areas known to be infected. This entails restrictions not only on the movement of live animals but also on fodder, fittings and animal products.

The movement of fodder from Queensland into New South Wales is prohibited unless the fodder has been fumigated. One would expect a grazier and a senior Country Party Minister, especially one who had been a Minister for Primary Industry, to be more than usually aware of the need to protect clean areas and to be zealous in observing quarantine regulations. Regrettably, that is not the case. In August of last year or thereabouts unfumigated hay was purchased in Queensland and taken against the law from Queensland into New South Wales and delivered to Glenclair, the property of Communications Minister Ian Sinclair. Mr Sinclair would have us believe that he was an innocent bystander to these events , the blameless victim yet again of circumstances beyond his control, of the perfidy of others. However, yet again he has been the financial beneficiary of the very perfidy he purports to deplore. I am not suggesting that the Minister was actually driving the truck. I am stating that it was his hay, his cheap Queensland hay, hay destined for his farm, which was loaded on the truck. Ian Sinclair was not technically responsible for evading the tick controls but there is no doubt that his hay, bought in Queensland presumably to cut costs on his farm, did by-pass the tick gates and thus put at risk of infection the New England cattle industry. I understand that the same hay found its way also onto the properties of several of his neighbours.

When the presence of the illegal hay became known to the authorities all the properties, that is, those of the Minister and his neighbours were placed under quarantine. Livestock on them were inspected periodically by New South Wales government officers. I understand that the quarantine has recently been lifted. No prosecution has been instigated, even though the Minister would have us believe it is an open and shut case against a careless truck driver who brought the offending hay unsolicited onto the Sinclair farm. It is a wonder that he does not claim that George Sinclair ordered the hay. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of course knows that Ian Sinclair was the completely innocent victim of his evil old father's larceny, a penalty, in the Prime Minister's judgment, not mitigated at all by Ian Sinclair's being the recipient of the stolen $400,000-odd that wicked old George had taken from the Walshes. Knowing how Ian had been disadvantaged by his father's embezzlement the Prime Minister decided that it was only fair that Ian be allowed to maintain the family company in a solvent state by keeping the stolen money for an extended period. For that reason, supplemented by the fact that Ian Sinclair had agreed to repay the stolen money-eventually-the Prime Minister on 19 August 1980 reinstated him as the fourth most senior Minister in the Fraser Government. Among other things the $100,000 repayment due on 1 February this year under the deed of covenant detailing repayment terms no doubt imposed stringent economy on the Sinclair farm managerial policy and its decision to purchase cheap hay which was illegally transported from Queensland to New South Wales.

For a man as experienced as the Minister for Communications in both business and public administration Ian Sinclair has had a surprising number of accident- prone or delinquent subordinates. Pre-eminent among these was, of course, Tony Webster, at the Australian Dairy Corporation. Now we have this anonymous truck driver. Both were set up to take the rap in the now familiar Sinclair style reversal of the Westminster system-if anything goes wrong, or perhaps more accurately, if one gets caught, blame it on a subordinate. Ian Sinclair has now become almost a professional victim of circumstance. Poor Ian Sinclair was, of course, the victim of circumstances when, as Minister for Primary Industry, he presided over the Australian Dairy Corporation's record breaking run in 1976 with respect to General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. On that occasion, he would have us believe, he was a victim of the perfidy of the Dairy Corporation's management which had concealed from him the continuing breach. The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations chose unanimously not to believe that version of events-a conclusion vindicated by the telex from Jack McGuire, tabled in the House of Representatives on 18 November last year ironically by Mr Sinclair himself.

It is, of course, well known that Ian Sinclair has little knowledge of or interest in financial transactions associated with his family companies and farming business. Indeed, Judge Staunton found to that effect. But on his own authority we know that he maintains a keen interest in the farm's physical operations. For example, he is quoted in the Land of 14 January as saying:

But I still like to be involved in all the major stock decisions. I'm there at the weekend and I try to have a look at the stock. I sign cheques and give orders and ask why last week's orders weren't carried out. Occasionally I participate in calf-marking or hay-making or something like that, but really my actual physical time on the farm is getting less and less.

Mr Fraser, Mr Anthony, Mr Nixon and the Country Party in general trenchantly asserted, in spite of the evidence of Mr Webster and the conclusions of the Senate Committee, confirmed later by Mr McGuire, that Mr Sinclair did not know what was going on in the Dairy Corporation in 1976. Surely none of them would dispute Mr Sinclair's own assertion that he does know what is going on on his farm.

It is well known that I am no admirer of the Country Party, much less of its senior Ministers. I am appalled that its deputy leader, for the sake of a bit of cheap hay, would risk thrusting a crippling burden on the cattle industry of northern New South Wales. The cattle industry has suffered enough from Country Party indifference and incompetence. It should not be exposed to biological sabotage instigated by that party's deputy leader.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address myself, unusually I suppose, to the actual substantive matter of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 [No. 2] (1982). I am very keen to pick up this debate as I have not had an opportunity in earlier discussions in the Senate with regard to the sales tax legislation to do so. It is something on which I have a very personal understanding, a very strong feeling, about the kinds of developments which this Government has been trying to achieve with its policy towards extending the range of sales tax. It is pretty clear that in this country there has been a great deal of criticism over the years of the form of direct taxation as it is imposed on individuals in this country. The income tax complaints, the constant calls for tax cuts, are well known and well understood by members of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: It has become increasingly clear that the potential for substantially cutting the amounts of income tax which are imposed on individuals in the community would rely very greatly upon the Government's being able to extend the range of taxes by perhaps, a consumption tax on goods themselves being taxed rather than having people taxed at the source of their incomes. Of course, we know substantially the difficulties with people who are on the pay-as-you-earn taxation system by which dollars are taken from their pockets before they actually receive them. Of course, that finds its way into the hands of the Government. With an alternative system where a tax is imposed upon consumption and goods purchased, individuals with adequate cash in their hands coming from higher net income have a potential to decide upon the categories of goods which they would like to buy. In that way they make individual decisions about the goods that they buy. Consequently, this leads to a freedom of treatment of their own incomes rather than what occurs when we leave those kinds of decisions in the hands of the Government.

This underlying proposition is the fundamental one in terms of the Government's decision in the Budget of 1981 to extend sales tax to a broader range of goods than had previously applied. Clearly, it was the Government's intention to increase the tax base to ensure a greater flow of revenue not necessarily in the first year but certainly in the future when one could consider changes in the tax mix generally in such a way as to look forward to reductions in income tax. We face a situation-it has been debated in this place and in the House of Representatives for the last three or four months-in which the passage of these Bills is being obstructed by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. Many justifications for this obstruction-most of them spurious-have been put up by the Opposition and particularly by the Democrats. I shall come to those matters in a few moments but I think it is worth first noting Senator Chipp's statement last week making it clear that the Democrats in this place would be opposing passage of this legislation. He said:
I say frankly that our--
I take it that he meant the Democrats as a whole-
undertaking to ultimately allow these Bills to pass was-in the light of subsequent events-an error of judgment.

I can only agree with Senator Chipp and his four colleagues that they have made two very fundamental errors of judgment-firstly, of course, in putting forward their spurious economic arguments and, secondly, in their intention to pick up the most cynical political act that could possibly have been perpetrated in this place. Let us examine first of all some of the so-called effects of the imposition of sales tax which I take it the Democrats and the Opposition claim are at the base of their decision. Let us consider the so-called effect upon inflation. Quite a deal has been made out of a study conducted by one Mr Warren in connection with the effects of indirect taxes upon the rate of inflation and in connection with the regressive aspects of this form of taxation. Mr Warren carefully qualified many of the implications that were stipulated in his report but, true to form, the Opposition has ignored those qualifications. The fact is that the effect on the consumer price index of additional sales tax is a one-off effect and need not be built into the future structure of wage developments and the rate at which inflation grows.

Let us consider the situation which has existed over the last few years. We have seen indirect taxation rises in some years of as much as 10 per cent; yet in the last few years we have seen the rate of inflation actually decline. This year we see that the increase in indirect taxation across the board-that is, in all categories-and including the estimates of taxation to be received from this form of sales tax, is of the order of 3.7 per cent. So the claim that this form of tax would be inflationary flies in the face of the evidence that increases in indirect taxes in previous years were accompanied by a rate of inflation which showed a decline. Can the Opposition or the Democrats prove substantially that this form of tax leads automatically to an increase in inflation? Clearly, they have not presented any evidence to that effect.

I refer also to the fact that quite often members of trade unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions claim that direct taxation is a direct cause for people to seek higher wage settlement than they would otherwise seek. Does that mean that direct taxation in that sense is not inflationary? Obviously, if it is going to push up the costs of labour for manufacturers and employers in the country, that direct tax element must amount to some inflation. Does that mean that in any real sense there is a difference between direct taxes and indirect taxes in their inflationary effect? I can only point out that the evidence is that the additional indirect taxes which have been imposed have not substantially increased the rate of inflation in the last few years although, clearly, substantial problems have arisen as a result of increased wage pressures in the community, which pressures constitute one of the areas of greatest concern at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about tax avoidance? You are not mentioning that.

—I am glad that Senator Childs mentioned tax avoidance. Of course it is an area of very great concern to this Government. As the Senate would know, we have done a great deal to try to restrict the growth of tax avoidance practices. Indeed, I think it is clear on the evidence that these activities have had a substantial effect. During the period of government of Senator Child's party one of the most infamous taxation rip-offs of all time- namely, the Curran scheme-got its birth. A Labor Treasurer undertook to do something about it but failed to do anything at all about it during the period of his Government. Senator Childs would know that it was the present Government that took action about that scheme in 1978.
—You had been in office for how many years in 1978? When did the scheme come to notice? It was in 1974, wasn't it?

—I think it was of the order of 18 months. A point that Senator Childs has overlooked is that tax avoidance can in some ways be better controlled by imposing taxes on consumption and through the forms of indirect taxes that we have at hand. That is because people will find it more difficult to avoid payments of taxation when consumption is taxed. That is not necessarily a categorical statement; I believe that there are still ways in which one can avoid paying tax. It has been proven in the United Kingdom with the value added tax system that people can still substantially avoid taxation. Nevertheless these forms of taxation reduce the opportunities for tax avoidance and, I believe, help substantially in reducing tax evasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the claimed regressive effects of sales tax as laid down in this legislation. I believe that the Opposition and the Democrats on many occasions have sought to make something of the fact that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is it in order for the Minister to speak on a matter relevant to the subject matter of the Bill in a first reading debate?
—It is unusual but it is not out of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am very thankful for your indulgence on this matter. I know that it is unusual but it is something that I have the opportunity to do for the first time. I wish to make a few points about the arguments which have been raised in connection with the so- called regressive effects of this form of taxation. Clearly, the rate of tax which is sought to be applied to some new ranges of goods, particularly to clothing, is a very small rate; that is, 2.5 per cent. Clearly, that is not a very high rate. In fact, by international standards, on some of the items it is very low. From my understanding, the value added tax in the United Kingdom is imposed at the rate of 15 per cent on the same classes of goods. Indeed, in France the tax applied to clothing and goods of that kind is of the order of 7 1 /2 per cent. So on an international comparison Australia is fairly cheaply rated .

SPEECH.PARA: On other classes of goods of a slightly more luxurious nature-if I may use that term-tax is to be applied at the rate of 17 1/2 per cent. They would include motor vehicles, computers and office furniture. A third scale of rates is to be applied to areas where there is perhaps the highest degree of luxury. That rate is to be 30 per cent and will apply to cameras, watches, television sets and record playing equipment. Surely people could not say that those items were necessities of life. Yet we find that the Opposition and the Democrats are opposing this legislation across the board on the basis of those items being basic necessities of life. I am sure that I could argue quite successfully in this forum or any other that hi-fi equipment, jewellery or television sets do not come into the category of basic necessities of life, as is claimed by the Opposition and the Democrats. I guess that that is just one of the major inconsistencies displayed by speakers from the Opposition side of the chamber.

I point out that more significantly, because of the rating structure, because the rates range from 5 per cent on such things as clothing up to 30 per cent on items which might be called non-essential, there is a progressive impact on the taxpayer in a way which I am sure the Opposition would agree with were it thinking straight on this issue. A flat rate of tax is not being applied to all goods; a progressive rate is being applied. So, it can be firmly argued that those who can afford to pay the most do pay the most and those who can afford to pay the least are not forced to pay the most. That very significant point appears to be overlooked in the arguments that have been discussed in this place and in the media generally. One does not have to take my argument on this. Several studies have been conducted on this matter. Recently an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development study indicated that general consumption taxes in the countries of the OECD are not regressive because the same kinds of luxury goods are taxed at higher rates. Of course, this impacts most on those in the highest income categories. In some countries, as in Australia, food-that basic essential of life-is not taxed at all. So, for us to make out arguments on that spurious point is merely to hoodwink the Australian people as to the actual effects of the proposed legislation. It seems as though the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are determined to confuse the public on these issues and not give them an opportunity to think through all the issues themselves in such a way as to understand clearly what the Government is on about with this form of legislation.

Honourable senators should also consider some of the other effects of not undertaking the kind of decision which this legislation contemplates. Very largely, the Government is seeking, through this legislation, to meet its Budget deficit, which is an item for which the Opposition and the Democrats seem to have very little regard. They have little regard for the argument that the greater the deficit the more likely an upward impact on interest rates and a higher rate of inflation. Those two matters are inextricably interlocked. If this legislation is not passed we will suffer a further blow-out in the deficit which will have to be financed from the general community by people who lend their savings to building societies, to finance companies or to banks. The community can use those funds for the purchase of goods and houses. If the funds are not used for that purpose, they will be used by this Government to finance its day-to-day operations. This will mean that the Government will need to go into the money markets and compete against the financial institutions in this country to gain funds to meet its own deficit. That would have an obvious upward impact on interest rates.

So, if this taxation measure is not implemented it follows that not only is it likely to lead to greater rates of inflation but clearly it will also lead to higher interest rates through the impact in the money markets. From that point of view the Government has a very clear obligation-if it has an interest in keeping interest rates low in this community-to go ahead with the kind of Budget that was set out in August; that is, we should go for a Budget surplus in the domestic area to ensure that we have as neutral an effect as possible upon interest rates. We must ensure that we succeed in keeping interest rates at a low level throughout the next year or so. One would think that the Opposition and the Democrats were intent upon seeing higher interest rates in this community and clearly frustrating the Government's program in order to see that come about. One does not need too much imagination to realise what a cynical act that would be and the hardship it would create for individuals in this community .

I turn now to a few other issues which have surrounded this issue in the last three or four months. We have to consider some of the statements made earlier by individuals in this place and in other places about the nature of the political consequences of the sorts of decisions that they now appear to be about to force upon the Senate. We know the fundamental constitutional issues that are involved . Quite clearly Senator Evans, who is in the chamber at the moment, can speak on this matter with far greater understanding and knowledge than I can. I can only repeat what he says. Clearly in the past he has been one of those who have said that this Senate has no right to restrict the passage of money Bills in this place. One can understand that kind of statement coming from a man of such integrity as Senator Evans and no doubt it is something that he would or should stand by. In fact, we find that he is changing his mind about this matter. I quote from a speech that he made to the National Conference of Labor Lawyers on 3 July last year. He said:

. . . the fact that constitutional and democratic principles were torn up in 1975 is no excuse for anyone doing it again. While there is a great deal to be said, tactically, for never ruling out completely any option, I believe that our credibility-
Meaning his-
and self-respect as a movement depends on us-
that is, Senator Evans and the Labor Party-
being more principled than our opponents, and that we would sadly demean both ourselves and our cause were we ever to descend to the Tories' level.

Those are fine words, Senator Evans, but where is the meaning of them today? We know that he is committed by his party to vote against this legislation. We should not criticise him too much for that act because it is a direct result of the imposition of a Caucus decision to which all Labor members need to subscribe , or immediately resign from their party. Individuals, whatever their personal views and integrity, are bound by that decision of the Labor Caucus. Whether it is made in this House or the other House does not matter in terms of their personal judgment and integrity. They are forced by that decision to maintain and uphold that principle. Notwithstanding that Senator Evans, through some form of sophistry, might be able to justify his own stance, I would like him to justify that of his party on this issue and to demonstrate to us on this side of the chamber how he might justify his recent decision to oppose his most deeply- held views upon this very important and constitutional issue. It is important to note that Senator Evans has spoken on this issue in many forums in the past; in fact he probably made his name throughout Australia with regard to this issue following the great events of 1975. However, he now sees himself in a situation in which he is bound to support the Labor Caucus, no matter what his individual views are. I hope that when this vote finally occurs, later this evening or tomorrow, we will see Senator Evans on this side of the Senate defending the principles which he holds so deeply and with such great integrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you got any taste at all?

—I guess we could find a place for Senator Evans somewhere over here. I turn now to some of those wonderfully chiselled-in-stone remarks in relation to this matter that came from the Democrats some six or eight months ago at the time of the presentation of the Budget. Let us recall, for instance, the sorts of remarks that were made by Senator Macklin in a famous article that he wrote for the Courier-Mail in Brisbane on 2 September 1981. In part he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The widespread criticism with which the sales tax gifts were greeted put us in a postion to gain much electoral popularity by heading them off . . .

Irrespective of the potential electoral backlash to the Democrats, we will not follow the Liberal and Labor parties in breaking election pledges. We could hardly claim to keep either of the old parties honest unless we are honest ourselves.

Since then we have seen Senator Macklin, along with his four colleagues, change his mind dramatically on this issue. They say that they will not support their former stand. The question of honesty does not appear to come into this matter any more. It did at the time of the presentation of the Budget, but it no longer does. Now the Democrats are out for electoral gain. They said they were prepared , for the sake of honesty, to suffer electoral unpopularity on this matter. We now find that they are not prepared to do so any longer-in fact, they will prove that they are dishonest. These sorts of remarks have been sprinkled through the pages of Hansard in recent times. Further statements were made by the then Acting Leader of the Democrats, Senator Mason, on 26 August 1981, when referring to the course of opposing this kind of legislation. At page 360 of Hansard he said:
That course would mean that every future government would face the risk of having at least part of its financial program destroyed.
The sales tax legislation is a very large part of this Government's financial program for the reasons that I outlined earlier. Senator Mason continued:
It is a fact that governments have a mandate for their financial program.

He in no way made any specific qualification to that statement by saying that this Government has no mandate at all for its financial program. On that very fundamental point we find it very difficult to understand why Senator Mason now has an alternative point of view. Later in the same speech-it is recorded on page 361 of Hansard-Senator Mason said:

Listen to this, senators, it is my bottom line. Those on the Labor side in particular should listen to this. Undesirable though the sales tax increases are , damaging though their impact might be, the consequences of the Senate meddling in or unilaterally rewriting a Budget seems to us too horrifying to contemplate.
Clearly, Senator Mason now finds adequate reason to deny that point of view which was expressed with such vehemence and sincerity at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was impeccable logic, wasn't it?

—It is an interesting form of logic when one can turn it on its head so quickly. Consequently, I find that statement, in conjunction with several statements that have emanated from the other side, very confusing. I believe that the electors of this country find it extremely difficult to understand the reasoning behind the Democrats' proposals. One can only assume that there is a particular reason. I guess that Senator Macklin has found it because, as I said earlier, in his letter to the Courier-Mail he managed to say that, irrespective of the potential electoral backlash, he would not follow the Liberal and Labor parties in breaking election pledges. I remind the Senate that the Democrats' statements were supported by statutory declarations which we understand were sworn by each Democrat senator at the time of the election in 1980. We believe that they must have solemnly and sincerely held the views that they put down at that stage. However, they now find that electoral considerations are of greater concern to them than the fundamental issues which they said they were espousing.

SPEECH.PARA: I again draw the Senate's attention to the later statement made by Senator Chipp last week, when he claimed that his party had made an error of judgment in relation to these Bills. I believe it is patently clear for other reasons that they have misjudged the economic impacts of the Bills. They have misjudged the actual impacts of taxation on the community. They have not bothered to seek the truth. They have taken the easy line of supporting the so-called political concerns on these Bills which have been built up by pressure groups and other groups within the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, you wouldn't do that.
—We are elected to this place to consider the facts and make decisions accordingly.
—You haven't kept any of the promises you have made. What are you talking about?

—I have indeed. The honourable senator is having a counselling centre in Darwin. On the PM radio program on 19 August 1981, Senator Chipp suggested that if it were at all possible for the Senate to amend the sales tax Bills in such a way that the total amount going to Consolidated Revenue would not be diminished but so that in levying the taxes those at the lower end would pay less and those at the higher end would pay more the Democrats would certainly consider such an option. The point I want to make is quite clear. If there was ever any error of judgment on the part of Senator Chipp and his Democrat friends, it was in that area. As I have pointed out previously, the system which is to be implemented as a result of the passage of this legislation is not regressive in its effects upon the taxpayer. It is substantially progressive. It imposes only the smallest rates of tax on those goods which will be consumed by those at the lower end of the income scales. It imposes the highest rates of tax on those classes of goods which will be used and consumed by those in the upper reaches of the income scales. In other words, substantially this legislation does the things to which Senator Chipp made specific reference on 19 August 1981. Yet he sees reason now to refuse to accept that line and to deny that that is the impact of the Bills. His attitude is not only an error of judgment upon the way in which the community might react to this legislation but also it is an error of judgment upon the facts. It is for that reason that he stands most condemned in this place. He is not prepared to consider the proper impacts of these decisions and the way in which they impact upon the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, if Senator Chipp wants to change his mind he has a perfect out. As I have argued, the system is not regressive; it is progressive. Senator Chipp said on 19 August that if it could be demonstrated that that would be the effect of the system he would support it. I invite him to support it on those grounds and consequently to vote with the Government in support of the legislation later. The fundamental errors of judgment which Senator Chipp has made will come home to roost in one form or another in future. It is those things by which he will be judged in terms of the proper performance of his party in this chamber. It will be regretted if the Democrats and Senator Chipp remain in their present frame of mind. We hope that, given their predeliction for changing their minds, they will see reason to do so along the lines that I have outlined. Other errors of judgment may have been made by Senator Chipp and the Democrats which they have not spelled out very clearly. One can only attribute the most base electoral hypocrisy to the decision not to support this legislation which they announced in public last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, and wish to make a personal explanation. Although, of course, there is a threshold question as to whether anything that Senator Messner might say would be taken seriously enough by anybody to justify a response being given, I do find offensive the repetition by him today of the canard that I, somehow, in my support for the Australian Labor Party's opposition to these sales tax Bills have been caught in an inconsistency of a fairly spectacular kind between my principled pronouncements in 1975 and much more recently. I point out to the Senate that, clearly, Senator Messner must be a man of either limited memory or even smaller attention span-or both- because there have been at least three occasions on which I have risen in my place in this Senate to answer canards of just that kind. One such occasion was on 9 September. I happen to have that speech in front of me here. The point in question-
—I just happen to have my speeches in front of me, too.

—Mine are worth preserving. I do, in fact, keep them in a drawer here for occasions such as this. I can well understand Senator Walters having some diffidence about ever having occasion to refer to her contributions on future occasions. The point that is being made, of course, is that the relevant distinction is not between money Bills on the one hand and non-money Bills on the other hand or between Budget and non-Budget Bills. The relevant, principal distinction which sustained the Labor Party in 1975 and has sustained it subsequently is between those Bills which are crucial to the survival of a government, its continuance in office, and those which are not. It is exactly that distinction which I have espoused. I suggest to the chamber that that does not savour of sophistry in any way at all. I appreciate that it is a distinction which is not capable of being well understood by a number of honourable members of this House, including Senator Messner. I also appreciate-I finish on this point-that it is a distinction which may not be capable of being appreciated by my colleagues, the Australian Democrats, who have been writhing in what they perceive to be a dilemma between constitutional purity on the one hand and crude opportunistic expediency on the other hand. That is not a dilemma which we in the Labor Party feel. We believe that it is possible to maintain constitutional purity of a very high order indeed by drawing the distinction which I have just made and which we have made throughout our contributions to this debate. I have made this distinction on all the occasions in the past. Accordingly, I hope that Senator Messner will be gentleman enough to acknowledge the point and not to repeat it tiresomely in the future. Those remarks apply also to his fellows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise to members of the Senate that I will take this opportunity on the first reading of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills not to speak on the subject matter of the Bills, unlike the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner. I take this opportunity to make some comments on the situation in the Middle East at the moment. I have just returned from a visit to the Middle East. I went firstly as part of a parliamentary delegation and, secondly, as part of an Australian Labor Party delegation-with two of my colleagues from the House of Representatives, Mr Beazley and Mr Holding. We are the Labor Party's members of the Middle East Sub- committee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. We visited nine countries in the Middle East: Iraq, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Syria, Jordan, Israel and Egypt. It was a unique opportunity to see, at first hand, the situation in the area and to talk to officials, ministers, rulers, members of the royal families, military officials and Australian foreign affairs officials serving in the region.

SPEECH.PARA: I make this speech at this time because I think the situation in the Middle East is particularly fluid at the moment. One has only to look at the newspaper reports of the weekend. One article that comes to mind stated that the Middle East lives up to its reputation for intrigue. 'Arafat and one damaged Boeing' was the heading of one article. Another article was headed 'Huge Car Bomb used in Syrian suicide attack'. I think these are examples of some of the things that are happening in the Middle East at the moment. At this stage I do not want to talk about the report of the parliamentary delegation or any recommendations that we might make in that report. I am not trying to pre-empt that debate.

I place on record the two main impressions that I received in the region. The first was an optimistic impression that in the long term prospects for peace between Israel and the Arabs are good. But I want to stress that they are good in the long term. I do not consider that there will not be difficulties in the short term. Personally, I fully support the peace settlement that came about between Egypt and Israel. I think it has been good for both countries. I think one has to be very realistic and realise that Egypt, under the new president, President Mubarak, will return to the Arab camp. I think Egypt will return to its historical position within the non-aligned movement. Only a few years ago it was threatened with expulsion from that movement. In fact, it is one of the founding members of the non-aligned movement. I think there is sufficient evidence at the moment to suggest that it is returning to its historical position.

I firmly believe that Egypt, under the new president, will keep the peace and that the normalisation of relations with Israel will continue. I think the importance of this is that Egypt is really the centre of the Arab world. Its population of 42 million people cannot be ignored. One example of this is that the Arab countries need Egyptian workers. Three million Egyptians work outside Egypt in the Arab world at the moment. There are Egyptian doctors, teachers, technicians and, very importantly, labourers in large numbers throughout the Arab world. the very fact that Egypt, central to the Arab world, has been able to reach a peace agreement with Israel, I believe, has changed the Middle East picture permanently. The very fact that the Fahd plan is being discussed by the Arab states, even if a number of them reject it, means the issues involved in a Middle East peace plan will continue to be debated; the plan will continue to be on the agenda when the Arab nations meet.

My second impression was one of pessimism. Now, more than ever, I am convinced that the Labor Party's stand on the Sinai is correct. I say that because I am very pessimistic about the continuing war that is going on between Iraq and Iran . It is the forgotten war; it is the war that is being allowed to continue; it is the war that no one can seem to stop. One Western view that has a lot of currency is that it is good for the United States, it is good for Israel and it is good for the West for this war to continue. I believe that this war contains a conflict that could engulf the Middle East and eventually pose a greater threat to world peace than the Arab-Israeli conflict. I see this conflict as a battle between the Islamic fundamentalists, whom I call 'the mediaevals', and the twentieth century Arabs. It is a war that is already spilling over the borders of Iraq and Iran. It is already ignoring the traditional left or right wing labels on the regimes in the area. It is ignoring previous loyalties to either Eastern or the Western blocs. It is slowly involving the super-powers in a conflict between the countries that have the second and third largest oil reserves in the world. I believe that should be a worry to all of us.

I want to deal, very briefly, with the two sides of the conflict. Iraq has a reputation of being a radical Arab regime. Most of its military equipment has come from the Soviet Union. In particular, its strong air force has been entirely purchased from the Soviet Union. But it is a twentieth century country. For that reason alone I support it in the present conflict. It has been looking increasingly to the West as it has attempted to modernise and, especially, as it has attemped to buy new technology. It is following the Yugoslav line in the non -aligned movement. It is opposing the view that there are natural allies of the Soviet Union in the non-aligned movement. It is important in this context because the next non-aligned movement meeting will be held later this year in Baghdad, the capital of Iraq. Iraq is being supported in the war by a number of countries. It is being supported financially, mainly by Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states. They, of course, have the reputation of being conservative regimes. I say that it is being supported financially because we heard in the Middle East that Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states have poured $US30 billion into Iraq to support it and to maintain its standard of living and to make sure that Iraq maintains its present military superiority over Iran.

Iraq is being supported morally by Oman, a pro-United States regime in the Arab world. It is being supported by Jordan. King Hussein of Jordan recently asked for the formation of a volunteer brigade which he is going to send to fight with Iraq in its war against Iran. It is interesting to notice that Jordan has been accused of funnelling United States weapons to Iraq at the same time as Jordan is attempting to buy a sophisticated United States missile system and F16 aircraft from the United States. Even Egypt says that it sides with Iraq in the war; if Iraq's borders are threatened it will sell arms to that country. It has been reported that the Soviet Union, which has mainly supplied Iraq in the past, is turning off the tap on replacement of military equipment. That is certainly the impression that we got when we visited Iraq.

I think we have to ask ourselves: Why are these countries worried and why are these countries in particular supporting Iraq? Why, for instance, is the Gulf Co -operative Council-a body I am sure we will hear a lot more of in the future- holding joint defence Ministers meetings at present? Why has Saudi Arabia agreed to build an oil pipeline across Saudi Arabia from Iraq to Yanbu to guarantee that Iraq will be able to sell its oil? The Saudi Arabians say they are supporting their Arab brothers in an historic battle against the Persians as they have done over the centuries. I think their real concern is something different. They believe the Iranian leaders are becoming the terrorists of the Gulf. They believe that the Iranian leadership at the moment is exporting its fundamentalist revolution to the Shi'ite minority populations right throughout the Arab world.

I think if any of us want to see an example of that we have to look only at Bahrain where recently it was proved that the attempted coup was Iranian sponsored and that the people concerned had got their weapons and training in Iran. Even on the West Bank we have a situation where some Palestinian students are following the fundamentalist line. No country at the moment is more worried than Saudi Arabia. I will return to that in a few minutes. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an article from the Jerusalem Post of 2 February entitled 'Khomeini delivers the goods' which adds to the argument I have used. I also have a number of other articles which I will seek leave to incorporate later. They are straight newspaper articles from a number of newspapers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—I assume that what is referred to is the text of the articles?
—That is right.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no objection to the text of the articles being incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
KHOMEINI DELIVERS THE GOODS
Internal chaos has only served to heighten religious fervour in Iran and enhance the position of its ruler, writes MORT ROSENBLUM.
HAVING SEIZED the advantage against Iraqi invaders and anti-government guerrillas, Iran is now threatening Gulf oil states with new revolutionary fervour, according to Western analysts.

''The Ayatollah hasn't collapsed as we expected . . . He has got it together, and his appeal to Shia nationalism is making an impact,'' a ranking U.S. official said privately in Washington. ''We're worried about it.''
Others in Washington and Paris, including informed Iranians, reflected the same view.

Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has urged repeatedly that Shi'ite Moslems revolt in states governed by Sunnis, followers of the other major branch of Islam. In the past, problems at home limited active subversion.
Iran's economy is in a shambles, with serious food shortages, crippled production and chaotic services. But, the analysts say, adversity has actually served to heighten religious zeal.
''Khomeini never talked about giving anyone prosperity,'' observed Amir Taheri, a leading Iranian journalist, now living in Paris. ''He promised martyrdom, and he is delivering the goods.''

U.S. intelligence sources say Iran is smuggling arms and funds into several Gulf states, sometimes in diplomatic pouches. The sources linked Iran to a December coup attempt in Bahrain, where Sunnis rule over a large Shi'ite population. They also claim Iran is backing dissidents in Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Oman and Qatar.
SAUDI ARABIA, a fundamentalist state with a strong Sunni leadership, is less vulnerable, the analysts say. But Saudi authorities are clearly concerned.

Saudi Interior Minister Prince Nayef Ibn Abdel-Aziz charged last month: '' Iranian leaders have become the terrorists of the Gulf.'' He accused them of training, arming and funding dissidents throughout the region.

Iranian authorities have meanwhile conferred the status of ''Great Satan'' on Saudi Arabia, and some have demanded that the Saudis turn over the holy Islamic cities of Mecca and Medina to international control.

Saudi officials say Iranian pilgrims have beaten policemen who tried to stop them from ''gibbering loudly'' and spreading political propaganda in holy shrines. Iranians charge the Saudis with harassing Shi'ite worshippers.
Iran has denied any connection with the Bahrein coup attempt. But, according to Teheran newspapers, Khomeini has earmarked $18 million this year for official efforts to export the revolution.
The Islamic Students Organization, with branches in a number of countries, recruits militants to spread the revolutionary word.

Powerful radio transmitters in Iran offer a more direct appeal. They broadcast religious messages and news of the revolution throughout the region. One recently urged the Gulf states to impose an oil boycott on the U.S. and Western Europe because of their support for Israel.
Last week, parliament Speaker Ali Akbar Rafsanjani said Saudi Arabia ''is the only obstacle in the way of the Moslem movement.''

The Iranian Government also underwrites Martyr, an Arabic-Language weekly which claims a circulation of 150,000. The latest issue carried the constitution of the Bahrain Liberation Front, a manual for making Molotov cocktails and three addresses in Iran to write to for help in designing a made-to-measure revolution .
IRAQ which invaded Iran 16 months ago to gain control over its only access to the Gulf-the Shatt-Al-Arab-is a diminishing counterbalance to Iran, the analysts say.

Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other Gulf states have loaned Iraq an estimated $20 billion to pay for the war, effectively shifting local power balances. Two years ago, Iraq, wealthy and strong, was considered a potential threat.
Few outsiders can approach the front, but reliable accounts agree that Iran seized the advantage late last year after months of desultory exchanges, and is now pressing for victory.

Latest reports say revolutionary guards and army troops have pushed Iraqi forces back along a 563 km front that now ranges from 3 to 19 km from their common border. They are reported to hold a salient 13 km into Iraq, west of Qasr -e Shirin, within reach of a military centre. Iraqi defenders are well- entrenched, but Iranians are posed above the Mesopotamian plain, within 160 km of the Baghdad area.
No accurate casualty count is available, but tens of thousands have died, according to most reports.

Glorifying martyrdom, the Iranians have reportedly been more willing to suffer casualties than the Iraqis. Iranian soldiers, according to eye-witness accounts have been shot while walking unconcerned towards Iraqi gun barrels, protected by bits of paper from Mullahs assuring them of invincibility.
Also, the war has proved to be more costly for Iraq than Iran because of internal politics.

Iraqi president Saddam Hussein is a Sunni, but at least half of Iraq is Shi'ite . Iraqi Shi'ites rallied as Arabs against Iranians, but the government supports elaborate social programmes and pays large casualty indemnities to bolster loyalty and morale.
KHOMEINI uses the war as justification for economic privation, and his government gives low priority to traditional development.
The war is also used as a pretext for severe repression against opponents, mainly the Mujahedden Khalq, directed from Paris, which seeks to trigger revolt against the Mullahs.
Since June, guerrillas have killed at least 1,100 religious leaders, including the powerful Ayatollah Mohammed Behesti, in bombings and bursts of gunfire.

Authorities say they have executed more than 1,600 suspected guerrillas; opponents put the figure above 4,000. Attacks are now less frequent and less severe. Few Iranians have shown themselves ready for another revolution.
Successes against the Iraqis and Mujahedden Khalq have increased the external appeal of Khomeini's Islamic republic.
''Other Shi'ites, used to centuries as underdogs, look at Iran and ask themselves why they can't do the same thing,'' observed one U.S. specialist.
The successes apparently have also encouraged Iran to reject peace initiatives, and few analysts see a quick end to the war, short of Iraq's surrender or Khomeini's downfall.
The writer is a special correspondent of the Associated Press

TALK.START.PARA: —In a military sense Iraq has been successful up to date. But it is now in a situation where it is bogged down on a front over 500 kilometres long. Iraq has suffered casualties estimated at 15,000 killed and 15,000 captured. The Iraqis themselves are capturing increasing amounts of Soviet and Israeli weaponry besides the United States weaponry that Iran had at the time of the Shah. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an article concerning military equipment that is finding its way from other countries into Iran.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
KIMCHE: STRONG IRAN ARMY IS GOOD FOR ISRAEL

Foreign Ministry Director-General David Kimche said last night that Israel's interests are served by ensuring that the Iranian army is strong, and if possible, strong enough to take control of the country.
Kimche was speaking on the BBC television programme Panorama, Israel TV's correspondent in Britain reported.

Appearing with Kimche was Aluf-Mishne (res.) Nimrodi, who identified himself as the Israel Defence Forces' representative in Iran during the reign of the late shah. Nimrodi said that it is still possible to attempt a military coup in Iran, and that the chance should not be missed, lest the Communists take over the country.
The programme's commentators claimed that Defence Minister Ariel Sharon had tried to convince the U.S. to support Israel's plan during his recent visit to Washington, but had not succeeded.
The programme said that Israel is supplying Iran with recoilless artillery, ammunition and spare parts for planes and tanks through a company called Elul, under the ownership of David Colitz.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. At the moment the Iranian Air Force appears to be grounded. That has lead to some speculation that in fact its sophisticated military equipment cannot be maintained. Some of us had the opportunity of going out into the Strait of Hormuz on an Omani Navy patrol and we were told that the Iranians, only a couple of nights previously, had been able to put a destroyer and a frigate to sea. That indicates that this sophisticated equipment-at least in the navy-is capable of being used and sustaining a military conflict. I believe that at the moment Iraq is looking to settle the war. I believe it is trying to settle the war on an honourable basis. But it does suit Khomeini and others for the war to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now turn to Iran. The casualties of the Iranians are horrendous. The estimate is that 90,000 to 100,000 people have been killed or captured in this conflict. Admittedly Iran has a larger population than Iraq. There are disturbing reports of Khomeini's revolutionary guards armed with just a piece of paper given to them by the Mullahs, apparently to ward off bullets, being pushed into the front line against the Iraqis and then being followed up by Iranian tanks. As a matter of fact officials in Jordan called this particular piece of paper issued by the Mullahs the Iranians' transit visa to heaven. Any war in which there are 90,000 to 100,000 casualties on one side is, I believe, a war that has to be stopped. The Iranians still have sophisticated United States equipment-as I said-from the time of the Shah. They are getting increasing amounts of Soviet equipment. Any visitor to Baghdad can see examples of captured equipment. It was reported to our delegation that the Soviet Union at present has between 2,000 and 4,000 military advisers in Iran. Also there are reports that the Soviet Union is pressing Iran to sign a friendship and mutual assistance treaty. I have another newspaper article to back up that assertion. I seek leave to have that article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
'Reds pressing Iran to sign treaty'
NEW YORK, Mon. (AFP)

THE Soviet Union is pressing Iran to sign a ''friendship and mutual assistance treaty'' for a period of five to 10 years to defend Iran against ''foreign-led subversion'', Time magazine claimed today.
The proposal was put to the Iranians on November 18 at a meeting between the Soviet ambassador and Iranian Prime Minister Mir Hossein Moussavi, Time said.

Ambassador Vinogradov is believed to have put forward his government's view that the growing opposition to Ayatullah Khomeini and the ''CIA backed Leftists' ' in the Mujahedeen Khalq resistance movement created a risk of civil war and counter revolution backed by the U.S.

Time said the ambassador had offered stepped up Soviet protection probably in the form of arms and technical advisers. Soviet advisers had earlier been sent to strengthen the Iranian secret services and help reconstruct the country's economy.
Following the meeting, Time said, the envoy informed the Soviet side that its offer was ''under consideration.''

Meanwhile in Iran, the speaker of the country's parliament today condemned the assassination attempt on the brother of President Ali Khamnei in Tehran, calling it an ''empty act without a goal'', Tehran radio reported.

The radio, broadcasting a tape of Ali-Akbar Rafsanjani's speech delivered in parliament today quoted him as saying ''not even the Mafia has stooped so low to remove characters who are loved and respected by the people.''

Muhammed Khamenei, a parliament deputy from the north-eastern city of Mashhad and the head of parliament's judicial subcommittee, was injured in an attack on yesterday in which two of his guards were killed.
Officials have blamed the Mujahdeen for the assassination of more than 1,000 prominent politicians and clergymen.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the position of the Tudeh party within Iran is being strengthened because there is no real alternative for large sections of the Iranian population. A particular scenario that worries the majority of the Arab states is that following the death or overthrow of Khomeini there is the possibility of a pro-Moscow regime being installed in Tehran at the same time as they see a weakened Iraq or more radical regime taking over in Baghdad. It was continually stressed to us that the United States ought to examine more closely this scenario. Of course, it is only one of a number of scenarios that might happen when Khomeini goes but it is one raised constantly by the Gulf states. Strangely enough Iran is being supported in this war by Syria. When talking to us Baath party officials made no secret of the fact that they also aimed to bring down the current regime in Iraq. One has to question the very stability of the regime in Syria itself. The British Broadcasting Corporation reported an attempted coup in which the Air Force was going to bomb key installations in the city and two divisions of the Syrian Army-one from Aleppo and one from Lebanon-were going to rebel, bisect the city and remove Assad's regime. The Muslim Brotherhood, a banned organisation in Syria, is at this moment, with certain rebels in the Army, fighting the Syrian Army at Hamah and Aleppo. The Army is run and controlled by an Alawite minority which is being increasingly isolated in Syria. As I said the very stability of that regime has to be seriously looked at.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have also to look at the stability of the regime in Saudi Arabia. Since the incident at the Mosque a number of people around the world have speculated as to how long the Saudi Arabian regime can last. I believe that the incident at the Mosque if not started by the Iranians was certainly under Iranian influence. Recently in newspapers in Iran, Saudi Arabia was referred to as 'Great Satan'. They are asking that the cities of Mecca and Medina be taken over by international commissions and taken out of the hands of the Saudi Arabians. I think we have to look at the situation in Saudi Arabia in the context that at the moment the Saudi Arabians are producing nine million to 10 million barrels of oil a day which is certainly helping to produce the oil glut and bring about a situation favourable to the West at the moment. The Saudi Arabians really need to produce only five million or six million barrels of oil a day. I think it is horrendous to contemplate what would happen if the regime in Saudi Arabia were to collapse suddenly. I do not think that that is about to happen despite the medieval attitudes on a lot of issues. I do not think the Saudi Arabians will make the same mistakes as the Shah of Iran. I do not think they are trying to modernise too quickly. I think the regime will last a lot longer than some people think. In the longer term everybody should question the stability of the regime and ask how long it can last. These are some aspects of the scenario in the Middle East at present.
