I believe that in the light of these scenarios we should examine Australia's involvement in the region and pose some questions that were put to members of the delegation. For example, will Israel return the Sinai by 26 April?

Will Israel invade Palestine Liberation Organisation strongholds in southern Lebanon before 26 April and therefore weaken Egypt's position in the Arab world? I have shown the Minister an article which backs up that statement. I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Muffling the war drums

The abortive incursion by five Fatah terrorists near Mehola in the Jordan Valley last Saturday drew a furious, indeed a threatening, reaction from the Israeli side which struck many people as rather out of proportion.

Saturday night a press conference was hastily held on orders from Defence Minister Ariel Sharon, at which Chief-of-Staff Rafael Eitan went through the motions of playing up the incident as though it had been a major military confrontation. Sunday night Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir followed suit on television, wagging his finger at Jordan for its failure to seal off the Jordan River and, more important, charging a gross violation of the cease-fire concluded with the PLO-although ostensibly with Lebanon-last July.
Israel, Mr Shamir sternly warned, would take measures in the wake of this violation of the cease-fire agreement.

This latter argument was, however, immediately interpreted, both here and abroad, as an attempt to capitalise on the Mehola incident to justify a retaliatory attack on the terrorists in southern Lebanon. It was a questionable argument, for all the evidence tended to show that the cease-fire had been strictly limited to the Lebanese frontier. If Israel needed political cover for taking forceful military action to shatter the PLO's mounting concentration of arms across the border, it would have to find something better.
As the matter stood, the chances were that in such places as Washington the blame would be put squarely on Israel itself for the outbreak of any fresh hostilities.

But the prospect of a resumed war in the north did not cause jitters in the U.S . alone, but also among Israelis along the Lebanese frontier, who recalled their nights and days in stuffy air-raid shelters last summer. A local government leader in Upper Galilee yesterday urged the authorities to do everything within their power to maintain the calm that had prevailed in the area for the past six months.

Themselves finally somewhat alarmed by the sound of their war drums, the authorities started to beat a tactical retreat. 'Sources' within the government were now quoted as saying that last Saturday's incident near Mehola was not a sufficient reason for a major anti-terrorist offensive by Israel.
Someone had apparently lost and then recovered his good senses. But what about the next time?

TALK.START.PARA: —Other questions which were posed to us are: Will Israel annex a portion or the whole of the West Bank? How concerned is Israel that after 26 April United States foreign policy will be more pro-Saudi Arabian? Will the United States, under the constant pressure of the Arab world, begin a dialogue with the PLO? I think we ought very seriously to look at Australian involvement in the Sinai. There is a chance of PLO incursions into the Gaza Strip using arms caches which it was reported to us are in the Sinai Desert. As I have said, all these possibilities were put seriously to the delegation.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of clouds on the horizon. Of course the first one is the autonomy talks between Egypt and Israel, which is the next step in the so-called peace process. In my opinion, the views of both sides are irreconcilable and I do not think we will see that next step being taken in the near future. The Australian situation was quite favourable. We had a very low profile in the area . We had excellent relations with both sides. We had built up quite a large trade with the Arab nations and, of course, we had our strong traditional support of Israel.

It is quite evident to me and to other members of our delegation that our contribution to the Sinai has dramatically raised the Australian profile in the region. Australia will now be expected to have a view on all issues in the middle East and in future no comment will not be good enough. We will undergo a constant test of our relations with the United States, our relations with Israel , our relations with the Arabs and in particular our attitude to the PLO. It will be a constant test that need not necessarily be a bad thing but I think Australia must be prepared to stand up and be counted on a number of issues involving one of the major trouble spots of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the first reading of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills I make no apology whatsoever for speaking generally on the subject of the Bills and being concerned with the vital and principled issues that arise particularly from the decision recently made by the Australian Democrats. The decision may well lead to the defeat of these Bills and consequences which, I think, are horrifying for the sustainability of democratic government in this country. Therefore I believe it is a subject which ought to be examined fully. We ought to look at the record of the Australian Democrats and urge them, even at this early stage in the debate, to think again or face the fate which the Democratic Labor Party faced when it lost its principles and sought to embark upon a different track.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we have heard from Senator Evans and others references to 'constitutional purity', as though how honourable senators vote on an important question such as this is just a matter of purity or slight impurity. It is not; it is a much more fundamental matter than that. We have seen reference in the Press to how the Democrats have now lost their innocence. It is not a simple matter like that. Surely they have been past innocence for quite a long time. At times they have shown themselves to be quite mature in their determinations on this issue. But they have moved away from their determination and they have done it for popularity alone. I am afraid they have decided that popularity is more important and should be heeded at the expense of principle. If principles matter at all they matter when they are important--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have learned a good lesson from your lot. Look at your Prime Minister. What has he done?

—I will not reply to the honourable senator-probably my voice will not stand it-but I make my speech and set forth here the matters which I believe ought to be on record for the Australian people. It is easy to have principles when everything is going with one and when one is winning. It is unpopular principles that are the test. At the moment the Australian Democrats have a cause which is superficially and temporarily popular. They feel that they can get easy popularity by going along with the ridiculous line which the Australian Labor Party has created for itself in regard to money Bills and Supply. The Australian Democrats have been led astray. In fact this is a--
—How did you vote in 1975?

—I will certainly deal with 1975; fear nothing about that. Admittedly part of this legislation is unpopular. A government with a mandate in the House of Representatives and a mandate to determine its Budgets, something to which the Democrats and others pointed, has determined that these taxes ought to be collected. I have criticised these taxes before and made representations about them. I believe that some particular parts of the tax are unwise and will not be very effective. But it is not for the Senate to determine those matters. It is a decision for a government which, of course, has its obligations to its electors. The issues will be dealt with and argued at the proper time when the Government will be judged upon the whole of its financial policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Some honourable senators say there has been a change of front by the Australian Democrats. Since the Australian Democrats have been in this chamber they have promoted some excellent ideas. Many of the points which they have raised in debate about Bills and so forth are matters that very often ought to have been raised earlier. If they stuck to that positive line of action, I think there would be a future for them. But if they choose to move from their major principles, I think their future will be very short.

I go back to 1975, the year to which an honourable senator referred. The leader and founder of the Democrats, Senator Chipp, was a member of parliament, as I was, in 1975. Today he acknowledges that he made a mistake of judgment then. He has admitted to quite a few mistakes of judgment which the Australian Democrats have made in recent times. At that time I resisted, month after month, the very enticing idea that because a government was in trouble, as it was then, one should take the opportunity to try to throw it out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you cross the floor?

—My crossing the floor would have made no difference; I can assure the honourable senator of that. The honourable senator has forgotten Senator Field of Queensland. I stood up and opposed that idea. Where was Senator Chipp then? He was very determined. He was among the strongest advocates of throwing the rascals out. He wanted an early election. I could never get any support from Senator Chipp at that time. I looked in vain for support from him in the Party room or in the Parliament. Now Senator Chipp has recognised that he was mistaken in those days. In an interview reported in the Bulletin on 21 October 1980, Senator Chipp expressed his sense of guilt over the Vietnam issue but he felt no guilt about supporting the blocking of Supply. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I put that down to being a bad error of judgment. . . In '75 the bloody place was in a hell of a mess. The proposition I supported was that we would go to an election and let the people decide. I didn't have the faintest idea it was going to be such a divisive and emotional issue. No member of the shadow cabinet had any idea that Kerr was going to sack Whitlam.

He admits that he certainly did not have the foresight then. However, following that he developed it but somehow it has disappeared in the last few weeks. Also relevant to Senator Chipp's attitude in 1975 is what he said when interviewed on 17 August 1981 by Derryn Hinch, who pointed out that Senator Chipp made much of signing affidavits. I will come to that point in a few moments. Derryn Hinch asked:
How did that change in your mind from when you were a member of the Government back in 1975 when you blocked Supply?
Senator Chipp replied:

Because I saw what it did. It threw the country into turmoil. It divided the country. Although the Senate has that power, we opted of our own free will as Democrats, to say 'we might have that power to do it, but we believe it wrong for the Senate to do it', so we virtually abrogated that power that we have. Now if you want me to say 'I believe we were wrong in 1975', I'll say it, because that is what I believe.

Honourable senators should note that he said that they abrogate that power. That was the position then. In fact at the last election when a number of Australian Democrats were elected they abrogated that power. They became neutered. They told the people: 'Trust us. We are not dangerous. We will not use this power'. Of course, now they have decided, enticed by the opportunities that they think might be before them, to leave that and to use the power.

I want to say something about the actions of the Australian Democrats at the last election. I was very fascinated when they put down statutory declarations as to what they were going to do. Perhaps we did not read the fine print of the statutory declarations closely enough. Whenever people come to me and say, 'I will swear this on a stack of bibles', I become very suspicious of them. I wonder why they need to say that, why they cannot rely upon their general integrity and say: 'This is what we will do and this is what we will not do'. They have to go through the drama of making statutory declarations. It is worth while recalling and recording and what is in those statutory declarations. I have here the standard form of the statutory declaration which the Australian Democrats all signed. Let us see what they said. We find now that they are quoting only one part, the more extreme part which relates to the bringing down of governments. But they said more than that. I will read paragraphs 3 and 4, the relevant parts, of that statutory declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they all say this?
—I understand that they all said this. They all signed a standard form.
—Not all. Senator Chipp and Senator Mason did not sign those declarations.
—They did not? I think this is the first time the public has ever heard that. I had always understood that all Australian Democrat senators had signed that statutory declaration.
—Only those senators who were standing for election.

—I see. Of course, Senator Chipp and Senator Mason were not standing for election. I would have thought that they all would have made those undertakings. It was only those honourable senators who stood for election. That is something that we have now found out. That is something new. In the statutory declarations which at least the three new senators signed they said:

SPEECH.PARA: That I personally subscribe to and endorse without reservation of any kind the publicly announced policy of the Australian Democrats, as stated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, the Honourable Senator D. L. Chipp, that the Australian Democrats, if gaining a position of 'balance of power' in the Senate would not use their voting numbers in such a way as to cause the blocking of supply or money bills . . .
I ask honourable senators to notice the play of words on those two things-
. . . in a manner which would prevent the majority party in the House of Representatives from governing.

That surely is what the Democrats are doing now. They are blocking the sales tax Bills and the important parts of the Budget of the majority party in the House of Representatives. It is interesting to note that, although Senator Chipp may not have signed that declaration, the Democrats are affirming his publicly announced policy. Paragraph 4 of the statutory declaration, the paragraph more quoted by Senator Chipp these days, is a little more extreme. It states:

That for all purposes and with no reservation of any kind, I hereby declare that if elected to the Senate I shall not cast my vote as a Senator in a manner which would be contrary to the policy of the Australian Democrats as stated in Paragraph 3 hereof and thus shall never during my tenure as a Senator contribute to or cause a situation which through blocking of supply or money bills might bring down the Government.

The words 'bring down the Government' are stronger. That is the paragraph that the Democrats tend to quote now, having had a change of mind. But both of those things are in the statutory declaration and at least they are bound by them.

We have been told time and again about 'keeping the bastards honest' and what must be done to 'keep governments in control' and so forth. Nowhere have we been told how we are to keep the Democrats honest. People voted for them on the basis of principles. I suggest that of the 10 per cent or so of the public in Australia who brought those people into office, most were concerned that they would not be likely to bring down governments, that they would act honestly in this regard, and that they would be consistent. If they fail in that what is the basis of their support? In regard to this matter it is interesting to note that Senator Chipp said this in his policy speech at the time of his election:

Can you be sure your Members of Parliament will keep their word? If not, what can you do about them until the next election? You can keep them honest by giving the Democrats the balance of power in the Senate . . .
Of course, now we see what that really involves us in.

I wish now to deal with the position in August or September 1981. Let us come to the better period, the high point of Democrat principle when they were saying things and determining their action on these sales tax Bills for the first time. They, like a horse, ran to jump the fence that the sales tax imposed. At the first running they bolted and went back again. They did not jump the fence. They did not jump into the fence either. They put it off for a period. Now, of course , they have jumped and they have fallen into the fence. In August they were being berated by the Australian Labor Party. Honourable senators will remember that the Labor Party had just developed a new philosophy; that one could just take some money Bills and supply Bills and that, provided they were not important enough to really disturb the government and knock it down it was all right. This is known in China as 'death by a thousand cuts'. One can cut off a limb or a bit here or there and so forth. Ultimately the victim dies but I suppose one could say that not one of these were major incisions. Only at the end did the victim bleed to death. The Democrats are now going to adopt this policy but this was not the case in August and September 1981.
I ask honourable senators to listen now to what was said-this is one of my best and favourite quotations-by Dr Michael Macklin, already in the Senate, about the Democrats' attitude on sales tax:

The sales tax provisions have many disturbing effects-on the building industry, first home buyers, low-income families, and they would introduce an unwarranted new tax on information-but the legal advice we have received is that they are part of the Budget parcel. As such, no Senate has the right to reject them.

The Australian Democrats were elected under a promise never to use our power in the Senate to block Supply-and rightly so. Nobody should want a repetition of the events of November, 1975. By referring part of the legislation back to the Lower House, we have steered away from this possibility and at the same time we have given voters an opportunity to register their disapproval.

By taking the stance it did last week Labor-also pledged not to block Supply- has abandoned all pretence of political principles. Despite all it said in 1975 the ALP has now joined the Liberals in using the Senate for short-term political advantage. The lesson has not been learned.

Irrespective of the potential electoral backlash to the Democrats, we will not follow the Liberal and Labor parties in breaking election pledges. We could hardly claim to keep either of the old parties honest unless we are honest ourselves.

What a splendid statement! I make no apology for reading it with some inflection or for thinking that that represented the high point in Australian Democrat history. Let us see how Senator Mason was handling this at that same time or just before during the Budget debate. Part of the quotation which I am about to read was read by Senator Messner today. But let us hear the whole of it. Senator Mason was explaining why the Democrats did not like the Bills but said that they were not going to vote them down. Senator Tate interjected:
You can reject this when it comes back here.
The Hansard record then reads:

TALK.START.PARA: —True; I will go on to that. We are facing that one. We are not dodging that one. True to our word, if the Government takes the reprehensible step of rejecting that request the Australian Democrats will not oppose the passage of that Budget legislation through the Senate. That is definite. It is a considered decision. That is the way it is going to go. Sorry chums, that is the way it is. Undesirable though these sales tax increases are, damaging though their impact may be--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-
One does not need too many guesses as to where those interjections were coming from. Senator Mason continued:

Listen to this senators, it is my bottom line. Those on the Labor side in particular should listen to this. Undesirable though the sales tax increases are , damaging though their impact might be, the consequences of the Senate meddling in, or unilaterally rewriting a Budget, seem to us too horrifying to contemplate .
That, too, is one of my favourite quotations which I trust will be enshrined for all time. Senator Mason also said on that same day:

We can legally reject Supply Bills but what would be the long term implications of such an action? A respectable view can be put forward that the right of any government, including a Labor government, to create a Budget and govern is inviolate.
I suggest that that is so. I do not want to swell Senator Mason's head too much. When he was questioned on AM on 21 October he was asked:
Will you be trying to block them again in February.
His answer was this:

No, we will not be blocking them for the reasons which we have stated time and time again, that the Democrats will not precipitate a re-run of November 1975. We see that if the sales tax legislation were blocked permanently from the Government, it would interfere with their Budget to the extent where they could, as indeed the Government is saying, take the country to a double dissolution. And I would agree, they would be justified in both circumstances.

I hope that the Australian Democrats are listening to those words because clearly they have increased the possibilities of a double dissolution. If a party loses all its moral integrity and fibre it is very vulnerable in the eyes of the public even though it may think it has popularity because of the issue on which it voted. Senator Mason has said this in a number of ways. At that time he made it very clear that it was a considered decision. I do not doubt that at that time Senator Chipp knew what the Democrats were doing and did not take any stance against it. On 19 August Senator Chipp made some comments on the PM program. In reply to a question he said:

Well we can't back away from being, from breaking a promise either and we're not going to be dishonourable because I'll remind you that one of the things I featured during the election campaign, under no circumstances, not even ' reprehensible' circumstances, would we ever block Supply or impede a money bill so as to prevent a democratically elected Government from governing. And this proposal of the Labor Party, which unfortunately is knee jerk, I think it hasn't been considered, the implications of it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—That was said by Senator Chipp on 19 August 1981.
—In the chamber?

—No, that was said on the PM program. All these things were right attitudes at the time; apparently they are now wrong attitudes. We know now the Democrats have said that they are wrong again and that they are going to vote against these Bills. In a statement on 16 February Senator Chipp said that it was an error of judgment to have said all that. He went on to say, and I think this is interesting:

SPEECH.PARA: As the Government's members in the House of Representatives have resisted the continued representations of the majority of the community during the five months delay achieved by the Democrats, we believe the Senate now has no option but to take action itself.

In other words, he is passing the buck. He is telling the people that, because members of the House of Representatives in their judgment, which surely they are entitled to make, and on hearing all the representations which they got decided that they should support these Bills, this gives the Democrats some excuse to run away from their loudly announced policies of a number of years. One might ask: What is next? If these Bills are to be thrown out, what next? There is no longer any principle guide as to what they may or may not support. If the Government wanted some money to build a nuclear power station, for example, because it had determined that there was a need-we know what the views of the Democrats are on nuclear power stations-clearly that Bill would be thrown out because that is something that they do not want. The Government may find it is necessary to build such a nuclear power station to meet the energy requirements of the country. One can think of many instances where the views of the Democrats differ from those of the Government and where they now have no excuse for taking such views. There is no way for the public to judge how they will react to any of these matters. Senator Mason says the present situation is due to the attitudes of the members of the House of Representatives. That view is quite contrary to the view he adopted in August. That was not his reason then for taking the decision he did.

The Australian Democrats should be aware of the fate of the Democratic Labor Party. In 1974, five Democratic Labor Party senators were apparently ensconced for some time in this chamber. Their principles and views were well known. It was noted that one of their members turned from the party, sold out, took an office at the behest of the Government and betrayed them and their principles. In a matter of weeks all the Democratic Labor Party senators had disappeared. I had the pleasure of eliminating their leader, Senator McManus, by my entering this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good on you.

—I thank the honourable senator for his interjection. At the same time, I think we were perhaps fortunate that it was a party which was based upon certain principles and not much more. Once those principles are broken a party is very fragile indeed. I warn the Democrats that if they vote this way they are likely to go the same way and will not be in this chamber for very long. The Government has a responsibility to make a determination with respect to Bills such as those before us. I may not like these Bills and I may not like some others, but I do not put myself in the place of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the people who have to determine the financial policies of this country. We know that under the Constitution the Senate has limited financial powers. It is recognised that there is a primacy in the House of Representatives. As much as we may think at times that the House of Representatives is a poor chamber and does not stand up very well for its rights, it is not for us to weaken its position or to arrogate to ourselves things which we feel we might know better about. There have been errors of judgment by the Australian Democrats. They admit it themselves. If they vote against these Bills it will be the worst error of judgment they have ever made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a very polished performance from Senator Missen, as one might expect from an ex-champion Australian debater. He has said a lot of things. He has hammered the point that there is a question of principle involved here insofar as it applies to legal arguments about what the Senate can or cannot reject under the Constitution. He has further attributed certain comments to our leader, Senator Chipp, which only he and Senator Chipp were privy to. I assure the Senate that Senator Chipp will be speaking later in this debate and is well able to defend himself in respect of those remarks that were attributed to him in 1975. Senator Missen has claimed also that there is now a danger that the Australian Democrats might throw out any Bill-a Bill on uranium, for instance. I remind Senator Missen that the Democrats themselves cannot throw out a Bill. The Democrats and the Australian Labor Party can combine to block legislation; we cannot do it by ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot of legal arguments this afternoon about this situation, we have heard interpretations of our pledges and we have heard about the consequences of our changing our stance or our tactics in relation to the sales tax legislation. All these matters are secondary to our overwhelming concern- that concern has increased rapidly as the months have gone by-that if we voted for the introduction of sales tax on the necessities of life, we would be increasing the grinding burden on the family man. That is an overwhelming consideration and the only one that any responsible member of this chamber should consider.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you receive many representations over the summer period?

—I will cover that point if the honourable senator will allow me to continue; it is basic to the argument that I wish to present. Our predictions last August that the Budget would be a catastrophe have, in fact, been borne out . The balance of payments situation is appalling, inflation is acute, the housing and construction industry is collapsing. Despite all this, the Government refuses to alter its course and is not prepared to reflate the economy even to a mild extent. It has been unable to control interest rates, inflation, unemployment or the balance of payments. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) stated recently that he does not intend to index taxation or otherwise reduce the burden of income tax. The inescapable fact is that the passage of the sales tax legislation will immediately and directly increase unemployment and inflation and, in particular, it will increase the cost of housing. Should we vote for legislation that will exacerbate these burdens on the average battling Australian?
—You told us you should.

—I have been making the point that the economy has deteriorated rapidly since August. Situations change. We were elected to keep the Government to its election promises. Bearing in mind the rapid deterioration of the economy , if we had voted for this legislation we would have done so in blatant disregard of the wishes of the electorate-the people at large. That position was abundantly clear, and it should have been abundantly clear to the Government that something had to be done.
—Why? Is it because of the representations made to you?

—I want to keep my remarks brief. I have essentially made the point that the overwhelming consideration was the decision that we had to face as to whether we would be party to increasing a rapidly growing burden on the Australian family. It can be argued that to vote for increasing taxes on the necessities of life is in fact the antithesis of the Government's pledge to reduce inflation and unemployment. We could not vote for that. That is our position. We in the Australian Democrats can see no other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity on the first reading of a money Bill to raise the matter of resettlement of refugees in Australia and in particular to look at the role of government departments in this matter. I should like to illustrate what I have to say tonight by reference to a case which is at present in the news and which was mentioned on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program AM this morning. It relates to 34 Laotians who came to the Northern Territory in June 1980. I will try to avoid generalising from one case but it could be that by an examination of this case some lessons will be learned by the departments which will assist in future. Let me then relate the history, as I understand it, of the group I refer to.

SPEECH.PARA: I should preface my comments by saying that I have spoken to members of the group-not to all of them but to more than half of them-the social worker from the Resources and Settlement Centre in Darwin, an officer from the Northern Territory Immigration and Ethnic Affairs section of the Department of Community Development, and to employers and others who have come in contact with members of this group since they arrived in Australia. The situation is that a family group of 34 people moved from Laos into a Thai refugee camp. A relative of theirs who was living in Darwin, a Mrs Vilay Buschman, visited the camp in 1980. She was disturbed by the conditions she saw there, and whilst she had no criticism of the Thai Government she shared the view of others of us who have seen the camps in Thailand and in other areas. She came back to Australia and put the proposition to her husband-who, incidentally, is an American who has lived here for many years-that they would sponsor the family as a group of refugees to come to Australia. She contacted the Federal Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and she also contacted this group I spoke of previously, a small department in the Northern Territory Government also called Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is a part of the Community Development Department of the Northern Territory Government.

The Immigration and Ethnic Affairs group of the Northern Territory Government then approached the Federal Department and put a proposition to it. The proposition was very similar to one advanced by the Honourable Nick Dondas, M.L. A. when he had responsibility for immigration in the Northern Territory. He put his proposal to a meeting of State and Federal Ministers in 1980. Basically the proposition was that refugees should come to Australia in groups, be settled on farms in the Northern Territory and carry on what might be called subsistence living-I do not use that word in any derogatory sense-but simply to imply they might look after themselves and be no great burden to the Australian people. He sought funds from the Federal Government for this purpose. Whether it was because he sought funds or not, the proposition was not agreed to. It did, however, at the time excite a good deal of comment both in the Press and, I recall, in this place. I raised the matter and I believe honourable senators on the other side of the chamber were also excited by the proposition. Approval to bring the family out was nevertheless given by the Federal Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

I will not go into fine detail here but basically the group consisted of Mrs Buschman's father-a man 91 years of age at that time-his second wife and their three children, four of Mrs Buschman's brothers and sisters and their spouses and families. Some of the families ran into the second generation. There was a total of 34 people in all. These people arrived in Darwin in June 1980. The family was met at the airport by the Buschmans and taken to a property south of Darwin known as Tumbling Waters. It is a delightful area. The accommodation available to them there, as I understand it, was a shed with a roof but no walls and a dirt floor. Beds had been purchased and set up in this open shed. No running water was available but water was available from a river close by and could be carried up to the shed. There were no toilets but there was ample space for these to be dug by the refugees.

The plan which Mr Buschman and his wife had was basically this: that the group would live on the farm, very much along the lines I have suggested; that they would be able to establish themselves there and grow most of the food they needed. They would keep livestock, mainly in the form of poultry, and some members of the group would seek employment off the property to bring in additional money. I must say at this stage that the Northern Territory Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs assisted in the finding of positions for these people, as did the Buschmans and others who had agreed to co -operate and assist. The fourth section of the plan was that the adults would attend English classes until they became proficient in English so that they would be more able to be employed and that the children would attend school-some in the primary school and some in the secondary school. Of course, not having English they would attend the excellent classes conducted by the Northern Territory Department of Education for both younger children and teenage students . That was the plan put forward by Mr Buschman which was agreed to, apparently, by the Department in that it gave approval for the family to come out.

Let us jump from the time at which they arrived to a period of six months or so later when in January 1981 one of the group, Phayloth, came to the Resources and Settlement Centre and laid certain complaints. He alleged firstly, that the living conditions were inadequate. Honourable senators might recall that I mentioned earlier that the group of people were living in a shed and that the toilet facilities were reasonably primitive-dug out close to the shed. There were few cooking facilities apart from barbecues and open fires which they could construct outside the shed. The second section of his complaint was that all of the moneys-that is, the unemployment benefits where appropriate, the family allowances and some wages-were paid into trust accounts, Mrs Buschman being trustee for all the people. I should explain here that some people worked off the property and in addition to this Mr Buschman had a contract with a poultry processor to supply labour at certain times. Some people worked under contract for Mr Buschman in poultry processing. The complaint Phayloth made about this money being paid into the accounts was that the members did not have access to it, and he made the additional complaint that they were kept short of money.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was speaking about the refugee settlement situation in the Northern Territory. I was explaining how one of the group of 34 Laotians who came to Australia, a gentleman by the name of Phayloth, had been to the Resource and Settlement Centre and had made certain allegations and complaints. The first was about living conditions. The second concerned the fact that all moneys were paid into a trust account. I was about to move on to the third complaint which he made, and that was that the people were not allowed to leave the farm. When I pressed him on this he explained that the only transport available was held by Mr Buschman and it was not always possible for Mr Buschman to take the people to town. I think we have to be a little wary about the proposition that they were not allowed to leave. Perhaps on some occasions their movement away from the farm was not facilitated. The social worker at the Resource and Settlement Centre, Mrs J. Kaese-Hagen, took Phayloth to the Department of Social Security in early 1981. He presented to the Department a list of complaints which he had prepared with some support by a friend in Darwin. The Department of Social Security took one action only, and that was to stop Phayloth's cheque and to pay him by cash. It did not take any further action. I will come back to that later. Phayloth obtained a job at a local firm at which he was not successful. Then he and his wife went to Sydney. This movement to Sydney was organised by the Resource and Settlement Centre. He returned to Darwin in 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: Continuing the chronology, in March 1981 Salieng-I just make the point that Salieng is a lady-came to the Resource and Settlement Centre with complaints similar to those that had been raised by Phayloth. She had left the farm having several complaints about money and she had been befriended by a Darwin family. She continued to work at the hospital and her husband continued to work at the poultry farm. Following her visit to the Resource and Settlement Centre, Salieng contacted the Federal Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs which sent two officers in April to look at Buschman's farm. They did not have an interpreter when they visited and so they relied on Mr Buschman himself to interpret for them. When they came back they made no report to the Resource and Settlement Centre although they had been asked by it to visit the farm. In answer to a telephone query they made the comment that living at the farm was ' better than a refugee camp'. Towards the end of the year the remainder of the group left the farm although one person continued to work on it. The Resource and Settlement Centre was able to contact the Northern Territory Housing Commission in Darwin and arrange emergency housing for the four families. I just make the point that no application had been made by anyone prior to this time for a Housing Commission house. On the arrival of the Laotians in the Territory no arrangement had been made to put their names on the housing list.

We move now fairly quickly to 16 January this year when a number of members of the group visited Buschman's home in Darwin. Their intention was to get from him and from his wife the bank books, documents and clothing which they claimed were theirs. I understand that there was some fracas at the home and Buschman called the police. On the advice of the police he later sought an injunction to prevent the group visiting either his Darwin property or the Tumbling Waters farm. The Resource and Settlement Centre arranged for legal aid. The case is to be heard on 1 March, so I do not want to discuss it.

I do not want to get involved in any sort of family problems that might exist among all of the members of that family. My concern, at this stage anyway, is to raise a number of queries regarding the involvement of government departments. Perhaps I can list them in three main groupings. Firstly, I ask: Was sufficient investigation carried out by the departments prior to approval being given by the Minister for this Laotian family to come to Australia? Let me remind the Senate of the facts. Mr Buschman had one house in Darwin and a partially completed shed on the farm. The question must be asked: Are one house and one shed enough for Mr Buschman himself and his family and 34 additional people? We might ask further: Was the farm investigated to see whether it was suited to settlement and this self sufficiency that I spoke of earlier and called subsistence living?

Did both the Federal and Territory departments of immigration and ethnic affairs really investigate the viability of the scheme which was put to them by the Buschmans? Was much thought given to the strength of family ties and the relationship of Mrs Buschman to the rest of the family? I do not wish to elaborate on this except to say that those of us who have been to that area know that a person who has moved away from a family to work in a main centre and then has married a foreigner, an American, is not always accepted by the rest of the family. How much thought was given to the appriateness of Mr and Mrs Buschman as sponsors to handle what anyone would regard as an extremely difficult task; that is, settling a family of 34 people-four or five groups of adults and a number of children-in a new environment.

I go on to a second bracket of questions. We have talked about what might have happened before the Laotians arrived. How much support was given to the sponsors after this group had arrived and, of course, how much follow-up support was given to the family? We know that the Territory immigration and ethnic affairs people tried to find employment for the adults. We know that the children were enrolled at school-the younger children at primary school and the older children at secondary school. We know that some adults attended English classes for two or three months but then they were required back at the farm to do additional work so they were withdrawn from the English classes.

So, for the first four, five, or six months from June 1981 everything seemed satisfactory. What happened then? These questions, I think, must be put directly to the government departments. Did the Department of Social Security really examine the claim made by Phayloth that unemployment benefit and family allowances were not made available to the recipients and that some arrangement had been made whereby someone had trust accounts that this money was paid into and was denying the normal recipients of family allowances and unemployment benefits access to the money. Did Social Security examine allegations that unemployment benefit was being paid to people who were actually working even though they might have been working only one, two or three days a week? Did the Northern Territory Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Section have a look at the living conditions to which it had encouraged the Federal Government to bring these people? Did the Commonwealth Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Department look at the living conditions? Did the Commonwealth Department investigate whether the sponsors were meeting the conditions which they promised or which they set out when they requested that the 34 people be brought to Australia?

The last question in this general area is: Is the comment from officers of the Department that it was 'better than refugee camp' really sufficient? The Department is certainly more stringent than this in the cases that I have had to deal with. The Department is very seldom prepared to take an open tin shed as being sufficient accommodation. Even if it were better than the refugee camp is that sufficient for us? Are we prepared to accept those sorts of conditions? I would have thought not. I would have thought that we in Australia, if we were bringing people to Australia, would have wanted something more appropriate, something nearer the level which the majority of people in Australia enjoy.

I do not want to discourage refugee settlement-I have spoken in this place before on the topic-but I want it to be effective. We seem to have a situation where the majority of the group that came out under this sponsorship program are living in emergency housing. The majority of these are on unemployment benefit. I am not complaining about this. But we have brought these people out and the majority of them are now living here at considerable cost to the Australian community. Again, I am not complaining but I do not think we ought to create these sorts of situations. I am not suggesting either, of course, that members of the group are themselves blameless. It could be that they are not making the contribution that they ought to be making. Perhaps they are not prepared to get in and work a little harder. Perhaps they are not prepared to take their share of the responsibility for the farm enterprise not working out. Most of the members to whom I spoke seem committed. Some are in employment and are working well, it must be said, some are not. It is as blunt as that.

Without developing this theme any further I just say that perhaps the example I have brought before the Senate today will help us to play our part in refugee programs by improving our techniques in three ways: Firstly, prior to arrival by checking sponsors and instructing those who are coming to Australia about their responsibilities-surely that is part of the program; secondly, after arrival by providing back-up services and assisting with appropriate accommodation and employment-we should make sure that this is available before the people are brought out; and, thirdly, in the post-arrival period by continuing to give support until the refugees are settled and have become contributing members of our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I argue that the Sales Tax Amendment Bills should be supported. To reach that stage I will argue for the desirability of changing the tax mix in Australia with a reduction in direct tax, particularly income tax, and a corresponding increase in and broadening of the indirect tax base. One legitimate and valid way in which this can be achieved is by extending the current sales tax. The Budget sought a package of sales tax extensions which increased the overall existing tax, removed certain anomalies and widened the tax base to include certain transactions which were not previously so taxed. I believe that as a package the legislation can be fairly said to have the potential for generating desirable reductions in direct taxes, particularly personal income tax as economic and budgetary conditions permit. This was the objective stated by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the Budget, and is an objective with which I concur.

SPEECH.PARA: Why should we change the tax mix? In recent times it has been widely accepted that whereas the overall level of taxation in Australia may not be comparatively high nevertheless Australia relies heavily on direct taxes, particularly income tax. Of the member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development only Japan, which does not have any consumption tax, derives a smaller proportion of its revenue from indirect taxation. Australia raises 6.1 per cent of its revenue in this way. It can be compared with such countries as Austria, with a figure over 19 per cent; Belgium, over 17 per cent; Canada, over 12 per cent; Denmark, over 21 per cent; Finland, 20 per cent; France, over 21 per cent; Germany, over 15 per cent; Ireland, over 19 per cent; the Netherlands, over 16 per cent; et cetera. Thus Australia is out of step with most highly developed countries in this regard.

I wish to put three principal reasons to the Senate as to why the Australian community would be better off with some redress of the balance between direct and indirect taxation. The first is the sum of taxation revenue being lost through avoidance of direct taxation and the consequences of that loss. Despite the Government's best endeavours such knowledgeable commentators as Professor Russell Mathews still estimate that 20 per cent of the personal income tax normally required to be paid is being lost to revenue through avoidance and evasion, usually by high income tax payers rather than wage and salary earners. Professor Russell Mathews, in a recent article, said:

. . . quite apart from its unfortunate effects on the distribution of the tax burden, this revenue loss has had a direct impact on the size of the public sector budget deficit, the level of government borrowing, the rate of growth of money supplies and the level of interest rates.

Expenditure based taxes are much harder to avoid than income based taxes. Secondly, the reliance on income tax has meant a need for high marginal rates which has an adverse effect on incentives and a consequent loss of economic efficiency. Thirdly, and as something of a corollary to the first two points, again as Professor Mathews says, the tax system appears to have largely failed as machinery for the redistribution of wealth on a more equitable basis. Because of the ease of avoiding income tax and the loss of incentive at higher marginal rates the tax has not had the progressive effect usually claimed of taxation systems with a high direct tax content. Indirect taxation with an increasing scale from the so-called necessaries through to luxury goods, offers greater opportunity for a progressive effect, particularly in a system without significant capital taxes and no wealth tax or death or estate duties. Progressively scaled indirect taxes offer an opportunity to redress the mix where a significant section of the community low in income but high in wealth contributes little to the tax burden.

It is worth recalling that it was also the recommendation of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee in 1975 after its comprehensive review of the Australian taxation system that there should be greater reliance upon taxes of goods and services by the inclusion of a broad-based tax. Given the desirability of an alteration of the tax mix, and keeping the debate within the sphere of consumption or expenditure taxation, the alternatives open to government must be considered. In that regard it should be recognised that Australia's indirect tax system is narrow-based and highly discriminatory. Simply to increase the rates would therefore not be desirable. To broaden the indirect tax base would be to reduce distortion and improve horizontal equity-that is, persons in the same position should be treated equally. Thus not only should we look to a better balance between direct and indirect taxes than currently exists but the base of the current indirect taxes should be broadened.

Four obvious alternative systems of broad-based indirect tax would have had to be considered. The Government could have imposed, firstly, a value added tax; secondly, a retail turnover tax, possibly with a selected services tax; or, thirdly, a personal expenditure or consumption tax. Fourthly the current Australian sales tax, which is a wholesale point of sale tax, could have been broadened. The Government chose the fourth alternative for reasons which are sound and logical. Whether or not it was the best way to go is a question for political judgment with which I may not necessarily agree but the reasons for which I am prepared to concede are sound.

The value added tax is a multi-stage tax imposed at all stages of the production and distribution chain for goods and services. It is generally conceded to be an equitable tax but it does impose an enormous paper work burden on taxpayers and collecting authorities. It tends therefore to be cumbersome in its operation and expensive to administer. For those reasons I suspect that it was dismissed by government. A retail turnover tax has the potential to generate large income from low rates of tax and therefore has considerable appeal. On the other hand, it would necessitate an extensive licensing system and provide a significant increase in the number of tax paying units. There would be the difficulty of educating a large number of new taxpayers and recruiting and training administrative staff. The addition of a selected services tax also has appeal but, as has been argued elsewhere, it has limitations. To tax services such as interstate passenger and freight services falls beyond the Commonwealth' s tax powers. Certain transactions, such as betting transactions are already taxed at the State level. For such reasons it appears that the alternative of a retail turnover tax together with a selected services tax was also dismissed.

The third alternative, that of a general personal consumption tax, has considerable theoretical appeal on accepted criteria of equity, efficiency and, to a lesser degree, simplicity. However, it would be a totally new concept requiring a complete re-education of the Australian public. Additionally the transition problems would be enormous. Although it has been considered from time to time by both the United Kingdom and the United States of America, neither country has been prepared to proceed with any real form of implementation. To some extent, it has operated in Sri Lanka and India. However, to change the whole emphasis of our taxation from personal income to personal expenditure is not something which could simply be introduced in a Budget. I believe that in the longer term it would be a subject upon which the Government could profitably encourage public debate. Such stimulation by means of a Green Paper or otherwise would, in my opinion, be a worthwhile exercise.

This left the fourth alternative; that is, an extension of the current sales tax. I thought that the reasons for the Government's decision to extend further the current sales tax rather than introduce a new form of consumption tax were well stated by my colleague Senator Jessop on 8 September 1981 when he made a statement which I respectfully adopt. He said:
He said:

If there is to be a greater reliance on indirect taxes, it will be necessary to find the tax that is best suited to Australia's political and economic framework . The main requirements for such a tax are that it should raise the required revenue, should be administratively simple and cheap, should keep the economic side effects to a minimum and should be politically acceptable. On the whole sales tax fits this bill.

It is true that it is an indirect tax with which the community is familiar. It has in fact been part of our taxation system since it was introduced by a Labor government in 1930 when it was imposed on a very wide range of goods, including many food items. It is administratively quite straightforward. It involves a small number of relatively large businesses, usually with developed accounting systems. The expense involved in extending the existing tax is relatively light compared with any new form of tax. Given therefore that extensions to the current sales tax were observed as the way to go, the Government had then to decide in which way the tax was to be extended. The Government obviously wanted to do it in a way that had the least detrimental effect upon inflation; further, it was anxious that the extension should not be regressive; and, finally, it desired that it be a broad-based tax in order that adequate income could be raised at a low rate.

I wish to consider briefly the three objectives I have just mentioned in the light of the package of sales tax measures proposed by the Budget, the last part of which is before the Senate tonight. In relation to inflation, Treasury figures indicate that the impact of sales tax Budget measures on the consumer price index could be calculated at only 0.8 per cent. In this regard it should be particularly noted that the rate of increase of indirect taxes in recent years has been falling. By this year's Budget it was planned to increase by 3.7 per cent compared with 5.1 per cent in the previous year 9.6 per cent in 1979-80 and 15.5 per cent in 1978-79. Thus, although sales tax is to be extended, the total rate of increase, and, therefore, the effect on inflation, is moderate compared with previous years.

The second argument concerns whether the changes are regressive. A regressive tax is generally accepted as being one which places a heavier share of the tax burden on low income earners and a disproportionate lower share on high earners. A specific tax on liquor, traditionally widely utilised by low income earners, is therefore regressive and the narrow base of Australians' sales tax in the past has been criticised on such a basis. It follows, therefore, that the more broad-based the tax the greater the option of purchase and the less regressive it tends to be. Add to this higher rates on luxury items as exist in the Australian sales tax system and the tax can actually become of a progressive nature. It is true that certain of the specific items proposed to be taxed, when looked at in isolation, are obviously necessary; for example, clothes. On the other hand, such items provide great options for the taxpayer in the sums of money that are to be spent thereon.

To examine the effect on the income of lower income earners it is, therefore, necessary to make some assessment of what they would in fact be spending on these particular items. A recent study by the Australian Taxation Office showed that approximately 26 per cent of purchases of the lower income groups is food, which is, of course, exempt. If food were included-and such a great percentage of low income earners' income is spent thereon-the tax could be said to have a regressive effect. But estimates of tax that would be paid by low income earners on the items included is in fact very low. It is perhaps for that reason that an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development study recently indicated that broad-based sales taxes tend not to be regressive at lower and middle income levels.

I commend to the Senate the speech of my colleague in the other place, Mr Michael Baume, M.P., who argued that the expenditure by a pensioner on the tax would in fact be less than the increase in the consumer price index resulting from the tax and, as that is passed on in higher pensions, the pensioner will actually be better off relative to the rest of the community. Therefore, he argued that the tax would actually have a progressive effect rather than a regressive effect. Certainly I believe the Government was correct in its assessment that, as a package, broadening the base, increasing the rate on currently existing goods and removing anomalies will provide a tax which is more progressive than before.

Very briefly I wish to mention two of the items included within the current Bills which have aroused extensive campaigns of lobbying. The item which particularly concerns me, because of the deflated building industry in South Australia, is that of sales tax on building products. I think, however, it must be borne in mind that the rate of tax is very low. The most realistic assessments put the addition to the price of an average new home at $400, which gives a repayment of about $60 per year or $1.20 per week. When the package is balanced with the potential for direct tax relief that an extension in indirect tax offers, in addition to the detrimental effect it can potentially have upon the cash economy, I am satisfied that the benefits can outweigh the detriment.

The other subject I wish to mention is the extension of the tax to newspapers, magazines and books. In looking for a broad-based tax at a low rate, I can see little reason why all newspapers, magazines and books should be exempted. Schools, universities, community libraries, et cetera are already exempt and a not inconsiderable portion of the balance of sales of newspapers, magazines and books is for entertainment. As one journalist stated, he could not see why there should be a tax on photography but not a tax on pornography. Contrary to what was originally argued by the lobbyists, indirect taxation on newspapers, magazines and books is the norm rather than the exception in developed countries . The rates are worth noting when they are compared with the 2.5 per cent proposed by the Bills. For example, Austria imposes 7.8 per cent; Belgium 6.1 per cent; Denmark 22 per cent, on books; France 7 per cent; Germany 6.5 per cent ; Ireland 10 per cent; Italy 3 per cent on newspapers and 5 per cent on books; the Netherlands 4.1 per cent; and Sweden 19.1 per cent on books. It is possible to argue against any form of tax. However, if the extension of indirect tax, of which this forms a part, has the ultimate effect of allowing reductions in income tax and therefore a better tax mix, which is the basis upon which I am supporting it, then again I am satisfied that the benefit will outweigh the detriment.

Therefore, in summary, I commend the Bills to the Senate as a logical and sound way, when seen as part of a total package, of taking a small step towards redressing the imbalance between direct and indirect taxes in Australia. I am quite satisfied that if such an imbalance can be overcome, it will be to the benefit of the Australian community as a whole. It is not an ambitious step and will not resolve what I see as the major shortcomings of the Australian tax system which I detailed in my first speech to the Senate on 9 September 1981. It is, however, a constructive contribution and deserves support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I would like to discuss tonight in speaking to the first readings of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1A to 9A) [No. 2] is the nuclear industry. It is an industry which I believe has stalled, and the signs are that it is going into reverse. There is, I believe, no more dramatic example of this than a comparison of the situation in the United States 10 years ago with the current position. At the beginning of the 1970s orders for nuclear reactors within the United States were being lodged almost daily. This peaked in 1973-74 when 40 reactors were requisitioned. The position at the moment is that there are no current orders in the United States. This is not purely an American phenomenon. In Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development countries the peak for orders was in the period from 1972-74. In those three years 44, 56 and 48 units respectively were ordered. In the years 1979 and 1980 orders in the OECD countries totalled 18. Even France, which is resisting the turn away from nuclear power more than any other country, is decreasing the number of orders. There are a number of reasons for this which I will turn to later.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I will have a hard look at the economic effects of this downturn in the nuclear economy. It is perhaps best demonstrated by looking at world uranium prices. The price of uranium yellowcake peaked, because of the popularity of nuclear-based electricity, at the end of May 1979 when it was fetching just over $US43 per lb. The price then began falling. It has now stopped. Although the uranium producers hope it has reached its rock bottom it shows no sign of rallying. The latest figures show that the current price of uranium yellowcake is $US23.5 per lb. To show what sort of effect this is having on the industry, I will quote from a transcript of an interview with the chairperson of Pancontinental, Mr Tony Grey. The interview was broadcast on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's Money Talk program on 23 July 1981. Mr Grey said:
They-
He was referring to uranium prices-

certainly have slid from levels that were in existence a few years ago. They've got to the point where much of the world production capacity, particularly in the United States, is threatened and, indeed mines are closing down.

In the light of this it would seem to be the height of economic stupidity for this Government to be actively pursuing a policy of expansion in the nuclear industry but then again this Government is perhaps in the forefront of world governments when it comes to economic stupidity.

To reinforce this point I refer honourable senators to the developments occurring in the technology for uranium enrichment. There are a number of ways of enriching uranium ready for use in reactors. Enrichment involves the separation of uranium feed into two streams, one enriched in the isotope U-235 to approximately 3 per cent from the naturally occurring 0.7 per cent and usable for fuel, and the other a waste or tail stream decreased in U-235 concentration to a concentration of about 0.2 per cent to 0.3 per cent. These are the basic processes, although there are variations on this theme. The same amount of fuel can be produced from a smaller or larger amount of natural uranium by using more or less enrichment. Variations of up to 20 per cent in natural uranium requirements are accordingly possible. The latest technology being developed in the enrichment area is, as a matter of economics, tending more towards obtaining the same amount of fuel through enriching less uranium. This will have the direct effect of further deepening the depression in the demand for uranium in the world market to which I referred earlier.

Another major influence on the depression of the world uranium market is the decline in world demand for electricity. The demand for this kind of power consumption is now expected to increase at approximately 3 per cent to 3.5 per cent a year which is, in fact, half the rate of growth of the 1960s. This slump has left the electrical power industry, which already has an overcapacity of 40 per cent, with an even greater overcapacity.

There are four big nuclear power producers in the United States. They are Westinghouse, General Electric, Combustion Engineering and the infamous Babcock and Wilcox, the producers involved with the Three Mile Island plant. Only one of these, Westinghouse, is currently believed to be in profit. But when one looks at the situation of that company one quickly realises that this profit comes only after taking into account the huge losses on its uranium contracts, said to be about $US400m a year, following a tax write-off of the same amount. General Electric has nuclear business which accounts for 3 per cent of its total business. It is estimated that it is losing between $US20m to $US40m a year on the nuclear part of its overall operations. Combustion Engineering, which has 10 percent of its business bound up in nuclear matters, is said to be losing between $US10m to $US20m a year on this aspect of its operation.

Finally, I turn to Babcock and Wilcox, which in recent days has earned the record of being the worst abuser of nuclear safeguards and a positive danger to anyone who lives anywhere near a plant constructed by it, as the events of the last day or two have once again shown. At the moment this firm which, as I said earlier, designed the Three Mile Island plant, is losing $US10m a year on the 10 per cent of its business in the nuclear industry. These four big firms are not only suffering from a loss of demand as a result of the drop in nuclear power generated electricity consumption. They are suffering also from many cancellations for nuclear plants. Westinghouse has had 18 orders halted in the last five years. General Electric has had 19 orders stopped since the early 1970s. Combustion Engineering has lost four orders in the past two years. Babcock and Wilcox suffered six cancellations before the nuclear disaster at Three Mile Island and has suffered seven since that date.

Another reason why this is happening is that energy economists and planners in the Western world are finally realising that it is cheaper to generate electricity from coal than from nuclear power. The main reason for this is the enormous capital cost involved in setting up nuclear power stations. Costs in this area are rising at the moment. All predictions are that they will escalate rapidly in the next few years. In a study entitled 'Power Plant Cost Escalation' from Komanoff Energy Associates in New York it is stated that by the late 1980s electricity from nuclear power plants will be at least 25 per cent more expensive than electricity from coal plants. The major reason is that although nuclear plants are cheaper to operate than coal plants the crucial factor is the capital cost. As a result, and as this study shows, nuclear power plants in the United States are being wound down. Komanoff said that nuclear power plants would be operating at 55 per cent capacity. That claim was made five years ago when plants were running at 70 per cent to 80 per cent capacity. The present capacity, according to the American magazine Science, ranges from 50 per cent to 62 per cent, indicating that Komanoff's prediction of five years ago was very close to the point.

Komanoff also now predicts that because of general costs and the costs of mounting safety requirements attached to nuclear plants, the cost of building a nuclear plant in 1988 would be 75 per cent higher than the cost of constructing a coal plant. By the latter part of the decade Komanoff claims that the cost of building and operating nuclear plants will so greatly exceed that for coal plants that many reactors now in the early stages of construction could economically be scrapped and replaced with coal units. That phenomenon is happening at the moment. In America the Virginia Electrical Power Co. is studying the pros and cons of converting two planned reactors from nuclear to coal. I submit that this demonstrates that on economic grounds alone the nuclear industry is in an advanced state of crisis and is getting worse.

One important aspect which I have not as yet touched upon is the question of safety. I believe that the Three Mile Island incident, a disaster which has proven itself to be of immense proportions, has set off a reaction which is yet to stop. To support this I refer to a Republican congressman from the United States-the Oklahoma representative, Mickey Edwards. He has had a long record of being a self-confessed, former pro-nuclear person. He visited the Babcock and Wilcox plant at Three Mile Island. During an interview very soon afterwards with the magazine Congressional Quarterly Congressman Edwards said:

I believed all the rhetoric-that nobody died, that the system worked. I got there and was absolutely shocked at what I saw-at the responses from the Met Ed officials, at the design of the plant, at the training of the people. As I went through all of this, I became convinced the nuclear industry is a kind of loose cannon.
I've just about come to the conclusion that nuclear power may be a nice thing to have, but it just may not work.
It's not true that nobody died at Three Mile Island. The nuclear industry may have died.

Mr Edwards is not alone in his pessimism about the future of the nuclear industry and nuclear power. Another congressman, Morris Udall, the chairman of the American House of Representatives committee responsible for overseeing nuclear regulation, in an interview in February 1979, said:

More and more sound thinkers I talk to believe that nuclear is one of those kinds of technologies that get so complex they fall of their own weight- technologies that are really not compatible with democratic society.

This notion is borne out by the evidence found in atomic and nuclear legislation throughout the world. All relevant pieces of legislation contain aspects which are clearly anti-democratic-suppression of information, suppression of liberties , emergency powers and so on. These safety requirements, which I contend are inadequate, are having a profound effect on the nuclear industry. One direct result of this industry and this type of legislation is unease among the public and, indirectly, unease among corporate managers. In respect of this I will quote very briefly one United States power firm manager, Mr John Selby of Consumers Power. In 1978 he told the Wall Street Journal:
I'd be very reluctant to put shareholders' money into another nuclear plant in the future.

This type of corporate unease in the industry shows no sign of being relieved. The Wall Street Journal in an editorial in the middle of last year emphasised the fact that the uranium and nuclear power industry was in trouble. Those nuclear power stations in the United States which are being constructed are caught up in the immense problems surrounding the safety of the industry. Reports from the United States describe the so-called 'regulatory log-jam' which companies now face when they make the decision to build a nuclear power station. The problems are just beginning to get worse.

I briefly refer honourable senators to recent investigations and research being carried out by scientists in the United States on what levels of ionising radiation persons can be subjected to before they face a serious risk of contracting cancer or suffering some other consequence of radiation poisoning. The most recent and most important work in this area is that being carried out by people such as Professor Edward Radford, professor of epidemiology at the Pittsburg University and former chairperson of the Committee on Biological Effects of Ionising Radiation. His research, which has recently been published and discussed in American scientific journals, came about in a somewhat accidental and ironic fashion. The American scientists working on the development of the neutron bomb became worried about radiation levels in the laboratories in which they were working. This concern directly led to two research groups having a close look at the calculations upon which are based the radiation protection standards which are used throughout the non-communist world at the moment. The standards being used are taken from radiation levels received by the survivors of the atomic blasts at Nagasaki and Hiroshima at the end of the Second World War. The people in those cities were the only large cross- section of people to have received varying amounts of radiation with various degrees of shielding. Therefore, the incidence of cancer among survivors measured against degrees of exposure led scientists throughout the world to measure and to provide standards for the non-communist world's industry.

The results that the professor came across are startling in terms of our current standards. It is now established that the figures for current radiation exposure levels are far too high. This means that the safety standards which apply at the moment in our nuclear industry seem to be too lax. According to Dr Radford, the safety standards should be lowered substantially. He told an American Broadcasting Corporation report in an interview broadcast on the Monitor program at the beginning of November last year that the standards operating in western countries should be lowered by a factor of five; that is, made five times stricter. He said also that the calculations upon which these safety requirements are based-that is, the likelihood of death-should be broadened to take into account the incidence of cancer; cancers which may not be necessarily fatal. I shall quote from the Monitor program and refer to Professor Radford's statement on currently accepted safety standards of permissible exposure in one year. That standard at the moment is, in scientific terms, five rems per year. During the Monitor interview, Dr Radford said:

If a worker actually got five rems in a year for 30 years, a total of 150 rems, I believe that would more than double his or her chance of getting cancer in their lifetime and since the chance of getting cancer is about 30 per cent, each of us has about a 30 per cent chance of getting cancer in our lifetime, being exposed to that much radiation would lead to perhaps a 60 per cent chance of getting cancer in one's lifetime which I think is too much.

In summing up, I say that Australia could play a part in nuclear technology and in the nuclear industry if this Government and conservative State governments had the will and had concern for future generations at heart. The International Commission for Radiation Protection should be called on to study immediately the recent findings of these American scientists. The safety standards in all aspects of the nuclear industry need urgent revision as the findings of these scientists have shown. Australia should be pressing strongly for the ICRP to make a review of the international safety standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity presented by the first reading of the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) to revert to a topic that I raised in this chamber before Christmas. I do this in the light of further information that has become available in the development of that public debate. I refer, of course, to the proposition that the Royal Australian Navy has before the Government at present to buy an aircraft carrier to replace HMAS Melbourne. This is a very large cost for the Australian community to bear. Not only is it an expensive thing to buy, but also it is something which dictates the pattern of maritime response that is possible for Australia to make for possibly 20 years ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I restate the basic premise on which our defence is based and that is that we have to look after ourselves, particularly in a post-Vietnam ' Guam doctrine' era. A corollary of looking after ourselves is, of course, that we get value for the very limited amount of money that the Australian taxpayer has to spend on defence purchases. Formerly, the Australian forces always saw themselves as supporting what we euphemistically referred to as their great and powerfull friends or allies. But in the post-Vietnam era we have to look after ourselves and rely on our own resources in times of need. There is a public expectation that we will be able to do this. It is quite remarkable to look at the shift in public appreciations of defence that have taken place post-Vietnam. If I dare say it before my learned colleagues, I think the public expectation exceeds the political recognition of it. I think one can see in the Services- certainly in the Air Force and the Army-a movement towards an Australia first concept.

The argument for a carrier really has to be addressed on the basis of whether we really need it. If there is a case to be made for it, is it the most cost- effective way of providing it with respect to our other priorities?
