I will not go through in detail the argument that the Navy made, which I mentioned in my previous speech, as to why the Navy thinks we need this carrier-the convoy protection, the anti-submarine warfare, tactical air power at sea, command and control and all the minor things like brushfire wars, diplomatic showing of the flag, emergency relief programs and that sort of thing.

I emphasise the point that we really are not talking about a carrier at all here; we are talking about a small ship and a ship that, in many ways, is not as capable, operationally, as HMAS Melbourne, the ship that it is designed to replace. That is an entirely different matter from getting emotionally involved in talking about the needs for a carrier for Australia. I have an absolutely open mind about the need for a carrier for Australia. I can see that there is a very good argument for tactical air power at sea. My only concern about a carrier for Australia is how survivable it is in an age of sea-skimming missiles and of missile technology in general. I will come back to that in a few minutes and look a few miles down the track as to what is going to happen technologically. If we have a case for a carrier, for goodness sake let us buy one and not buy a toy that will not do the job. I have no time at all for my colleagues, either in my own party or on the other side of this chamber, who worry about the cost. What price is freedom? We cannot measure it. We can afford the defence systems in this country that we need to protect ourselves.

I want to spend a little time looking at the tactical air requirement because this is the basis of why the present proposition is unacceptable. Tactical air, or in the jargon of the Navy organic air power at sea, means providing fixed wing aircraft with the ability to do certain things-to fulfil two broad groups of functions; an aggressive function and a search function. Of course, the aggressive function is the air superiority business of controlling the air space over the fleet by airborne means. That means seeing off unfriendly aircraft; fighters as well as maritime reconnaisance aircraft. It also means the ability to mount an air strike capacity. In naval aircraft those two functions are usually discharged by the one aircraft. With the search function, of course, there is a maritime reconnaisance phase, and that capacity may be mediated by the aircraft used in the aggressive role. Certainly an airborne early warning capacity is needed so radar horizons are extended out beyond that dictated by the seaborne radar.

In an anti-submarine role some anti-submarine capacity is needed which means using a different type of aircraft from that category in the former class. All anti-submarine warfare is a combination, a complex of various detection sensors. The truth of the matter is that on the type of ship we are talking about, the Invincible or the American LPH class which were looked at last year and the year before, it is not possible to embark any airborne early warning or ASW type fixed wing aircraft because they are too big to fit on that little 300-foot flight deck. The only type of aircraft possible to put on it are the short take- off and vertical landing aircraft. Operationally their performance is so limited and likely to be so limited from a developmental point in the future that effectively one would have no tactical air power at sea. The only aircraft that operate or exist in the world today in this category are the British Aerospace Sea Harrier and the American McDonnell-Douglas AV8B which is going to Patuxent River for its prototype trials in March and April of this year. It is very much a developmental aircraft at present.

The Sea Harrier is marketed as a fighter but it simply does not have the capacity to survive against anything in the post-Korean war era. It is a very slow fighter. It is a subsonic fighter and is slow to accelerate. One of its biggest disabilities is the fact that it does not have an adequate air fighting radar. I see Senator Tate sitting in the chamber. He will remember the long lectures I gave him a year or two ago on the characteristics of airborne air superiority radars. The radar does not have the capacity to get into the business today. It is designed for infrared weapons systems, the Sidewinder, short range-five nautical miles-air to air missile. Most critically it is short on its look-down capacity-its ability to discriminate from on height low flying fast aircraft. Because it is limited in its radar capacity it is also limited in its strike role, the identification of difficult targets under difficult weather conditions. It suffers very severely from a range and pay load limitation. There are certain various unfortunate aerodynamic quirks with that aircraft as well.

The AV8B is built for the Marine Corps and is purely a strike weapon. It has no radar in it at all. It is not an air fighter in any way. It is a very much better aircraft than the Sea Harrier and it should never be confused with it, although it looks the same to the uninformed eye. In many ways it is roughly twice as good when looked at with respect to payload-range combination. It is exclusively a strike aircraft at present. While there are proposals to develop it in the future as a fighter with some limited ability, none of that has been funded yet. We are looking at a time that may be 10 years down the track and certainly quite a few hundreds of millions of dollars in developmental costs. These are costs which Australia would have to pay if it wanted to move into that field. Effectively we would be denied any modern fixed wing strike aircraft on the type of ship we are talking about.

The Navy case seems to have moved away from this requirement to the anti- submarine warfare capacity. That is a stronger case for the Navy to make but it is also a very limited case. As you, Mr Acting Deputy President would know, because these ships embark the Sea King which is a helicopter operating a dunking sonar. These helicopters do not operate all that far out from the ship- maybe up to 20 nautical miles. This is an active sonar system which ranges from as low as 1,000 yards up to maybe three to four nautical miles. It is a very useful tool but it is part of a whole system of arrays and sensors that the fleet needs for anti-submarine detection. The important point is that those helicopters can be mounted on other platforms. They do not need a very expensive pseudo aircraft carrier to carry them. They can be carried and launched off other platforms. Of course, their main requirement is for some communications data-link system so the whole of the tactical picture can be integrated. The great weakness of this kind of ship apart from the technical shortcomings I have listed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, what is the data link story on the Invincible? There have been conflicting reports in the Press recently.

—My belief is that the data link systems fitted to HMS Invincible are more than adequate for all present and future requirements of the Australian Navy. I do not think there are any problems at all in that field. From a defensive point of view we are operating in a missile age. Surface missiles and if we consider the guided torpedoes now in existence as missiles, operate over very great ranges. Classically defence against them is to get to the launch platform and not to try to put a screen between the released missile and the target. We are looking now at torpedoes. The Russian equivalents of the Mark 48 torpedo have ranges well in excess of 20 nautical miles. That means we have to be able to get beyond that to detect the platform. The big threat is the sea skimming missiles. Since 1959 when Russian Styx missiles were used to destroy that Egyptian destroyer in Elait things have moved at a very rapid rate. The sea skimming missile is a very difficult weapon to detect and to destroy. It is moving at nearly sonic speed and is a very small target. It is a relatively cheap system as opposed to the target that it is trying to destroy. Most importantly, because it is cheap, it is possible to multiply the missiles. The defensive systems can be quite simply overwhelmed. Cutting a long story short, the initiative rests very strongly with the attacker at present. I have been to every seminar the Navy has put on since I entered Parliament and I have studied the case as assiduously as I can. I say this with the greatest regret but I think the senior levels of the Royal Australian Navy fail to appreciate the revolution in weapon systems technology which has taken place at sea. I think this tragic in respect of the purchase of very large capital ships.

SPEECH.PARA: What worries me is looking ahead five or 10 years down the track and seeing missiles that have very much better target acquisition systems. They will possibly be moving at three times the speed of sound. They will incorporate radar stealth technology and so will be very hard to find. We will be looking at a situation where it will be very hard to stay alive on top of the water. That is what concerns me. We are not buying a ship for 1982 or 1984; we are buying a ship that will play an essential part in the defence of Australia in 1990 and 1995. It is no good having a symbol. We have to have something that has got teeth and that will threaten someone if we ourselves are threatened. Believe me, the military analysts of any of the potential aggressors of this country will not be deterred by a little bit of Navy PR.

The point is that given all these short-comings how can the Navy proceed with the purchase of the ship. People say that the United States Navy uses the Iwo Jima class and the Royal Navy is building three of this type of ship for its use . The important thing that was hammered into me last month in London by defence experts there was that the Royal Navy ship was built always to operate under land based air cover, to provide air superiority, to provide the air strike capacity when needed and to provide the ASW and AEW capacity. It was built to operate primarily, but not exclusively, in the North Sea under land based air cover. When it was not operating in that mode it was built to operate as part of a major fleet system where the other ships of the fleet gave it the protection that it inherently lacked itself. That is a really crucial point because what the Royal Australian Navy wants to do with this ship is make it the capital ship , the centre point of a task force concept. It was never designed to do that. We cannot make a silk purse out of a sow's ear.

If we need a carrier at all we should go to the Americans and say: 'Look, you are concerned about regional defence. It is a concept we support. Give us a ship , one of those Oriskany-class that are in reserve. We will man it and operate it for 10 years'. We can avoid the capital cost in that way. Having talked extensively to American State Department people and people in the United States Navy last month, I do not think that is an impossible thing to do. If we did that we could get a ship which would fulfil all the functions that Navy wants it to fulfil. We could lay off the increased running costs against the lack of a capital cost and embark something like the F18s which we are buying for the RAAF and achieve considerable savings in the defence budget by having a common strike and air superiority fighter. But that is only if a case exists for a carrier.

Let me look at the cost of this ship because there has been a great deal of misrepresentation as to the true cost of this weapons system. We are not buying a ship; we are buying a weapons system. Figures of $200m to $300m have been floating around. The latest figure that I have been able to get for the cost of getting the ship here, without aircraft, will be of the order of $477m, nearly $ 500m. Once we have it we must put aircraft on it. We will have to put ASW helicopters on it and at some time in the future short take-off and vertical landing aircraft. At the moment the Government's position is that it has no intention to buy short take-off and landing aircraft. That is about as silly as buying a gun and not having any ammunition. Inevitably, if we buy the ship we will have to buy short take-off and vertical landing aircraft because they are the only sort of aircraft that will fit on the ship and Navy will want some fixed wing aircraft to fly. If we do that we are looking at a cost of $12m to $ 15m at least for the Sea King helicopters. If Navy becomes ambitious and wants the Lamps III ASW helicopters they will be in excess of $30m a copy. But the AV8B-this is purely my estimate and I will be happy to see how it works out in time-will end up coming on the market at a price considerably in excess of the F18. I do not believe that we will buy the AV8Bs at a figure under $30m a copy. The equipment fit for that comes to about $700m for helicopters and fixed wing aircraft. If we add that to about $500m for the carrier and a few other things along the line we are looking at a project cost, five or six years down the line , of $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the vessels to protect the carrier too?

—That is the other thing. We will be committing the whole of the Australian fleet-the four FFGs that we are getting and one or two of the DDGs plus the fleet supply ships-just to maintain this carrier. We will have lost all flexibility and diversity in the maritime defence capacity of this country. I would rather leave that matter at the moment because I wish to finish .

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, I do not mind spending $1.2 billion or $1.5 billion if it will do a job and keep this country safe. What I object to is paying that sort of money just for symbolism. Having fairly and dispassionately looked at Navy's case over the years, I do not believe that it has established that what it wants to do with this ship for Australia cannot be done by alternative weapons systems . I believe it has failed to appreciate what is going on in modern weapons systems. The sole justification for buying this ship seems to me to be greed, and the greed relates to the very low price at which the hull is placed on the market. The figure of around $300m is irresistable to the Navy at present because everything it has been looking at has cost $600m or $700m. I do not believe that that is a good enough argument for buying this ship for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first came into this institution I was unaware of the excitement that could be engendered both in here and in the other place by State elections. However, shortly before the New South Wales election it became very apparent that these Houses of Parliament would be used as a forum to try to influence the end result. As the election got nearer the Government's frenetic activities, in trying to downgrade the Wran Government in New South Wales, became more and more apparent. I am somewhat doubtful about their effectiveness given the result in New South Wales, but I fear that with the coming Victorian election we will see a similar situation develop. Already on two occasions last week Dorothy Dix questions were asked about the power supply situation in the various States, in particular New South Wales because of the problems it is having at present. Inferred throughout was that the Victorian Government had managed its power supplies with admirable administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I put on record the real situation in Victoria regarding power production and what the prospects are. Prior to 1980 the State Electricity Commission of Victoria was regarded as a very secure and effective public authority. It had been founded by Sir John Monash in the 1920s, based on Victoria's brown coal reserves, and there had been very few problems with it in its 50 to 60 years of existence. But in November 1980 the then Leader of the Opposition, Frank Wilkes, and his shadow Minister Derek Amos, based on Treasury documents, suggested possible power shortages in the winter of 1981 and that the SEC was near bankruptcy.

The reaction of the Victorian Liberal Government was immediately to call them scaremongers. It said they had got their facts wrong and were just trying to scare the public. Of course by May and June 1981 these claims were refuted by the fact that there were serious power shortages because of breakdowns at Hazelwood and a water shortage because of a drought in the Snowy River system. The breakdowns then occurring in Victoria were far worse than those being suffered by New South Wales at the moment. Many, many thousands of people were stood down, industry leaders were very critical of the Government at the time. The result was that the then Premier, Mr Hamer, who was overseas seeking foreign investment, was absolutely cut to pieces by his own party. It is a rather remarkable fact that one of Premier Hamer's main qualities was to show loyalty to his Ministers and supporters in State parliament. Ministers, who had been involved in the biggest land scandals in Australian history, were able to survive and not be dismissed from office. But the moment it was perceived that Dick Hamer would be a loser or could not handle the situation, he was cut to pieces and replaced by his loyal deputy of 11 years.

What is the situation regarding the Victorian power supply? Firstly, let us look at prices. In November 1980, after a 14.9 per cent increase, the Government promised no more increases for 12 months. That is 14.9 per cent compared with an inflation rate then of 8 per cent to 9 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that for domestic consumers or industrial consumers?

—There was a 14.9 per cent increase across the board. The Victorian Government promised there would be no more increases for 12 months. However 10 months later in August the SEC presented the Government with a fait accompli. There was a price increase of 19.7 per cent plus a consumer surcharge of $6 a month-$18 a quarter. The SEC disregarded its obligations to the Government and imposed a surcharge retrospectively to August 1981. It was only after immense public reaction that it set the figure from November on. The 19.7 per cent increase was not even across the board. Small consumers had to pay $6 a month surcharge plus 5.38c a kilowatt hour. In reality, for anyone who consumed only 200 kilowatt hours a month that worked out to a 42 per cent increase. Senator Carrick and others say that we must conserve our energy position. Yet the situation in Victoria is that whoever consumes less electricity in fact pays a higher rate. The more electricity a person consumes in Victoria, the cheaper it becomes. We had public meetings all over Melbourne in places such as Heidelberg, Flemington and Sunshine to protest about these charges. Normally at these sorts of protest meetings one gets only a small amount of people coming forward. At these meetings, literally thousands of people came forward to protest at these charges. So the situation in Victoria is that we have had an increase of over 14 per cent and an increase of over 19 per cent. Compare the inflation rate of maybe 18 per cent with a 33 per cent jump in power prices in two years.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to compare the situation in Victoria and New South Wales. In January and February this year the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, and the State Premier, Mr Thompson, claimed that the Victorian power supply was superior to that of New South Wales and that 1,400 megawatts had been added since June 1981 when we had the power problems. The reality is, of course, that 1,100 megawatts was already in the system; it simply had not been commissioned. The plaque had not been opened. They were already in the system when the power breakdowns occurred. New South Wales currently has restrictions but in the long term the projects that it has on the board will mean that in future it will have far less problems than Victoria. The only real increase in Victoria has been the Yallourn W4 which produces 375 megawatts. The increased demand since June 1981 has been to that extent and will continue at a rate of 7 per cent for the next few years. The position of the SEC, therefore, is worse now than it was in May 1981. The refurbishing of the plant at Hazelwood has not yet been completed. Breakdowns at Hazelwood, still the key to the Victorian power system, will be much worse in 1982 than previously.

There was a lot of speculation about the date of the Victorian election. One of the main reasons for not holding it on the most popular date, 29 May, was fear of future power shortages, not necessarily the fact that home interest rates were going up. When we look at the financial position of the State Electricity Commission of Victoria we find that the capital works program, Loy Yang A-the first set is due in May 1984-and Loy Yang B and the power line to the Portland aluminium smelter, will cost $820m. The Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Howard ) and John Stone from the Department of the Treasury have let the SEC raise only $300m to $350m from domestic sources in the financial year 1981-82. Therefore, the SEC has to raise somewhere between $470m and $520m if it is to survive. It has followed about four different ways in trying to make up the shortfall. It has obtained authority to borrow money overseas. It has already investigated Middle East sources but that does not seem politically popular so it has had to give that away. It will now have to go into the short term money market, at exorbitant interest rates, to cover the shortfall. The second thing it is doing is selling its assets. Its coal dredgers and open cuts are being sold and the one big building which it owns in the city, Monash House, is also up for sale. It has also encouraged contractor financing of power stations; that is, partial private financing of essential utilities on the basis that the SEC will meet the cash when it is able to do so. Finally, it has reduced the country customers connection rebate from $2,700, repayable over 10 years, to $800 payable over eight years.

The increase in country connection costs indicates the SEC's hypocrisy. The SEC claims that tariff increases should be consumer price index based but it wants to increase internal revenue for capital works by 20 per cent to 50 per cent. With massive expansion, these objectives are mutually exclusive. The Loan Council restrictions mean that a 15 per cent to 20 per cent tariff increase is imminent otherwise the SEC will not be able to meet its building commitment. Australian Ratings indicate that the SEC, rated at AA-, which is unique for a guaranteed utility, is close to bankruptcy.

I come now to the final power problem in Victoria which is the Alcoa smelter. I did not get up tonight to suggest that the Alcoa smelter should never have gone ahead. But it is very interesting to see the way in which negotiations have developed between Alcoa and the Victorian Government. In October 1978 the State Development, Decentralization and Tourism Department prepared a Cabinet submission for Mr Digby Crozier on the location of the new aluminium smelter. It was a superficial cost-benefit study motivated by the Government's need to produce a decision for the 1979 election. We have a history in Victoria once a State election is announced for a vast number of projects to be announced, be it the arts centre or the roofing of the railways, which has come up every three years in the last 20 years. There is always a new plan to roof the railways. I doubt whether the State Government will try that trick again but it is usually a good one because it gets onto the front page of the Melbourne Herald.

A substantial cost-benefit study by John Stanley was not completed until 1979, after the State election. At that stage Alcoa and the State Government had already decided to go ahead with Portland. The decision was made. It was a political decision made without the advantage of a cost-benefit study. The 1978 submission by Mr Crozier did not include detailed discussion of the economic impact on Victoria. It also did not look at the environmental impact, the appropriate tariffs or the effect on the Aboriginal community in that area and the sacred grounds involved. Alcoa appreciated the slackness and agreed, just before the 1979 election, actually to build it. It did not appreciate, however, the instability that existed within the SEC. Alcoa was guaranteed an exemption from turnover tax for 10 years and was charged only 21 per cent of the cost of the power line to Portland.

In September 1981 the Government announced an inquiry into the Alcoa tariff, which was to be increased by 25 per cent to 2.4c a kilowatt hour. Honourable senators should remember that domestic consumers are paying over 5c a kilowatt hour. The situation was that Alcoa had made its plans. The State Government had promised it a set tariff. In turn, the SEC, realising that unless it wanted every other consumer in Victoria to subsidise that, had to put up Alcoa's tariff . There have been at least two inquiries into the tariff. At first Professor Cochrane from Monash University was asked to handle it. He looked at all the problems and really could not come up with a solution other than stopping the Alcoa project. In typical fashion the Victorian Government then commissioned another accountant's report. It in turn came up with some fairly wishy-washy conclusions. Nevertheless, the project has gone ahead and this means the Victorian consumers will have to subsidise the Alcoa program.

Alcoa does not intend to start using electricity until the winter of 1983. But the first set at Loy Yang must not really come on stream, at the earliest, until 1984 and, given all the normal sorts of delays, it will come on a lot later. The implication for the Victorian power system is that it will have to take peak load stations, such as the gas fired Newport turbine, and run them as normal stations at a cost of something like 3.5c a kilowatt hour. To run Alcoa at Portland will cost in gas terms 3.5c a kilowatt hour for an electricity charge to Alcoa of 2.4c a kilowatt hour.

That is the situation of the Victorian power system. It is a very sad one. The system is an absolute mess. I hope that ministers and others in this place will refrain from pointing just to New South Wales without referring to Victoria in some sort of detail. I am not sure that over the next few weeks we will have a repeat of the sort of tactics used in this Parliament when a State election is due. I would have thought that the Federal Liberal Party is losing its taste for the fight in Victoria. It butted in last week without very much success. Already this week three Liberal Ministers have told Mr Fraser to keep out of the Victorian election. They have not done that because they particularly dislike Mr Fraser but because they regard him as a liability in that area. In addition, they are trying to use the tactic of attacking an unpopular Federal Government in the belief that they will be all right themselves.

The main person who has led that campaign is the Minister of Housing in Victoria. I have referred to him before in this place. He has said to the Prime Minister that he should 'put up' or 'shut up'. This same individual, Mr Kennett, has been storming all around Victoria about a housing policy. He has announced a lot of new initiatives, most of which will really come to nothing. It was very interesting to read in this morning's newspaper the truth about Mr Kennett and his housing policies. Honourable senators should remember that he has consistently attacked the Federal Liberal Government for its activity over housing. He has consistently blasted the Prime Minister over interest rates. He has consistently attacked the Federal Government over welfare housing. But this morning there was a leak relating to a report from Mr T. Kneebone, General Manager, Development and Property, in this area of housing. The newspaper report I have states:
The leaked memo is dated February 12, only six days before Mr Kennett was reported as saying that the Department of Housing was 'the most efficient in the (State) Public Service'.
This memo came out at about the time when Mr Kennett was claiming that his Department was the most efficient in the State Public Service. The article continues:
The multiplied form-filling and explaining of what we are meant to be doing actually prevents us from doing what we are meant to be doing . . .

In other words, the Victorian Housing Minister and others are all running around telling everyone what they are going to do and what they should be doing, but they are doing absolutely nothing. The article continues:
Staff of the division are heartily sick and tired of being prevented from doing real work because of what they see as multiplied gobbledegook . . .

Regarding the housing situation in Victoria, the State Housing Minister is far worse than anything we have in the Federal sphere. He has done absolutely nothing to relieve the situation in Victoria. A fund of $1m has been established which was supposed to relieve the pressure of interest rates and repayments. The reality, as the Treasurer has said, is that any scheme that is to work will cost in the order of $1,000m and above. The Government has spent something like $300, 000 or $400,000 on advertising the scheme which has only $1m allocated to it to help people who are in trouble in Victoria. The memo leaked this morning shows that Mr Kennett is a fraud when it comes to housing policies and that he has failed to do anything about housing in Victoria. The next time he tells the Prime Minister or anyone else from the Federal Liberal Party to put up or shut up, he would be exposed for what he is; that is, a publicity seeker, someone who only wants to see his photo in the paper, someone who only wants to see his now marginal State seat safe for himself.

I hope that that situation warns honourable senators opposite that it may be best to leave the State election where it belongs, that is, in the State field. As I said initially, we have had a couple of Dorothy Dix questions on power and other matters. I expect that after the Lowe by-election has passed the Victorian election will get a great airing in this place. When the people go to the defence of the Victorian Government I hope they will realise just how bad the situation is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening on the sales tax Bills on behalf of the many people of Queensland and, I believe, also of many Australians. I have not changed my previous feelings about this tax on the people of our country, nor on the consequences that such a tax would have on the average Australian family and pensioner. At the beginning of the sales tax argument I stated that when the Budget was brought down last year a tax on the so-called necessities of life would hit those in our community least able to afford it, namely, the family and the pensioners-the very areas that we should be encouraging. I was, and still am, opposed to the decision to direct this revenue raising effort in the direction of those two vulnerable areas. From all the mail, telephone calls, telegrams and personal representations that have come through my office since the Budget was brought down I have been left in no doubt whatsoever that the people of Queensland and, indeed, of Australia do not want, and certainly do not need, a further tax burden such as the sales tax promised to be.
—And they cannot afford it either.

—I would say that some of the people on fixed incomes, lower incomes and the pensioners certainly cannot afford it. Like everybody else , I had hoped that the Government would see fit to offset some of the effects of the sales tax with reductions in personal income tax. However, it does not seem as though that relief will be forthcoming at present. No one would criticise the Government's desire to reduce the deficit. The $300m or so that the increases in indirect taxes would have raised would have helped to achieve this. Indeed, I think that that would have helped eventually to give good tax cuts. My objection lies in the areas at which these cost cutting measures are directed; that is, the family and the pensioners in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that there are many areas where the Government could perhaps have shown some restraint in further expenditure without having to rely so heavily on indirect taxation. I think too of the emergence of the crude oil levy which during the 1979-80 financial year raised approximately $2,227m and during the 1980-81 year raised over $3,000m. Even taking into consideration the industrial strife in Bass Strait, which the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) was speaking about this morning, and the resultant reduction in revenue, surely a source of this magnitude could have helped to finance major reforms in the tax structure. However, there is a lot to be said for a government that acknowledges its capabilities and consequently tries to live within its means both domestically and at an international level. I appreciate that our Government is trying to do this.

When I listen to the Australian Labor Party people talking about what they would or would not do to fix the deficit, I think back to some of the years when they were in power. It is rather hypocritical that they should talk in this way because they did not do so well themselves. However, I believe that the Government expenditure, which this tax was to provide the revenue for, was perhaps too optimistic. It would seem from the recent statements of the Treasurer reported in the newspapers and broadcast over the air that the Government deficit will be significantly higher than was predicted at the time of the Budget. The Australian taxpayer is carrying a heavy tax burden despite the fact that the Government has said that, compared with overseas countries, we are a low tax nation. However, when people do not want to work or when they do not want to do overtime-they say: 'Well, most of the money that we make will have to go to pay tax anyway'-I think we must be paying too much tax. Such a situation is damaging not only to the individual's work incentive but also to the economy. That is being proved daily.

The Government has made it quite clear that the sales tax Bills are an integral part of the Budget strategy and, as such, cannot be excluded. As government members we accept that approach. Perhaps the Budget brought down last year by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was too optimistic, relied too heavily on revenue raising from taxation and put too much emphasis on expenditure in certain areas. For instance, the Government has to come to grips with our social security bill. In just seven years the cost of supporting parents benefits alone has risen from $40m to $800m. Social security spending comprises 28 per cent of the Budget's total outlays. The Australian taxpayer is not only footing this enormous bill but he is also, perhaps unwittingly, contributing to the emergence of a hand-out feeling in this country. This is a problem which governments will have to deal with unless something is done to control it now. It has a snowballing effect. Very large sums of money are going out in welfare and unemployment payments. We have to accept the position that people want more wages and more social security benefits but they want to pay less tax.
One matter I have mentioned quite often around Queensland and in other States too is that I feel people who get dole payments should have to do a few days work a week for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about giving them some work to do?
—I have been trying to suggest that it might be a good idea. Some of the local authorities in our area in Queensland have said that they would be quite happy to try to do something about it.
—How about giving them full time work? That is what they want.
—When the jobs are available I am sure that that is what will happen.
—You persuade Malcolm to give them a bit more money and then they will get jobs.

—First of all, we have to make sure that they do a little work for what they are getting. That is the point I am trying to put over . Part of the answer to this very serious problem, I believe, lies in helping to create the right economic climate which encourages work, growth and productivity , employment and consumption. This is what will happen shortly. These are all the economic indicators which help to make a healthy economy and ultimately, therefore, a happy and prosperous nation of people. I will suggest to honourable senators a way in which I feel we can get on with this job. I think we should overhaul our whole taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken before in this place about the flat rate of taxation which the National Party in Queensland has been proposing for some time. I have not, unfortunately, had very much success convincing Mr Howard that this is a goer. Despite the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) having a joke about it all on 1 April last, I still have not been able to get it through to Mr Howard that it is a good idea, but I do not intend to give up just yet. As the present system stands the average Australian is being taxed at the marginal rate of either 32 per cent or 46 per cent. This is the result of the tax drag or the tax drift which means that through inflation wages go into higher and higher brackets. Total taxable incomes for the 1980-81 year were in excess of $82 billion and the tax collections from them were more than $17 billion. A flat rate of tax on the basis of the 20 per cent proposed by our party would raise $16 billion subject to concessions to those supporting families on low incomes. A $1 billion shortfall is a rather large amount of money. I think that instead of a 20 per cent flat rate of tax a 25 per cent flat rate of tax should have been proposed. That would bring in $21 billion. I feel that that would really help. The tax base would in fact be increased with less tax avoidance and tax evasion and greater economic activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Senator Walsh has not come up with anything better.
—All the tax dodgers who are paying no tax now are not going magnanimously to make donations because you introduce some flat earth taxation, you silly old bag.

—At least it is a way to try. This reduction in tax evasion, I feel, is just one of the many advantages of a flat rate of tax. Dr Ian Spry, Q.C., the editor of the Australian Tax Review, has outlined some other advantages of a flat tax. First, the tax drift would be prevented.
—Rubbish!

—Senator Walsh seems to think it is rubbish. I do not know whether he sets himself up to be more important than Dr Ian Spry. I have not noticed that Senator Walsh has done much about it. The tax drift would be prevented.
—He is not so important.

—I ask Senator Keeffe to let me get on with my speech; I have not interrupted anybody else. Future increases in earnings would be taxed at the rate of only 20 per cent instead of 32 per cent or 46 per cent. I feel that the advantage to wage earners is incalculable. Honourable senators cannot tell me that if they had in their pockets 75c or 80c out of every dollar they would dig a hole in the ground and bury it. They would not; they would spend it or invest it so that the money would be able to circulate. Employment opportunities would be improved. I feel that employers would retain a larger proportion of profits for purchasing plant, for expansion and for increasing employment. Government expenditure would not be funded by the tax drift. The income tax revenue would still rise, but it would rise only in proportion to actual increases in incomes in real terms. Individuals would be less reliant on governments. Under the present system it is difficult, to a very large degree, for individuals to save sufficient for their old age or to improve their financial position.

SPEECH.PARA: The progressive tax system tends to prevent individuals from improving themselves financially. Is it worth while for a person who earns, say, $250 a week to suffer great inconvenience by working long hours in an attempt to improve his position so that he might make $350 a week? A lot of the increase would then be taken in tax. Incentives for investments and earnings would be increased. I think that is important too. The attractiveness of overtime earnings and of the rewards for additional work effort clearly would be increased substantially. Another important thing, which Senator Walsh pooh- poohed before is that tax evasion and tax avoidance would be dramatically decreased because it would not be worth while evading tax if one had to pay only 25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not paying tax at all now. Why should they pay tax afterwards? The maximum marginal rate has not been lowered for 40 years and tax evasion has never been greater.
—I do not think that the Australian Labor Party did much about fixing up tax evasion when it was in power.
—We passed eight amendments to the legislation in three years.

—The benefit to the Australian worker of paying a flat 20 per cent or 25 per cent in tax speaks for itself. Critics of flat tax have misrepresented the plight of the ordinary worker and taxpayer. They have concealed the effects of tax drift and the fact that he will, subject to tax indexation, lose 32 per cent or 46 per cent of each dollar under the present system. I feel it is vital to the future of this nation and those who live in it that we develop a taxation system which is more in keeping with the Australian worker's assessment of a fair and equitable distribution of the tax burden. I have no doubt whatever that continuing tax slugs will kill whatever incentive is left in the heart of the Australian worker. I urge the Government in all sincerity and with all urgency to take the burden off the Australian taxpayer either by having a complete overhaul of the taxation system such as the proposal I have just been talking about or by having a realistic approach to government expenditure and priorities. If it is good enough for the average Australian family to have to live within its means it is good enough for the Government of the nation to do the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention to use this first reading debate this evening to outline a small but blatant fraud which is being conducted by a Brisbane mail order organisation. The fact that I shall be referring to only one product which it advertises makes the fraud no less significant. This organisation is not only defrauding people in Brisbane or in other parts of Queensland; it is operating nation-wide. My intentions tonight are to alert the public to the activities of this firm. My aims are to ensure that fewer people will be duped, that advertisements lodged by this firm will no longer be accepted and that the names of reputable mail order firms will no longer be besmirched by this organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Before informing the Senate of the activities of this organisation I shall mention some factors in defence of those who use the mail order system even though they are not aware of the bona fides of the firms to which they forward their money. Many residents of rural areas do not have the opportunity to do personal shopping. Being a long way from major shopping centres they are naturally attracted by alluring advertisements which describe goods available through the mail. For people in these areas reputable mail order firms fulfil a real need. It is a tragedy, however, that crooked firms exist which prey on those who trust them to send the goods for which customers forward their money. If the goods are forwarded, the customers trust that when they arrive they will be what was anticipated.

I expect that in this session of Parliament I shall mention organisations other than the one I will speak about this evening. Many of my constituents have contacted me about other dubious firms. Tonight, however, I shall concentrate on this one firm. Advertisements for this firm invite consumers-'entice' might be a better word-to write to June Taylor at post office box 318, Spring Hill, Queensland 4000. I am not aware whether 'June Taylor' is a registered business name, but if necessary this could be easily established. Suffice it to say that I do not believe that a June Taylor has anything to do with this firm. I have received a letter from a purported June Taylor and I shall say something about that later. I understand that the person who either manages this organisation or has a close association with it is Mr Robert Clark of the Brisbane suburb of The Gap. I believe that Mr Clark is associated with a number of other enterprises which operate from post office boxes at Spring Hill.

I first became aware of this organisation when I read about it in the Brisbane Sunday newspaper, Sunday Sun. A reader complained that he had been duped by an advertisement which was obviously the one to which I shall refer. My attention was next brought to this matter when my colleague Senator McLaren contacted me on behalf of one of his South Australian constituents. As the firm concerned was based in Brisbane I was quite happy to see what I could do for Senator McLaren's constituent who had, in fact, responded to the advertisement. At this stage I should mention the advertisement for the goods which 'June Taylor' is selling. This advertisement has featured in otherwise respectable national magazines. For example, it was carried on page 59 of the Australian Women's Weekly of 18 November 1981 and on page 162 of the Family Circle of 15 January 1982. I will take the opportunity of tabling a copy of the advertisement. Part of the advertisement reads:
100 LITTLE DOLLS ALL FOR $19.95
Baby Dolls-Dancing Dolls-Ballerina Dolls-Indian Dolls-Cowboy Dolls-Nurse Dolls- Costume Dolls-Mexican Dolls-Clown Dolls-Bride Dolls-Groom Dolls and many more.

Don't shake your head in disbelief! This is TRUE! For only 19 CENTS EACH you can give that little girl the most thrilling present of her life. This set of ONE HUNDRED DOLLS for only $19.95-Just nearly 20c a piece!

The wonder of this unprecedented offer is that every doll is made from beautiful high quality Styrene plastic and hard synthetic rubber. You get BABY DOLLS, NURSE DOLLS, DANCING DOLLS, FOREIGN DOLLS, CLOWN DOLLS, COWBOY DOLLS, BRIDE DOLLS and many more in lilliputian cuteness. Your daughter or niece or the cute child next door will love you for this gift. What a family for a little girl! Just think of it, 100 exquisite little dolls in beautiful high-impact styrene plastic and hard synthetic rubber at this unbelievable price!

So fill out the coupon below. Order as many sets as you have little girls to give them to. Enclose $19.95 for each 100 dollsets you order. And even at this amazing bargain you take no risk over this bargain; just read our guarantee opposite.
Available at this special price by Mail Order only.

Then the advertisement goes on and describes where to send the money-to 'June Taylor', Box 318, Post Office, Spring Hill. It even suggests that although one set cost $19.95 one can get two sets for $39, three sets for $57 and four sets for $75. There is no cash on delivery. A customer should allow 14 days for his or her cheque to be cleared. If one wants the dolls airmailed the price is another $1 per extra set. The guarantee is mentioned in this advertisement. I will read what this guarantee says. As I read it honourable senators will realise that the guarantee is absolutely worthless. The guarantee reads:
Our GuaranteeHERE IS WHAT THESEDOLLS ARE MADE OF

People seeing our ad and not believing we can give such value write us to ask what our 100 Dolls are made of. 'Are they paper dolls or rag dolls?' they ask. NEITHER! Each and every one of are 100 dolls is made of GENUINE STYRENE and SYNTHETIC RUBBER expensively moulded.
Every doll has come out of an individual mould manufactured out of high impact styrene to resist breakage and is life-like in its proportions. They are truly delightful dolls!

Obviously, that guarantee does not mean anything. I suppose that one should really ask how could one expect to obtain 100 little dolls for $19.95. But the advertisement is so enticing that obviously some people would consider it too good an offer to miss. After all, who would not like to have their daughter, their niece or their cute child next door love them for this gift? So, off goes $19.95 and despite the keen anticipation back comes a load of junk. I illustrate to honourable senators what those 100 dolls are like. I have one of them which in the old measurement is about 1 1/4 inches high--

TALK.START.PARA: —We need a telescope to see it from here.

—Yes, indeed. Honourable senators opposite do need a telescope to be able to see it. That is an indication of how small the dolls are. I have another one which is probably a quarter of a centimetre higher than the other one. Again it is just a little bit of junk that is very hard to see. These are examples of the 100 dolls that are so alluringly advertised. They are what people get back.
—Mrs Auricht wasn't too pleased with them, Senator.

—The honourable senator's constituent certainly was not too pleased with them. A lot of people throughout Australia have not been pleased with them. I read a description of these articles in a letter which was kindly brought to my notice by the Australian Consumers Association, the publishers of Choice. I consider that that description should be brought to the attention of the Senate because it is an excellent description of these little trinkets that are sent. I quote a section of the letter of which this description was a part. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: On inspecting the goods we must entirely agree with Mrs ...... comments and would go even further to describe the goods as being rubbish. In our opinion they do not even remotely fit the description outlined in the advertisement. They are cheap plastic figures of the type one would find in cereal cartons, indeed a count of the figures reveals that 47 of them are models of the human figure the remaining 53 being models of various kinds of animals. Incidentally the Concise Oxford Dictionary defines doll as being a 'small model of human figure ...'. They are exceptionally small-the smallest human figure being 25mm and the smallest animal figure 15mm. Not only poor value but because of their small size potentially hazardous to small children.

Naturally, when people receive dolls nobody expects to get the money back if he or she indicates dissatisfaction. In fact, I tried to obtain the money back for one constituent. I have not been successful. I believe that the money just is not made available to people who return the goods. I am told that people are often told to return the goods and they will receive their money back. Somehow the goods never seem to arrive. Most people are extremely angered but they just resolve that they will not be conned by this sort of thing again. From a comment which I made in a Queensland newspaper Mr Clark or 'June Taylor' became aware that I might raise this matter in the Senate and wrote to me requesting that I should not do so. Even though I regard him or her, whatever the case may be, as a downright scoundrel and a confidence trickster, if not an absolute crook, I shall at least have the courtesy to read the letter which was sent to me. It reads:
Dear Senator Colston:
Regarding Item, Page 10, ''SUNDAY MAIL'', 7 February, 1982--We have been informed today that this MAY refer to our firm and our Sets of Little Dolls being sold at $19.95 per 100.

At one stage just prior to Christmas we had to have some small dolls air- freighted in from Asia which were not quite up to the standard of their past stock and not our present stock-but it was an emergency to fill some pre- Christmas orders.

I would be happy if you would examine a couple of samples of current stock of small dolls at 19.9 cents each to determine if 100 of these assorted designs etc would be worth $19.95. We think they are.

I shall continue with the letter in a moment. Apparently what 'June Taylor' is saying is that these samples which were sent to me are much better than some other samples that were sent out earlier. If they are better, one can imagine what the others were like. I did see some others which were sent out to Senator McLaren's constituent and I think they were of poorer quality than these. But if they were of poorer quality than the ones I have one can imagine what they would look like. The letter continued:
We do not know of any chain store even able to sell these at 1.5 cents each ($1 .50 per 100). . .
I interpolate here. I think I said in the Press statement that I put out about these that one could probably buy the whole 100 of them in a chain store for $1. 50. The letter continued:

We would gladly buy stock at such a low figure of 1.5 cents each as the little dolls we are selling cost us nearly $10 per 100 with freight and that is 10c each, and when you add the high cost of advertising (Example: $2850.00 for a small Black and White Advertisement in a leading Womens Magazine, the ''WOMENS WEEKLY'') then add the cost of staff to pack orders, address same etc-About $3 a set would be made on each $19.95 order, (IF THAT!) We do not think that this is excessive.

We cannot see where this is any 'rip-off'-I have shown these 100 Dolls to my little daughter and some neighbours daughters and find only praise from these children-from an Adult point of view what can one expect for 19c each-I see where BP sells little 'Smurf' Dolls at 79c and 99c each at all BP Service Stations.

We know that you have given a lot of time and effort to many matters concerning people and families in the past, and we really admire you for this, and by the attitudes and fair play, we want you to consider our point of view outlined above.

I do not consider it right to have any business ruined by unfair statements made under Parliamentary Privilege-Sure it may be in the case of Riley McKay NSW who took Queenslanders for Half a Million by just closing down, and their business is ruined anyway, and insolvent, so no criticism can hurt them, but for our business which is going into the manufacture from March of Queensland made Doll Houses et cetera it can be a disaster.

I understand that you might have access to 4 or 5 Queensland customers who complained. If this is correct, could you post us names and addresses of those customers, we will write kindly to these consumers, as we now have a brand new stock just arrived of these little dolls and we are prepared to exchange any older stock for these latest USA designed ones worth every bit of 19.9 cents each.
Best wishes to you.
Yours faithfully,
June Taylor.

Some parts of that letter may be technically correct but the point is that this person produced an alluring advertisement for 100 little dolls for $19.95 and the people who received them did not expect to receive such rubbish. I have no sympathy for Mr Clark, or 'June Taylor'. He, or she, has submitted deliberately misleading advertising throughout the nation to extract money for junk. If he carries on in that way he should bear the consequences of his actions. I have extreme doubts whether any of his future projects will provide value for money. To use an old adage, I would not expect that this leopard would change his spots .

There are two other matters that I wish to raise in connection with this advertisement and the dolls that are sent to unsuspecting consumers. Firstly, I am surprised that Australia Post can take no action to refuse this person a post office box. The results of my inquiries suggest that Australia Post has sought legal advice but that the advice is that at this stage the post office box must still be let. Surely this is something which should be given further attention. This crook is being assisted to operate because of Australia Post's inability to make collection of his mail more difficult and to prevent him from having the respectability which some people associate with a post office box number.

The second matter concerns the magazines which accept advertisements for these firms. When an advertisement is placed in a respected magazine such as the Australian Women's Weekly or Family Circle, I have no doubt that many readers afford the same level of respectability to the advertisements themselves. Surely these magazines have some responsibility to check out the bona fides of their advertisers. In fairness, I should mention that I have sighted a letter from the Australian Women's Weekly which indicates that Mr Clark or 'June Taylor' will no longer be able to advertise in that magazine. I wish to quote that letter, which was sent to a person in New South Wales. It reads:
We were disturbed to receive your letter of January 7 advising of your dissatisfaction with the goods received as a result of the '100 Dolls' advertisement in 'Women's Weekly'.

Unfortunately we are aware that a number of readers are also dissatisfied with this advertisement and we want you to know that before accepting the advertisement we were assured that, should any customer be unhappy, all money would be refunded.
We feel you have taken the right course of action by contacting the Consumer Affairs Bureau as, indeed, we have suggested to our readers.
We are sorry you have been inconvenienced and can assure you that no further advertisements for this company will be carried by our magazine.
Yours sincerely, . . . .
National Advertising Sales Manager

This action is a little like shutting the gate after the horse has bolted, but I suppose that at least it is something. I trust that other magazines will follow the Women's Weekly and refuse advertisements placed by this shyster. I would, however, urge executives of respected magazines in Australia to try to retain that respect by closely vetting the background of all potential advertisers. I raised this matter tonight because I believe that confidence tricksters, or crooks as they should be called, should not be allowed to flourish unhindered. As I gain further evidence on shady or disreputable practices I shall have no hesitation in bringing the facts to the notice of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating a package of nine Bills relating to amendments to the sales tax legislation. The Bills effectively impose a sales tax on certain categories of goods that would otherwise have been exempt under the First Schedule to the Act. It is intended that a modest rate of tax of 2 1/2 per cent should be imposed on these goods. However, not all items under the First Schedule will attract sales tax at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent. For example, goods used by universities and non-profit schools will continue to be exempt. The same will apply to goods used for church services and to machinery, implements and apparatus for use in the mining industry or for the carrying out of mining operations. Goods which are used for subsequent manufacture and goods designed as aids to manufacture will also be exempt.

SPEECH.PARA: The important point is that this package of nine Bills is an integral and essential part of the 1981 Budget strategy. We must recognise that twice these Bills have been returned by the Senate to the House of Representatives. The legislation was originally designed to come into effect on 1 January. It was our understanding on the Government side of the chamber that the Australian Democrats intended merely to delay this legislation. As a result steps were taken to defer the operative date from 1 January until 29 March, but that was not to be. In effect, not only the Liberal Party but also the Australian people have been conned by a change of mind, or an error of judgment, as it has been put. Twice, I think, the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) has had a change of mind on important issues which he has put down to errors of judgment. I just wonder how many times we will hear a repetition of the familiar phrase: 'Oh, we have made an error of judgment; we have had a change of mind'.

I think it is important that this legislation represents an attempt by this Government to spread the burden of tax, to move from a system of heavy reliance on personal income tax to a change in the tax mix. Whenever a country relies very heavily on high personal taxation, as we do in Australia, there is an inevitable move by some people to try to avoid or to evade their obligations to society. This means that those people such as pay-as-you-earn taxpayers who are not in a position to alter their tax responsibilities find themselves having to carry too high a burden-in fact an onerous burden-of tax. Some figures show that we are moving probably towards greater dependence than previously on pay-as-you- earn tax. For example, in the year 1969-70 pay-as-you-earn tax contributed about 33 per cent of the total revenue raised, but in 1981-82 that figure was estimated to rise to over 45 per cent. So, Australia basically has been low on indirect tax and high on personal tax. I think one of the messages put through by some of our opponents is that they tend to favour not only a lower indirect tax base but also a lower pay-as-you-earn base. At the same time they must recognise a need to maintain a high level of public sector spending to service the large requirements of social welfare, defence and a whole lot of other commitments.

I think all governments around the world, despite the attempts of some of their leaders to try to reduce the incidence of taxation, have found this to be a very difficult exercise. What we really have to do is to recognise our responsibilities to society while at the same time recognising the problems that are being incurred by a narrowing of the tax base. Over the years we have even seen a narrowing of the sales tax base. This series of Bills, which was a part of the overall integral Budget strategy, was an attempt to move away from a narrowing of the sales tax base over the years by a series of exemptions and reclassifications which effectively reduced the amount of money that the Federal Government was receiving from the sales tax area. The Government believed that of all the measures to try to widen the tax base, the sales tax medium was perhaps the most efficient and the most equitable. It saw this as a method of restoring some degree of equity. Most of the inquiries into income tax have agreed with this tenor of thought. For example, the Asprey Taxation Review Committee recommended the widening of this tax base.

I think the announcement by the Australian Democrats in recent days has really come as quite a disappointment to the majority of the people who supported them. Undoubtedly no taxes are popular. Undoubtedly the Democrats relied for their change of mind upon the fact that public opinion polls showed that these taxes were not popular with the electorate. The public opinion polls supported that thesis. I suppose that one would find that public opinion polls by and large would be very much against any sort of revenue raising. I think people to some extent like to have their cake and eat it too. They want the benefits of the social welfare system that the Government provides, but at the same time they want to see their hip pockets enlarged by higher take home pay. This is not always possible, but we have to try to establish a high degree of equity. To that end the Government is embarking on the right sort of program by trying to counter all these tax avoiding and evading schemes and at the same time altering the tax mix.

I wish to quote from the Mercury newspaper of 9 October 1980. I think that, despite people's attitudes towards sales tax, the Democrats have really let us down. I think many people put a great deal of store on the so-called honesty of the Democrats. Many people remember the message from their mothers while they were nursed on her knee: 'My son, make sure you are a man of integrity. Make sure you are a man of your word and stick to it'. Many people in Australia were saying: 'At last we believe we have found the party that is going to provide all round, without exception, this integrity'. As proof to the Australian people the Democrats provided affidavits in relation to not blocking certain monetary measures that were put forward by the lower House as, after all, this House is a House of review. They recognised the constitutional responsibilities. They pointed out the problems of 1975. They did not want to embroil the country in the sorts of difficulties that emerged from that situation in 1975. They said: ' We are going to wipe the slate clean. We are not going to have this sort of problem. We will act with a degree of honesty and integrity'. But what has happened? We have really been let down. This quotation from the Mercury of 9 October 1980 stated:
If the Democrats held the balance of power overnight, this could transform the whole parliamentary system.

What a transformation we have seen! The Australian electorate saw to it that the Democrats do hold the balance of power. But in holding this balance of power are they acting on the basis of political expediency or are they exercising integrity? The majority of people who supported the Democrats must be tinged with a little sadness. Basically they were good Australian citizens who were looking for high ideals in politics. I think they have been let down. Right across the spectrum the Democrats were very strong on the view that they would act properly and that it was their responsibility to defer but not finally to toss out these Budget Bills. Even the Courier-Mail of 2 September quoted Dr Michael Macklin as saying that the Australian Democrat senators acted properly in refusing to join the Labor Party's attempt to defeat the sales tax legislation in the Budget, even though they were under considerable pressure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a dossier you have in your hand?

—I have one or two items which I think are relevant to the dicussion here to night. That was a fine sentiment; it went down very well within the electorate. A number of people on our side may have said: 'Hurrah, this is great stuff for Australian politics'. Now I think they will be very dismayed to see this complete change of heart on the basis of political expediency. Had the Democrats taken that stance and had they passed the Bills, as they said they would and as we relied on, I think many on our side, despite the fact that we might have lost $79m in the meantime, would have accepted it as a political ploy that they could employ in the upper House. But we found that the situation was a complete reversal. I feel sorry for these people who went to press but somehow have had their arms twisted by someone within the party machine saying: 'No, boys, we can get away with it. We can use the excuse that the people are now with us'. But are they with the Democrats? Probably, temporarily a few may have been. The people who write to the Democrats demanding everything may have thought it was a good thing. I wonder how the thinking Australians will view this. The Democrats signed affidavits. They did not want the country pushed into turmoil but wanted some check on Liberal and National Country Party enthusiasm in some areas. I think people recognise that, after all , the government of a country should reside in the province of the lower House where the Liberal and National Country parties have a clear majority. The Democrats have had a change of heart. Their leader has had a number of changes of heart. He had one in 1975 and he has had one now. We wonder how many others we will have to face in future. This must be the nagging question that the Democrats have to overcome to restore their credibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Great store has been put on the cost of this package of measures to low income earners. It has been mentioned that these Bills are intended to raise $330m in a full year and $132m in the first part year. The losses to revenue will be compounded at a time of an overrun Budget situation. One could possibly make some excuse for the Democrats for adopting this attitude if more revenue had come in than was necessary or if we were cutting our expenses more than we had budgeted to do. It would not then be necessary to raise this extra money. But the Democrats have hit the Government at a time when it, the Treasury and the coffers are not in a position to afford any cut in taxation revenue. They have deliberately taken their stand within a few days of an announcement of a severe increase in the deficit. They have said: 'We now have the Government in a corner . We will squeeze it hard'. It comes back to the question of political expediency. I would have thought that the honourable thing to do would have been to consider the alternative situation to see whether we had an overrun of revenue or whether we were cutting costs and recouping revenue in that way. But the leader of the Democrats decided that Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister, and the Treasurer, Mr Howard, were in a tight corner on the question of revenue. He said : 'We will push them and squeeze them into the ground.'

These Bills provide for a modest increase of 2 1/2 per cent on a range of services. What will that mean to the ordinary person? On a summer frock costing about $20 it will probably mean an increase in price of 50c. My colleague in the other place, Mr Cadman, cited the case of the building industry. Workers in that industry recently had an 18 per cent wage increase which would have added $3,600 to the cost of the family home. There was not much of a squeal about that but there has been a heck of a squeal about the tax of 2 1/2 per cent on building supplies which will effectively add about $500 to the cost of a family home. Not a word has been said about the movements in land prices or the added cost to the family home of $3,500 as a result of the wage increase. The focus has really been on the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax which people think sounds a heck of a lot.

We have to recognise also that the States are missing out on this revenue. They get a fair whack of the revenue raised by means of sales tax. The Democrats' decision comes at a time when State revenues are certainly under pressure. We read this daily. My State has particular problems. New South Wales and Victoria have problems which have been highlighted as a result of elections in those two States. It must be recognised by the Democrats' that they are cutting off revenue, a large portion of which is due to the States. As we are a States House one wonders whether it is responsible to cut off deliberately revenue to the States at a time when they can ill afford to sacrifice revenue of this nature. Therefore, one must ask whether a responsible attitude has been taken. The States have responsibilities to the people. After all, they are very much closer to people than the Commonwealth is. This is something that the Democrats recognise. They believe that they are grass roots politicians and that the issues have to go to the people.

Who are the people who are being affected by their decision? That decision means that it will not be easy to introduce tax cuts, certainly of the size that many of us were hoping for. Some people believe that the greater dependence on indirect tax should have been associated with a hefty reduction in income tax. But as a result of changes in the whole taxation mix the wage earners and the people who are contributing their fair share of tax to Australian society-these are the ones I am concerned about, particularly the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers- will now not get the tax cuts that might otherwise have been derived. How can the Treasurer and the Government plan the finances of this Government and this nation in circumstances in which they are uncertain whether the Senate will pass the necessary taxing legislation? This raises serious questions. The ability of a government to govern is now dependent on the whims or attitudes of a very small number of people in this House and how they view certain legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the DLP did it to us for years and you welcomed them as allies.

—If we are trying to talk about principles, that is one thing. If we are talking about expediency, that is another. That has been the whole purpose of my address tonight. I am trying to distinguish between the two to establish whether government should be based on expediency or principle.
—They said they wanted to keep the bastards honest. That was the catchcry.

—How in fairness can Mr Howard or the Prime Minister attempt to bring in responsible taxing measures or even cost cutting measures in an environment of such high uncertainty? They cannot predict what the situation will be. It is no way to be able to govern a country when a government is certain that it will get the numbers in one place but when the members of the other chamber say: 'We will hive off that cost cutting measure and we will disallow this revenue raising item'. It raises tremendous constitutional problems for any government in future, whatever its political persuasion. We have to recognise that certain constitutional amendments may be necessary to overcome the situation, otherwise we will have a high level of instability in government. It will not be easy for our side of politics to get three senators up from each of the States at the next half Senate election, in which case after 1984, other things being equal and taking normal expectations into account, instability in this place could continue for a number of years. I believe that it is not in the best interests of Australia or in the best interests of Australian taxpayers to have a situation whereby the Government cannot really be judged on its merits. This is the situation in which the Fraser Government now finds itself. I think it would be far better for the Australian electorate to be able to judge a government on its package and what went right or wrong during its term of office. We are now in a situation of complete compromise and a rejection of normal business of government of an important nature because, after all, the raising of the revenue is particularly important to our social responsibilities and--
—How would you like a single chamber? If we abolished the Senate altogether, how would that be?

—That raises further complications, but at least there would be a certainty and we would be able to identify much more clearly the important aspect of government policy which I believe the Australian electorate could identify. It could then vote accordingly. The electorate is basically disappointed with this attitude because, as my colleague rightly said, the whole purpose of the strategy of the campaign during the last election was to keep the so-called bastards honest.
—That is a laudable objective.

—Whilst it might be a laudable objective, unfortunately at the real test that the Australian Democrats had to face up to, they fell. As many political parties around the world do, they chose political expendiency rather than integrity. This so-called error of judgment really was a recognition that they were essentially torn, between their principles and, what one leading commentator called, their opportunism. Unfortunately, they fell for opportunism on the basis that they thought it was politically popular to knock these sorts of taxes. The raising of any sort of taxes is basically unpopular. I believe that, in the long term, the Democrats have misjudged their mark and the mood of the Australian electorate, which is looking for these high principles. All along the line the Democrats were adamant that they would not change their minds. In fact, Senator Haines, when speaking in the Budget debate, spoke of the need to maintain principles. She said the Democrats would not be roughed up by the Australian Labor Party and forced into a situation to which which some of our colleagues on the opposite benches were trying to guide them. I must give full marks to the Labor Party. It did take it a long time to encourage the Democrats to come alongside in their views.
—They made their own decision.

—They made their own decision, but I believe this decision was made in the light of political opportunism. The credit for this opposition has not been given to the Australian Labor Party. It was determined and firm in its views all along the line. In the newspaper headlines who takes the credit for this situation? Not the Australian Labor Party even though it was steadfastly opposed to this legislation from the word go. There is no doubt that the Australian electorate knows where the Labor Party stands on this matter. Members of this new party-based on integrity and rightness of principles-have now taken the political opportunist line of wavering because of what they believe is a short term gain. However, in the long term, I believe that the Democrats have misread the mood of the Australian electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider some quotations. Senator Macklin said that by taking the stance that it did Labor also pledged not to block Supply. He said that it abandoned all preference of political principles. So people in glass houses should not throw stones. The Australian Democrats condemned the Australian Labor Party for its supposed lack of principles. In the course of going around the electorate during the break the Democrats have abandoned their political princples. Many people may have thought that the Democrats' attack on the Australian Labor Party was unfair. Senator Chipp said to Derryn Hinch when referring to certain problems:

It threw this country into turmoil. It divided the country. Although the Senate has that power, we opted of our own free will as Democrats, to say 'we might have that power to do it, but we believe it wrong for the Senate to do it', so we virtually abrogated that power that we have.
So the Democrats recognised the constitutional power that the Senate has in relation to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What matter?
—In relation to the rejection of money Bills. Senator Chipp continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Now if you want me to say 'I believe we were wrong in 1975', I'll say it, because that is what I believe.
Derryn Hinch then said:

Well you had a change of heart there, you've also obviously had a change of heart about Malcolm Fraser because some years ago you were a fairly staunch Malcolm Fraser supporter, and I think you even said on one occasion that Malcolm Fraser was the only man to lead the country?

TALK.START.PARA: —What date was that said?

—It was said on the program Willesee '81, on 17 August 1981 in an interview that Senator Chipp had with Derryn Hinch on that show. The whole purpose of that interview was to show that the party was one of integrity. I am worried about whether the newfound hatred of the Leader of the Australian Democrats for our leader is such that it is overcoming all the finer principles of all those Democrats who tried to bring purity and honesty to this new democratic party. I ask whether his hatred has been manifested to such an extent that they would almost try anything to overthrow, to upset, to make difficult--
—To tarnish?

—To tarnish the reputation of our leader. I think this is a very different situation where someone builds up such a degree of hatred and antagonism toward a man that he can move the principles of a new-found democratic party to try to destroy that person. If this is the aim of one person --

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT
