QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the claim in the National Times of 12-18 April 1981 that document 'J' of the Owen Royal Commission contained allegations that a Minister of the Australian government had given the Japanese government, prior to the outbreak of World War II, three months notice in advance that their funds were to be frozen in Australia.

(2) Are the claims concerning document 'J' correct; if so: (a) what is the name of the Minister in question; (b) is a close relative of the Minister named in document 'J' now a member of the present government; and (c) will the Attorney- General make document 'J' available to the Senate for perusal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Royal Commission on Espionage ordered that document 'J' not be published or disclosed. In this regard the Chairman of the Royal Commission, His Honour Mr Justice Owen, indicated that the document contained criminal libels and defamatory comments which 'smeared' the reputation of about 60 persons (many of whom I would expect to be alive today) 'some to a great extent, some to a lesser degree'.

In accordance with the rules for release of archives laid down by the previous Government and incorporated in the Archives Bill introduced by this Govermnent, the release of papers relating to the Royal Commission on Espionage would be a matter for consideration in 1984.
Given what was said about this particular document by Mr Justice Owen, the Government sees no reason for early release of document 'J' and no reason to offer comments upon it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to a report in the National Times (12-18 July 1981) referring to an attempt by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to tap the unlisted telephone of the New South Wales Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation, without the knowledge of the subscriber and without supplying a warrant to the Telecom technicians involved.
(2) It is an accepted practice by ASIO to issue oral instructions to Telecom to tap private telephones.

(3) Will the Attorney-General indicate whether members of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association are being forced into a breach of the Telecommunications Act by tapping telephones without sighting the necessary warrant, when it is an offence for anyone to intercept telephone conversations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention has been drawn to the National Times article. However, in accordance with the usual practice I make no comment on the substance of the allegations contained in that article.
(2) I am assured by the Director-General of Security that it is not an accepted practice for ASIO to issue oral instructions to Telecom to tap private telephones.

(3) The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 provides specifically that copies of warrants issued pursuant to sections 9 and 10 of the Act must be forwarded as soon as practicable to the Managing Director of the Australian Telecommunications Commission. Instructions to officers of the Commission to take action to enable an interception to be carried out pursuant to such a warrant are given by or on behalf of the Managing Director. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act does not require that any officer of the Commission apart from the Managing Director should sight the copy of the warrant .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of the decision taken by the Queensland Government to allow sandmining on 6.4 per cent of Moreton Island.
(2) Is the Minister further aware that in November 1980, Moreton Island was accepted on the Register of the National Estate as an area of national significance.

(3) Will the Minister assure the people of Queensland that no action will be taken to destroy this part of the National Estate, as this region contains a complex, integrated system of fauna, heathland, forest, natural dunes and ocean beach.

(4) Will the Minister say whether the listing of Moreton Island under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 creates a position where the Federal Government is not allowed to take any action, such as issuing export permits, because of the damage that any mining will cause to the environment of this island.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Moreton Island was proposed for listing in the Register of the National Estate in the Commonwealth Gazette G2 of 17 January 1978. Objections were received to this listing, and following evaluation of these objections the Commission has made a decision to enter on the Register the whole of Moreton Island with the exception of the gazetted townships of Bulwer, Cowan Cowan, Tangalooma and Kooringal. This area was advertised for entry in the Register in the Commonwealth Gazette G34 of 25 August 1981.
(3) and (4) With the exception of Commonwealth owned land, land management and land use decisions in a State are essentially matters for the State Government involved.

In respect of the export of mineral sands from Moreton Island, section 30 of the Act would require that Commonwealth Ministers or Authorities responsible for approving licenses for the export of mineral sands from Moreton Island shall not take any action that adversely affects the national estate value of the parts of Moreton Island included in the Register of the National Estate, unless they are satisfied there is no feasible or prudent alternative, unless all reasonable measures are taken to minimise the adverse effect and unless the Australian Heritage Commission is informed of the proposed action and given a reasonable opportunity to consider it.

The entry of Moreton Island in the Register of the National Estate is recognition of the Island's great environmental and cultural significance. The actions of State or local Governments are not affected.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minster representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the actual amount of tax collected from wage and salary earners in the financial year 1975-76.
(2) What is the estimated amount of tax to be collected from wage and salary earners for the financial year 1981-82, in 1975-76 prices.
(3) What has been the increase in actual wages and salaries paid in that period .
(4) What are the aforesaid increases in percentage terms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The amount of income tax collected from wage and salary earners is not recorded separately, but the income tax revenue figures show Pay as You Earn collections, i.e., amounts of tax instalment remittances and proceeds from the sale of tax stamps as well as PAYE refunds. PAYE collections in 1975-76 net of refunds made during that financial year amounted to $7,020m.

Some tax is also payable by salary and wage earners on assessment where the tax instalments that have been deducted are insufficient to cover the tax payable on the total income. It is noted that, because some PAYE tax instalments are applied against income other than salary and wages, PAYE collections to this extent overstate the tax payable on salaries and wages subject to instalments. It should be mentioned that PAYE refunds generally related to amounts of instalments deducted in the previous financial year.

(2) Net PAYE collections in 1981-82 are estimated at $17,255m. Consistent with the 1981-82 Budget assumptions regarding the expected level of the Consumer Price Index in 1981-82 net PAYE collections in 1975-76 prices as measured by the consumer price index would be $9,586m.

(3) The National Accounts estimate of wages, salaries and supplements for 1980- 81 is $71,332m. Consistent with the 1981-82 Budget assumptions as regards average earnings and employment wages, salaries and supplements should reach $82 ,580m in 1981-82, some $41,000m more than the 1975-76 National Accounts estimate .

(4) Net PAYE collections in 1981-82 adjusted to 1975-76 prices are estimated to exceed 1975-76 net PAYE collections by 36.6 per cent. Wages, salaries and supplements in 1981-82 are estimated to exceed those paid in 1975-76 by 98.6 per cent.

(9) Were the decisions mentioned in (1) and (2) expected to yield staff savings ; if so, what staff savings were estimated to result from implementation at the time the Review was first announced and what staff savings are now estimated to result from implementation of the Review.
(10) What money savings will result from any staff savings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question on behalf of all Ministers:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The RCF decisions listed in the appendix to the Prime Minister's Statement to the House of Representatives of 30 April were categorised, where appropriate, by department.

(2) (a) Staff implications of all RCF decisions, to the extent that these implications could be assessed at the time, were taken into account by the Government in setting provisional staff ceilings for 1981-82. Details of the ceilings for individual departments were stated at page 90 of the Public Service Board's Report to Parliament for 1980-81. Those ceilings may need to be varied in the light of RCF reviews or investigations currently being undertaken or yet to be commenced, or in the light of the disposal of Commonwealth assets. Where further studies already undertaken have shown that variation of ceilings is warrented appropriate adjustments have been made.

(2) (b) Departments' funding requirements for these categories of expenditure for 1981-82 were reassessed during the Budget process in the light of the Review decisions and other relevant considerations and the outcome of those reassessments was reflected in the bids for, and decisions on, funding provided in the 1981-82 Budget. It is not practicable to separately identify the effects on departments of the specific decisions mentioned as distinct from the effects of other considerations bearing on Budget funding decisions, all of which were reflected in the estimates tabled with the 1981-82 Budget.

(3), (7), (8), (9) and (10) In answer to Question No. 723 from the honourable senator it was made clear that the Review of Commonwealth Functions was not primarily an exercise in cost cutting. The focus of the review was on streamlining and fining down Commonwealth operations by withdrawing from areas more appropriately handled by the States and private enterprise and rationalising a number of Commonwealth activities. While eventual ongoing savings compared with the cost of continuing programs on the basis of then existing policies were estimated to be 'of the order of $560m' it was explained in that answer why more precise figuring was not provided at the time and that the figures did not make allowance for savings of a more diffuse kind. It is in the nature of estimates that they may not be completely accurate and that the degree of inaccuracy, if any, may not be precisely known.

The effect of RCF decisions on estimates of budget outlays is combined with that of other Government decisions (including the 1981-82 budget measures) and with changes in underlying parameters affecting estimates. It is not practicable to separate out the financial effects of each of the many interacting influences on the financial estimates. To attempt such an exercise would involve a major effort on the part of all departments and authorities which I am not prepared to authorise.

I am able to inform the honourable senator, however, that, taken as a whole, the savings on the 1981-82 forward estimates achieved through the current budget (which reflects effects of a range of RCF and other decisions) were well in excess of the figure of $560m estimated as the order of ongoing savings eventually to arise from the RCF exercise. The government will, of course, also continue to pursue further savings through the implementation of those RCF decisions currently outstanding.

The Prime Minister's statement of 30 April indicated an expected total staffing reduction of 16,000-17,000. The rate at which staff savings will be achieved can be expected to vary widely as between one decision and another. The implementation of some decisions will inevitably take much longer than others, for example the disposal of Commonwealth assets, the review of the Defence organisation, the Australia Post and Telecom reviews. Savings possibilities will in some cases only come clear as reviews proceed. The Government is closely monitoring the achievement of savings against particular decisions.

(4) As at end of October 1981, approximately 270 of the Government's decisions arising from the Review had been implemented or were close to final implementation, of a total of some 350 decisions. Implementation of the remainder is being pursued by responsible Ministers and is oversighted by a Cabinet Committee chaired by the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

(5) and (6) The process of Government administration constantly involves implementation of decisions; the implementation of RFC decisions has in general proceeded as part of that process rather than with seperate resources. Seperate records have not been kept of the resources applied to implementation of RCF decisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps have been taken to implement suggestions made in the McKinsey Report that Telecom 'adopt marginal cost pricing where excess capacity exists'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As mentioned in the report, Telecom already applies the marginal cost pricing principle in providing for discounted off-peak STD rates. In addition, it is further studying the implications of extending the application of this principle . However, in the circumstances recommended in the report, that is discounted connection fees in areas where spare exchange equipment capacity exists, Telecom 's view is that there is limited scope for applying this approach because it would only be possible if there were a surplus of all the network components necessary for service in the particular area. In addition, Telecom is required to publish details of rentals and charges which it determines in the Commonwealth Gazette and this statutory requirement would inhibit the flexibility necessary for the Report's proposal to be effective.

Telecom is mindful also of the possible customer reaction to a departure from its traditional non-discriminatory approach of prescribing uniform charges for all subscribers or for all subscribers within a particular classification.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many habitations were reviewed in each electoral division in 1980 under (a) the habitation review system, and (b) the electoral agency system.
(2) How many habitations were not reviewed in each division in 1980 in areas covered by: (a) the habitation review system, and (b) the electoral agency system.
(3) Why were some habitations not reviewed and others reviewed in each division , and how were those reviewed chosen.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (b) and (2) (b) The Electoral Agents' System is used to check the accuracy of individual entries in the rolls in remote and/or sparsely populated areas. This is not undertaken however, as in urban areas, by visiting residences. The system involves sending lists of electors to appointed agents whose familiarity with an area is such that they might reasonably be expected to have some knowledge of the movement of electors within their locality. These agents traditionally are postmasters, teachers, policemen et cetera.

The information recorded by agents will either confirm the enrolment records or will indicate that an elector recorded as residing at that habitation has now left. In addition the agents will report any new residents who appear to be qualified for enrolment and whose names do not appear on the record. They also report alterations required in respect of the particulars of an elector-for example, change of name, change of address, et cetera. Divisional returning officers are required to follow up all reports received from electoral agents.
As habitations are not reviewed under the Electoral Agency System there are no statistics available to answer these parts of the honourable senator's question.

(1) (a), (2) (a) and (3). The honourable senator appears to have a misunderstanding about habitation reviews. The aim of these reviews is to help to keep electoral rolls up-to-date by checking current entries on the roll against the names of persons actually living at addresses. The reviews do not operate solely to remove the names of electors from electoral rolls; they are concerned just as much at helping unenrolled but eligible voters have their names placed on the roll. As was pointed out in the answer given to the honourable senator's Question No. 856, in the same period in which the names of some 290,000 electors were removed from the rolls, 1.5m names were added. These of course were not all new arrivals in Australia or persons turning 18, but took into account people who had moved from one address to another, or whose names had been removed from one address by the required objection process but re- entered on the roll at their new address.

Much of the information being sought by the honourable senator is not maintained or needed by the Australian Electoral Office in the form in which the honourable senator asks. For example, in Question No. 856 the total number of hours worked by Habitation Review Officers for each month in each federal division in the 12 months to December 1980 was sought. As was pointed out in reply, review officers are paid by habitations reviewed and not by hours spent. In order to assist the honourable senator an attempt was made to provide him with information in the form asked for, but because of the basis of payment which gave no direct indication of time spent and because of the various densities of habitation within areas and the mixture of such areas within and between divisions, that information quite clearly could only be based on a very broad estimate. In seeking subsequently to verify further the estimates which had been made, the Electoral Office found that two of the States, Western Australia and Tasmania, had in fact interpreted the honourable senator's question more broadly than had the other States and had included in their figures not only the estimated time of habitation review officers in the field, but also of casual employees processing habitation review data in the divisional offices. Amended time estimates based only on field work are now provided in respect of those two States:
Estimate of total hours worked on habitation review
Jan. Feb. Mar. Apr. May Jun. Jul. Aug. Sep. Oct. Nov. Total

With this current question, No. 1374, neither statistics nor records are maintained in a way which gives ready answers to some of the questions asked or which are easily translatable into the form sought by the honourable senator. In addition, because of the way in which the question is framed there is a need to exercise care in interpreting and using the information provided. The question asks for the number of habitations reviewed in each electoral division in 1980. The position is that habitation reviews are conducted by the Australian Electoral Office not by calendar year, but by financial year. Therefore providing the information in the form which the question seeks can have a number of consequences when it comes to its use and interpretation. For example, a habitation which has been recorded as having been reviewed twice in 1980 could have been so reviewed because it is located in a new housing development with a high growth rate and it has been thought advisable to cover that area twice in the one review period or it could also mean that the habitation was visited once in each of two successive reviews, 1979-80 and 1980-81. Statistics will not give the reasons. Again, habitations which were not recorded as having been reviewed at all in 1980 could have been reviewed in the first half of the 1979-1980 review or in the second half of the 1980-81 review. Again the statistics asked for will not show this. The honourable senator will need to bear these points in mind in using the following statistical information from the Australian Electoral Office:

The Australian Electoral Office has advised that it is its aim to conduct a full habitation review each financial year. However as the honourable senator will appreciate it is not always possible to achieve this result. For example, elections and redistributions (Commonwealth or State) especially in the joint roll States can cause interruption to the review process. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister confirm that a senior executive of Ansett Airlines of Australia has admitted the purchase of 12 twin-engined narrow-bodied Boeing 737s was 'solely a marketing decision', as claimed in the September edition of Australian Aviation and Defence Review.

(2) Is it also true, as claimed in an article entitled 'Counting the One Per Cent'), by Mr Jim Thorn, the editor of the magazine, that a senior Ansett executive has stated that the Boeing 737-200 is no more economical to run than the Douglas DC9-30, with which Ansett is already equipped.

(3) Can the Minister confirm what the magazine describes as a 'strong rumour in the industry' that Ansett plans to back-trade or trade-in, its newly introduced Boeing 737-200s for 737-300s in 1985, only four years after the introduction of the 737-200.

(4) Does the Minister think it proper that Ansett was allowed to spend approximately $150m on the purchase of aircraft which appear to offer no significant advantages over existing equipment, and which the airline apparently admits were bought solely as the result of a marketing decision.
(5) Can the Minister justify capital expenditure of $150m at the expense of the long-suffering air traveller to maintain the market share of a privately-owned airline.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) During this year the Government had implemented policies, including the introduction of legislation which the Parliament has passed, directed at increasing the level of competition within the aviation industry and particularly between Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett. Consistent with those policies the Government considers that decisions relating to aircraft acquisitions are the commercial responsibility of the airline involved. Under the Independent Air Fares Committee Act the first class and economy fares of Ansett and TAA are matched and therefore there is no guarantee that one airline could recoup excessive capital expenditure. As the other matters raised by this question relate to the decisions of a commercial organisation, I do not consider it appropriate to respond to them.

ANSWER.PARA: Qantas has on a number of occasions engaged the services of Mr Barry O'Keefe, Q .C. The services for which he was engaged and the fees paid for those services are commercially confidential to Mr O'Keefe and Qantas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Australian diplomats and officials actively seeking a Vietnamese withdrawal from Kampuchea and an act of self-determination by the Kampuchean people; if so, why.
(2) Is this activity in support of an ASEAN resolution co-sponsored by Australia.
(3) Has not Australia's Ambassador to the United Nations, Mr David Anderson, been vigorous in the United Nations in appealing for the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from Kampuchea.
(4) Has not the United Nations General Assembly repeatedly pointed out that its Charter clearly states the rights of nations to self-determination.

(5) Why then has the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations been instructed to vote against moves by the United Nations to study the Timorese situation and to report on all aspects of East Timor, including how independence for the Timorese can be achieved.
(6) Did Australian officials hope that the issue of East Timor self- determination would become dormant and thus save any embarrassment for Australia .
(7) How can the Minister justify this seemingly hypocritical action in supporting Kampuchean self-determination yet blocking East Timor self- determination.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. We do not believe that the use of force is justified to bring about political change. We consider that there can be no lasting settlement in Kampuchea until the Vietnamese forces are withdrawn and a truly representative government is chosen by the Khmer people free from outside coercion or interference.

(4) Article 1 (2) of the United Nations Charter endorses the principles of the self-determination of peoples. In addition, Articles 1 of both the U.N. Covenants on Human Rights establish the right of all peoples to self- determination.

(5) and (6) Australia has voted against resolutions on the East Timor question since the 1978 General Assembly because we consider them to be unrealistic and to serve no practical purpose. The Government considers that the incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia is now a reality and that the Indonesian Government is the authority in effective control.
(7) The situations in Kampuchea and East Timor are not comparable or analagous.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do air traffic controllers at Brisbane Airport experience peculiar difficulties due to the proximity of the Amberley and Archerfield control zones and excessive 'return' images that occupy the display screens of the outdated equipment used.

(2) Do air traffic controllers at Brisbane Airport have a primary radar that provides only a twelve second update in an area of already difficult control and increasing traffic; if so, is the Minister for Transport concerned, and can he state the date when Brisbane can expect to receive the A.R.T.S. display console with facilities for callsign and altitude readout labelled display and a higher- frequency rotation terminal radar with five-second update.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) From time to time, problems do arise for air traffic controllers at Brisbane Airport due to the proximity of Amberley and Archerfield control zones. These problems are similar to those encountered at other capital city airports. These problems are overcome by employing control techniques to provide an orderly and expeditious flow of traffic.

During the hot summer months 'return' images, commonly known as angels, appear within Brisbane radar coverage under certain atmospheric conditions. Similar angel activity is encountered on other radars in Australia and overseas. These angels at Brisbane are not considered excessive. The Brisbane radar system employs operating parameters which reduce the angel returns to a minimum and its performance compares favourably in this respect with current 'state of the art' primary radar systems.

(2) The current Brisbane primary radar provides a twelve second update. This rate of data renewal is considered to be adequate for safe and efficient control of aircraft at Brisbane at the level of traffic expected for some years to come.

ARTS (Automated Radar Terminal System) is the name given to the system employed by the Department of Transportation, Federal Aviation Administration in the United States of America for airport (terminal) air traffic control within 60 nautical miles of an airport and, with the exception of the control tower, uses displays which must be viewed in 'dark room' conditions. ARTS will not be provided for Brisbane because of more modern system, as has already been ordered for Adelaide and Melbourne, is planned.

A terminal radar with four second update and a more modern radar display system (providing callsign and altitude readout on new display facilities) are planned for commissioning in the time period of 1985-88 in order to allow continued safe and efficient control of expected movements at Brisbane.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister of Communications aware of plans by Australia Post to close the suburban Brisbane post office of Keperra in January 1982 and transfer its functions to the suburb of Ferny Hills.

(2) Will the Minister ask Australia Post to reconsider its decision as Keperra Post Office is located in the middle of a busy and growing shopping centre and as the suburb supports significant numbers of single parents, pensioners, Army families and many single vehicle households which will experience inconvenience and hardship if the post office is closed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Keperra Post Office is to close when the new Ferny Hills Post Office building is ready for occupancy, probably in February 1982.
(2) Australia Post has advised me that it has given further consideration to the proposed closure of Keperra Post Office and that it still considers that the closure is appropriate.

Australia Post is building a new official post office at Ferny Hills to replace the existing non-official office in that suburb. Ferny Hills is considered to be a more suitable location as a base for the postal delivery group serving the areas of Ferny Hills, Arana Hills and Keperra and the postal delivery group is to be transferred from leased premises in Keperra to Ferny Hills when the new post office building is ready for occupancy. This is expected to occur in February 1982.

With the removal of the delivery group, Keperra Post office will have lost a major function and, as there are alternative post offices within a reasonable distance, it has been decided that the office should close concurrent with the opening of the Ferny Hills Post Office.

Arana Hills and Mitchelton Post Offices are 1.6 kilometres and two kilometres respectively from Keperra Post Office and each of these offices transacts more counter business than Keperra and is at a location which has a larger shopping centre. Public transport is available from Keperra to Mitchelton.

Australia Post considers that the postal needs of Keperra residents will be reasonably well met after closure of the office. In addition to alternative post offices nearby, a street posting box will be provided in the shopping centre and stamps may be purchased at two licensed stamp vendors already operating in the centre.

(Note: Army families have a further alternative available as there is a post office at the Enoggera Barracks. The office is four kilometres road travel distance from Keperra Post Office but Army personnel are able to transact postal business while at the barracks.)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Newcastle District Telecom Manager state that delays in household telephone installations in the Newcastle region were expected to worsen because of demands by expanding industry, as reported in the Sydney Sun on 30 September 1981.

(2) Does the district have a waiting list of more than 800 applicants, as reported in the article, if so, how many applications are outstanding and how long will they take before installation can be expected.
(3) Has the Minister for Communications received representations from various groups regarding the standard of telephone services being provided for the Morisset-Coorabong region.
(4) Have many of the residents serviced by the Cooranbong exchange reported that the emergency service number '000' cannot be reached.
(5) Will the Minister act urgently to improve the decaying telephone services to those residents, particularly in regard to the '000' service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Newcastle District Telecommunications Manager did state that delays in household telephone installations were expected to worsen because of demands by expanding industry.

(2) At the time of the article, 813 applications were held for telephone services in the Newcastle District Office, that could not be served under three months because of insufficient pairs of cable or shortages of exchange equipment . The position showed some improvement by the end of October with the deferred applicants reduced to 628 including 62 waiting for extensions to telephone exchange equipment. The estimated delays indicates that of these, 67 will be connected within six months, 49 will be connected between six and 12 months, 282 will be connected between 12 and 18 months, and 230 will be connected between 18 months and two years.
The forecast for telephone demand in the Newcastle District indicates that more than 11,600 new telephones will be required for business and domestic customers during 1981-82.

(3) Representations have been received from groups concerning the grade of service being provided for the Morisset-Cooranbong region. In reply to the latest of these representations, the organisation concerned was advised that senior Telecom officers would be prepared to attend a public meeting in the area , should it be considered necessary.

(4) The emergency service number '000' is accessible from all customers connected to the Cooranbong Exchange. Telecom advises that it has been unable to obtain any evidence of any Cooranbong residents who have complained that '000' cannot be reached.

Callers from outlying areas are encouraged by Telecom to dial the emergency service direct. The telephone directory listing Cooranbong customers has spaces allocated inside the front cover, for customers to record their own emergency service telephone numbers. This applies particularly to Bush Fire Brigades where details of changes in volunteers are not always made known to the '000' operator . Direct dialling has the added advantage of avoiding network congestion, in cases where the emergency service is connected to the same telephone exchange as the caller.

(5) The Cooranbong telephone exchange is of modern design and is capable of providing a satisfactory grade of service. However, like many other exchanges with a high demand for telephone services the network switching equipment is under strain during peak traffic conditions to provide switching paths for all traffic. In these instances calls to '000' experience the same grade of service as other traffic during those times.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

(3) The National Aboriginal Consultative Committee (NACC) which preceded the National Aboriginal Conference, (NAC) was elected by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities using a 'first past the post' system.

The Steering Committee (which included Aboriginal representation) established to recommend procedures for the conduct of the first NAC election in 1977 recommended, and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs approved, that the 'first past the post' system be adopted. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Were certain coins ordered from the Australian Mint in March 1980 not delivered to the purchaser until August; if so, what were the reasons for the delay in delivery and is it common for the Mint to take over four months to meet coin orders.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Order forms for the 1981 six coin collector sets were despatched to customers on the Mint's mailing list in March 1981. The Controller of the Mint advises that the arrangements which have always applied for sale of these sets are for orders to be taken commencing early in the year, with production and distribution of the sets proceeding through the year. An acknowledgement form is sent to customers advising when delivery of the order is expected. Orders are met in order of their receipt by the Mint. Thus, in circumstances of heavy demand as have applied in recent years, some orders are not met until relatively late in the year. This year the effects of the industrial dispute at the Mint, which was of three months duration, and the very heavy level of demand, will mean that some orders will not be met until December of this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

(2) Did the mobile polling booths in the SAA electorate of South Australia instead of remaining at designated polling places, move around visiting the homes of potential voters in contravention of the rules for the conduct of the NAC election.
(3) Did this occur in other electorates; if so, which ones.
(4) Will the Minister ensure a full investigation of all complaints about the conduct of the NAC election.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) A number of complaints have been received relating to the conduct of the National Aboriginal Conference election. All complaints received have been referred to the disputes Committees established under the rules for conduct of the NAC election to deal with matters arising out of the election. The extent to which these complaints are being, or will be, investigated is a matter for those Committees.
Six prominent Aboriginals, including Senator Bonner as chairman, have been appointed as a disputes panel from which committees of three were established to consider individual complaints or disputes.

One of the complaints directed to the disputes committees through the Australian Electoral Office related to the operation of mobile polling teams in the SAA electorate of South Australia. I am advised that no other complaint of this nature has been received.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Are there serious rivalries between the Uniting Church Commission for World Mission and the World Vision Overseas Aid Agency as portrayed by John Hurst ( vide the National Times, dated Sunday 1 November 1981) which seriously impair refugee aid programmes to El Salvador and Honduras.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Transport have any contingency plans for dealing with a coastal oil spill of major proportions; if so, (a) have these measures been tested, and (b) what are they.
(2) Had the bunker oil from the Anro Asia disgorged through rupturing of the vessel's hull, would the ensuing contamination have been a State or Federal responsibility, or both.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil takes into account coastal oil spills of major proportions.

(a) Measures have been tested by exercises where management and communications procedures are tried out and equipment exercises where pollution combat equipment is deployed during simulated oil spills. In addition, contingency plans are revised and updated following actual incidents.

(b) Measures consist of stockpiles of oil dispersant and pollution control and recovery equipment, strategically located at all State capital cities and some other ports. Pollution Committees are established in all States and are advised and assisted by Department of Transport marine pollution specialists. The Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre receives pollution reports and disseminates them for appropriate action as part of its coastal surveillance role.

(2) The Anro Asia was grounded within Brisbane port limits and therefore any contamination would have been a State responsibility under the administrative arrangements between the Commonwealth and States for combating marine pollution. However, the Commonwealth did provide assistance by sending two expert advisers and pollution combat equipment. Further resources would have been made available if required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did Tertiary Education Commission's Report for the 1982-4 Triennium recommend that the Institute of Child Health be closed at the end of 1981, followed by the establishment of an Academic Department of Child Health at the University of Sydney and for the continuing academic responsibilities at the Royal Alexandra Hospital (see Senate Hansard, page 912, dated 20 August 1981). If so, can an assurance be given that arrangements have been made for the medically qualified members of the staff of the Institute of Child Health who were permanent public servants to continue in their teaching roles in the University of Sydney and at the Royal Alexandra Hospital for Children.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is assumed that the honourable senator is referring to my reply to Question No. 912 as reported in the Hansard of 20 August 1981.

A task force established by the Commonwealth Department of Health recommended the closure of the Institute of Child Health. The Government agreed with this recommendation and the Institute will close on 31 December 1981. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Report for 1982-4 Triennium indicated that the Universities Council, in its advice to the Commission for the distribution of grants to the university sector for that triennium, has made provision within the grants to the University of Sydney for its continuing academic responsibilities at the Royal Alexandra Hospital at a level which is consonant with the student load in the Faculty of Medicine.

In accordance with approved procedures discussions have been held with relevant staff associations and the Public Service Board in relation to the redeployment of all officers of the Institute of Child Health following its closure. Discussions have also been held with the University of Sydney on the possible employment of professional staff of the Institute with the University. I am advised that final decisions in relation to this matter have not been taken. I therefore cannot give any assurance, as sought, at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

The following table illustrates the minimum and maximum full time staff levels which were employed on the project:
(4)-(5) Payments made to full time staff members of the task force between August 1980 and October 1981 were as follows:
Salaries including higher duties $201,833.76 Overtime, travelling and other allowances $70,080.41 Total salaries and allowances $271,914.17

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the treasurer, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of payments for medical services for those pensioners holding health benefit cards in (a) 1979-80, and (b) 1980-81.
(2) What was the actual cost of payments for hospital services for pensioners holding health benefit cards in (a) 1979-80, and (b) 1980-81.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is estimated that the cost of Commonwealth medical benefits (CMB) for those pensioners holding pensioner health benefits (PHB) cards in 1979-80 and 1980-81 was of the order of $240m and $310m respectively. This estimate is made on the basis of total Commonwealth Medical Benefits expenditure paid through both the direct billing mode and the funds on the basis of available statistical information.

(2) Under the health insurance arrangements operating in 1979-80 and 1980-81, all uninsured Australians were eligible for free public hospital accommodation and treatment by doctors employed by the hospitals. Commonwealth costs for pensioners with PHB entitlement and for other uninsured patients are not available separately. Similarly the Commonwealth's private hospital bed day payment (then $16 per day) was paid in respect of all Australians and separate figures for pensioners with PHB entitlement are not available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is there any proof that some finance organisations in Australia are favouring loan applications from married couples when the wife is prepared to undergo a sterilization operation; if so, what action is the Government taking to prevent such a discrimination practice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of any proof of practices of the kind mentioned in the honourable senator's question although I have noted recent Press reports concerning the alleged practices.

I am advised that neither the Office of Women's Affairs nor the Trade Practices Commission have received any complaints about the alleged practice. Apart from any misleading or deceptive surrounding circumstances, the alleged practice would be unlikely to constitute a contravention of the Trade Practices Act.

State Governments have legislation dealing with the provision of credit and I note provisions in both the new Victorian and New South Wales consumer credit legislation which relate to disciplinary action of credit providers if they engage in dishonest or unfair practices. I also note a reference in a recent Press report (Sydney Daily Telegraph, 2 December 1981) to consideration of the alleged practice by the NSW Anti-Discrimination Board.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does a 30 per cent import duty presently apply to the brand of insulin syringes imported from the United States and most favoured by diabetics in Australia, if so, will this duty be reduced; and if not, will the Minister for Health consider some other way of reducing the cost burden to diabetics, varying between 15c and 40c per day in addition to the cost of their insulin, because of the cost of the necessary syringes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is sympathetic to the needs of diabetics and is mindful of the costs to the patient in the management of diabetes. Consideration has been given to ways and means by which Government assistance can be given in meeting the cost of special equipment required by diabetics, such as insulin syringes. However, the current economic situation has necessitated policies of restraint in public expenditure. In view of this, it is not possible for the Government to commit itself to additional programs, such as assistance with the cost of insulin syringes. Nevertheless this matter will be kept under reveiw.
In the meantime, I understand that some diabetic associations make insulin syringes and needles available to insulin-dependent diabetics at a concessional rate.

Concerning the import duty on syringes, I understand that duty of 30 per cent does currently apply to insulin syringes imported from the United States. However, the question of any reduction in this duty should be directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

(2) Since that date has there been a drop in the numbers of passengers between: (a) Canberra and Sydney; and (b) Sydney and Canberra.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Air fare increases based on the Holcroft Report recommendations came into force on 1 April 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government know exactly what herbicides were used in Vietnam, and at what strengths were they used.
(2) Does the Government know the exact strength of all the contaminants in those herbicides and what were the levels of those contaminants as compared to current permissible levels in Australia.
(3) Does the Government know (a) where exactly every load of herbicide was sprayed or dumped; (b) date and time of spraying or dumping.
(4) Does the Government have exact records of all troop movements in Vietnam down to the smallest patrol, including the exact timing.
(5) Does the Government have all the meteorological data from Vietnam to make use of any wind drift tables.
(6)Does the Government have the necessary flow data on all streams and rivers in Vietnam, that may have been used by Australian troops to fill water bottles.
(7) Were all water points regularly checked for herbicide contamination.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Information on pesticides used in Vietnam and Australia is contained in a report prepared by the Department of Health and Entitled, ' Pesticides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and their Use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study'. A copy of this report is in the Parliamentary Library.

(3) Information on the spraying of herbicides by United States fixed-wing aircraft is held by the Commonwealth Institute of Health. This information includes the date, location, type of agent, quantity, purpose of mission and map grid co-ordinate for each flight.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What were the reasons for refusing the recommendation of the Administrative Review Council that in social security matters there should be right of appeal directly to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where both parties (the applicant and the Director-General of Social Security) agree, or where the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is satisfied that special circumstances exist which would justify a direct appeal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I wrote to the Chairman of the Administrative Review Council on 16 December 1980 informing the Council why this particular recommendation had not been accepted. The substantive parts of that letter were as follows:

The Minister for Social Security and I gave very careful consideration to the views expressed by the Council but we were unable to accept the Council's recommendation. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal (Social Services Act) Regulations (Amendment), which have now been made, have been drawn on the basis that for the time being the Social Security Appeals Tribunals are the most suitable initial avenue for external review of the vast majority of Social Security decisions. In our view, it is only in exceptional cases, where it is clear that an important principle of general application is involved and the case would ultimately need to be determined by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in any event, that an appeal should be able to be taken directly to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal without prior consideration by a Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The Minister and I were concerned to ensure that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should not be seen as the general review tribunal for all cases and I would not wish to see the Tribunal President forced to determine large numbers of applications for direct access to the Tribunal. I was also concerned that the Council's recommendation might give rise to difficulties in relation to the operation of sections 14 and 15 of the Social Services Act 1947.

I would add that, notwithstanding our decision not to accept the Council's recommendation in this case, it will, of course, be open to a person dissatisfied with a decision of the Director-General of Social Services ultimately to take his case to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. But in the absence of a certificate from the Director-General he will only be able to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal after his case has first been considered by a Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps have been taken till 18 November 1981, towards the establishment of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, as mentioned in the First Annual Report of the Australian Federal Police, for the year 1979-80.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI) was formally established on 6 February 1981 as a result of an agreement signed that day by the Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Ministers for Police.
The Director, Mr F. A. Silvester, and the Deputy Director, Mr W. Williams, were both appointed on 11 May 1981.

Under its charter, the ABCI is to provide facitlities for the collection, collation, analysis and dissemination of criminal intelligence to the police forces of the Commonewealth, the States and the Northern Territory to enable them to combat organised crime in Australia, and in particular, to assist them to combat illicit drug trafficking.

The ABCI, which is located in Canberra, is staffed by police officers seconded from the police forces of the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory and, where appropriate, officers seconded from other agencies. Its permanent administrative staff are provided by the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funds have been allocated by the Federal Government to New South Wales for expenditure for developmental roads in 1981-82.
(2) Who determines the way in which these funds are allocated.

(c) Two new projects on the East-West Road between Narrabri and Bourke (Trunk Road 68 and Main Road 343), that assists the development of primary industries in north-western New South Wales-$1,500,000.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the application of Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act item 100(1) result in unfair competition between manufacturers who are liable to pay sales tax, and those who are not by virtue of having a total sales value of less than $12,000.

(2) What steps are taken to ensure that small manufacturers with sales tax exemptions for their products do not exploit this situation by concealing cash transactions which would raise their total turnover above the $12,000 limit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Persons whose goods are exempt under this item 100 (1) are small manufacturers, generally in cottage industries. They are required to pay sales tax on purchases of raw materials and aids to manufacture.
In view of the limit on the annual value of sales and the fact that inputs are taxed the application of the sales tax law is not considered to result in unfair competition.

(2) An annual review of exemptions under item 100 (1) is conducted by the Taxation Office. The Commissioner of Taxation has stated that his officers also check individual businesses either directly or indirectly and persons found to be outside the terms of the item are required to register and account for sales tax on their sales.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it proposed to reduce the number of social workers in regional Department of Social Security offices by up to 50 per cent; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Review of Neighbourhood Child Care Centres

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the guidelines of the Review of Neighbourhood Child Care Centres when it was established by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle just prior to the 1980 election.
(2) What were the limitations, if any, put on the type of recommendations which could be submitted by departmental staff.
(3) What restrictions have now been put on this review's guidelines.
(4) Were the community organisations led to believe that there would be no restrictions and that funding would be allocated according to demonstrated need in neighbourhood child care centres.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The Federal Government is concerned to see that funds allocated for social welfare are expended responsibly and properly. Consequently reviews of programs funded through my department are necessary and are an essential mechanism in this process. The review of the neighbourhood centres established by the former Minister for Social Security, Senator the Honourable Dame Margaret Guilfoyle DBE, is one such example, and it is part of the internal workings of my department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In a dispute between an overseas buyer and an Australian exporter of meat, what role does the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) take in settling the dispute.
(2) Does the AMLC have representatives in meat importing countries who are in a position to determine the facts in disputes between buyers and sellers.

(3) Is the AMLC representative's report made available to both buyers and sellers, or is it made available only to the Australian exporter; if it is made available only to the Australian exporter, why is this so.
(4) What action can the AMLC take to assist an overseas buyer in obtaining redress through the Australian legal system if the exporter will not agree to an 'amicable settlement' of the dispute.
(5) When complaints are lodged concerning imports of Australian meat, what action does the AMLC take with regard to the exporter.
(6) Is the AMLC action restricted to putting pressure on the exporter.
(7) Is the exporter's licence reviewed.
(8) In the past 5 years, how many export meat licences have been cancelled by the AMLC in each year from 1975 to 1981.
(9) In each such case, what was the reason for the cancellation of the licence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Corporation aims to bring the parties together to attempt to reach an amicable settlement. Corporation staff attempt to establish fact from documents and by inspection of the product in dispute. The number of complaints received by the Corporation is minor in relation to the volume of meat exported.

(2) Yes. The Corporation has regional offices in London, Bahrain, Singapore, Tokyo and New York. Staff of these offices undertake inspections and enquiries to assist in settling of trade complaints arising within their region.

(3) The report is submitted to AMLC Sydney, then passed to the exporter involved. In cases where the AMLC officer involved is confident that there is no valid claim he may inform the importer to that effect. If the importer requests a copy of the report such request is referred to the exporter and unless there is a sound commercially sustainable objection, a copy is provided to the importer. A copy is often supplied by the exporter to the importer in the course of their negotiations.

The report is directed initially to the exporter, first because the AMLC considers the exporter to be the responsible party, and secondly, because a prime function of the Corporation is to assist the Australian meat export industry in the conduct and promotion of its business.

(4) AMLC could seldom be confident that it has full knowledge of all the facts of a commercial transaction between the contracting parties. Consequently, it considers that legal action to settle commercial disputes is a matter for the parties. AMLC product inspection reports, on occasions, have been made available for use in such legal proceedings.

(5) The AMLC initially contacts the exporter seeking a responsible approach to satisfaction of the contract arrangements. Should the facts reveal exporter negligence in negotiating or meeting product specifications, AMLC may place the exporter under quality assurance surveillance for a specified period.
(6) Yes in most cases where it appears that the exporter is at fault. See also answers to questions 5 and 7.
(7) The exporter's licence can be suspended or cancelled if he is found to have breached a condition of his licence.
(8) Only one licence has been cancelled. The cancellation was effective from 1 September 1981. In each year several licences not being utilised were not renewed.

(9) Licence No. 283 was cancelled for a breach of a condition to which the licence was subject, namely an AMLC direction issued pursuant to S. 11 of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act requiring each licensee to '. . . ensure that the class, quality, standard, grading and preparation of any meat for export in his name is as specified in any agreement (whether in writing or otherwise) for the sale or supply of that meat'. The breach concerned the inclusion of horse meat in an export consignment to the USA.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Why was the Trade Practices Consultative Committee disbanded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Trade Practices Consultative Committee was established to advise the Government on matters related to the operation of the Trade Practices Act.

The Consultative Committee has completed its reports on the two major matters which were referred to it (references to advise on principles to be applied in considering possible exemptions for primary industry from the Trade Practices Act, and on any action in relation to the Act which should be taken to improve the market position of small business in Australia).

The Government has given very careful and detailed consideration to these reports and to the Consultative Committee's recommendations. On 15 November 1981 I announced the Government's decisions on these matters.
There were no outstanding references to the Consultative Committee or further matters which I considered appropriate for reference to it.

For this reason, and bearing in mind the policies enunciated by the Prime Minister in his statement to the Parliament on 30 April 1981 about the Review of Commonwealth Functions, it was decided that the Consultative Committee should not be further continued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Treasurer seen the statement in the 'West Australian National Country Party News', that the Bank of New South Wales has provided the National Country Party with a $200,000 loan free of interest at least until 1 July 1983.
(2) Is an interest free loan a de facto donation from the Bank to the National Country Party.
(3) Would an ordinary donation from the Bank to the National Country Party be deductible from the Bank's taxable income.
(4) Would the interest received if the $200,000 was lent to a commercial client have been recorded as profit to the Bank, and therefore liable to company tax.
(5) Does this arrangement breach the Income Tax Assessment Act; if so, will the Commissioner of Taxation ensure that the arrangement is not a tax evasion exercise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Treasurer's attention has been drawn to the article.
(2) Whether an interest free loan contains any gift element is a question that can only be determined in the light of all the circumstances of a particular case.
(3) Donations to political parties are not allowable tax deductions.
(4) Interest is income subject to tax.

(5) Parliament has vested the general administration of the income tax law in the Commissioner of Taxation but has imposed secrecy requirements which prevent him from divulging information about any person's taxation affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Transport been drawn to an article in the 29 August 1981 edition of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization Journal ECOS entitled 'Lead in Petrol: where does it go?'

(2) Have oil companies been approached to discuss the possibilities for reducing the lead content in petrol; if so, what were the results of these discussions; if not, is it intended to hold such discussions in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Implementation of a program to reduce the lead content in petrol is a matter for individual State and Territory governments. Although the Commonwealth endorses the February 1981 resolution of the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) calling in part for an early progressive reduction in the lead content of petrol it has no appropriate legislative capacity with respect to the States and Northern Territory regarding this matter. Under this resolution State and Territory governments will require the use of unleaded petrol for passanger cars and derivatives manufactured from 1 January 1986.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Federal Police had drawn to its attention an allegation by Mr Jack Boyd, M.P., that people were being illegally enrolled in the Byron electorate in the State of New South Wales.
(2) Have the Federal Police been asked to investigate the matter; if so, (a) have they completed their investigations; and (b) what is the result of any such investigation.

(3) Will the Minister for Administrative Services refer this question to the Federal Police immediately and ensure a reply is forwarded to Senator McClelland during the forthcoming Parliamentary recess.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) In August 1981 an allegation was made that a person had apparently attempted to secure an electoral enrolment, to which he was not entitled, for an address in the Federal division of Richmond which encompasses the New South Wales State electorate of Byron. The Australian Electoral Office referred the matter to the Australian Federal Police for investigation. In the event there was no impropriety. The person concerned is, and at all relevant times was, living in the division and had simply incorrectly completed an electoral claim card seeking enrolment at 'No. 7' instead of 'No. 17'.

In November 1981 allegations were received by the Australian Electoral Office regarding a further seven apparent enrolment irregularities in the division of Richmond. From enquiries conducted by the Australian Electoral Office it would appear that some of the people concerned have in fact lost their enrolment entitlement by reason of having since moved. In the remaining cases the Australian Electoral Officer's preliminary enquiries indicated that the enrolments in question should be further investigated and they have been referred to the Australian Federal Police.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Have the three meat inspector positions referred to in Question on Notice No. 1431 been filled; if not, will they be filled. (see Senate Hansard, dated 12 November 1981, page 2179).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Was there a near collision between an Ansett Airlines aircraft and a Malaysian aircraft at Sydney Airport on 3 October 1981; if so; (a) what were the circumstances of the near collision; and (b) has any enquiry been held or is it proposed to hold an enquiry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A report has been received of the air safety incident at Sydney Airport on 3 October, 1981, involving a Malaysian aircraft and an Ansett Airlines aircraft but there was no 'near collision'. The Malaysian Airlines DC10 aircraft was on final approach for landing on runway 34 but, because a preceding landing aircraft had not cleared the runway, Air Traffic Control instructed it to discontinue the approach, turn right on to a northerly heading, and to climb to 2000 feet. However, the aircraft was subsequently observed to continue the right turn towards the east. At that time, an arriving Ansett Airlines Boeing 737 aircraft was east of the airport on a southerly heading. Air Traffic Control took immediate action to ensure safe separation between the two aircraft. The incident is being investigated by the Air Safety Investigation Branch of my Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon Notice, on 24 November 1981:
