(2) What is the financial standing of the Tansey abattoir.
(3) Does the abattoir pay some of its small producers with cheques that have to be sent back to the bank several times before they are honoured.
(4) Does this particular production unit not weigh some of the cattle and are proper records not kept; if so, is this contrary to any State or Federal law.
(5) Has the Tansey abattoir now been given a knackery licence and will this also be extended to kangaroo meat.
(6) Will there be any assurance given that both horse meat and/or kangaroo meat will not be disposed of on the domestic or export markets.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) (a) In Queensland, the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry has responsibility only for meat plants which are registered for export. Any non -export abattoirs such as that at Tansey are under the jurisdiction of the State Department of Primary Industries. For specific answers to the points raised I would suggest the honourable senator direct his inquires to the Hon. M. J. Ahern , M.P., the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries.

(b) In February 1980 an initial inquiry was recieved by the Australian Bureau of Animal Health from a Mr Gaudry, who was then manager of Tansey Wholesale Meat Supplies (Gold Coast) Pty Ltd, on what was required to have premises registered as an export game meat plant. No subsequent contact occurred, and no premises in Tansey is registered for export.
(6) (a) I am satisfied that the measures recently introduced by the Australian Bureau of Animal Health in response to the meat substitution findings will ensure non export meat is not exported.

(b) The Australian Bureau of Animal Health is species testing meat produced on export plants which is subsequently diverted to the domestic market. I am unable to provide any information on any species testing the Queensland Department of Primary Industries may be carrying out on meats under its control.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have recent events in the meat industry had an effect on both the production and processing of beef in Queensland.

(2) Does the Minister for Primary Industry and his predecessor in the present government have close ties with senior members of the United Graziers Association and also the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation.
(3) Are a number of Queensland graziers involved in beef processing as well as beef production; if so, does this constitute a conflict of interest which could act as a detriment to the beef industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of any 'recent events' which have had major lasting effects on the Queensland beef industry. The meat substitution matter interfered with export marketing for a short time, particularly to the United States of America, but the United States market price quickly returned to previous levels once Australian meat was released on to that market again. The other effect flowing from that matter is that meatworks are now incurring some extra cost from the additional security measures which have been imposed. Another recent event was the Commonwealth meat inspector strike which brought export meat production to a halt for one week during November.

(2) Any Minister for Primary Industry, by virtue of his portfolio responsibilities, is likely to be acquainted with some members of the United Graziers Association and of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. I am personally acquainted although not closely with several members of both organisations.

(3) I understand that some meat processing companies have grazing properties in Queensland. Such vertical integration could operate to the detriment of independent cattle producers if it was on such a scale as to substantially reduce competition in the market for cattle. No information laid before me suggests that is the case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 2 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the credentials of abattoir owners ever checked before licences are issued for the treatment and packaging of kangaroo and horse meat.
(2) Is Northern Territory buffalo meat and north Queensland donkey meat processed at any abattoirs in Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) So far as export abattoirs and game preparation establishments are concerned, credentials of owners are not checked prior to registration. Export registration is tied to the premises, is dependent upon the premises complying with structural and other provisions of the Exports (Meat) Regulations, and is in the name of the occupier or owner. I am unable to provide an answer with respect to horse abattoirs and kangaroo processing plants registered by State authorities.
(2) (a) I understand that feral buffalo numbers in Queensland are very low, and am advised that buffalo slaughter for meat production is currently limited to the Northern Territory.

(b) No export abattoirs in Queensland are currently registered to slaughter horses or donkeys. One registered export game establishment is located in Queensland but it has not and will not be permitted to process donkey meat.
(c) I am advised that no donkey meat is being processed on premises under the control of the Queensland Department of Primary Industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What were the dates and times of consultations the Minister for Health and his Department had with the Australian Medical Association regarding the extension of free cards and the introduction of health care cards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I consult bodies which are likely to be affected by Government proposals in the health care field, as and when necessary. In regard to the widening of the eligibility provisions for pensioner health benefits cards and Health Benefits cards (which are issued to sickness beneficiaries) I normally discuss the matter with senior members of the AMA executive. That does not necessarily mean I first obtain the Association's agreement to the proposal; the Government acts in the interests of all concerned in the community, particularly the users of health services.

In regard to the health care card initiative, introduced on 1 September 1981, the federal executive of the AMA was indeed consulted when changes to the arrangements for those in special need were being considered, and its views were taken into account.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government in the funding for the school to work transition program make any stipulation to the States as to where the funds should be spent and, in particular, the sorts of schools that should receive funding and the criteria of need that decide those schools; if so, how is need assessed, for example, would schools in areas of high youth unemployment be more likely to be funded than other schools.
(2) What criteria is used by each State to distribute the available funds.
(3) Are there instances where funds are being absorbed into existing State educational programs rather than being spent directly on pre-vocational programs ; if so what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) State and non-government authorities participating in the transition program are required to allocate funds consistent with the guidelines for the program which have been agreed between the Commonwealth and the States. The guidelines do not specify criteria for selection of schools to be funded. They indicate, however, that the primary concern of the program is for young people who leave school each year with poor employment prospects. The program should provide education and training with a work orientation, where appropriate, for these young people and also tackle the problem of those in the schools who are likely to be in similar difficulties when it comes their turn to leave. The guidelines indicate that proposals for funding in the school sector may encompass a range of activities including provision of alternative courses; career guidance and counselling, work experience projects, teacher development and curriculum development. The guidelines say that while the boundary between transition education and general education in schools is not easy to draw, it is necessary for program funding purposes for proposals to focus on skills and/or activities clearly relevant to the transition of young people to working life.

In allocating funds to individual schools, State authorities should take into account a number of factors including regional and local characteristics such as youth unemployment rates. However, it must be kept in mind that transition education in secondary schools is not primarily concerned with training young people for specific jobs in the workforce. Therefore, the local levels of youth unemployment are less significant for determining distribution of funds among schools than is the case with the provision of transition courses in technical and further education colleges.
I will make a copy of the program guidelines available to the honourable senator.
(2) States are expected to observe the various criteria included in the program guidelines in distributing the available funds.

(3) There are many instances where transition program funds are being used to expand or improve existing State transition programs. However, States may not use transition program funds to substitute for activities previously funded from State sources.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the Iwasaki beef production interests in the central Queensland region have an agreement with a local export meat processing firm for the killing of cattle produced on the Iwasaki properties, the processing of the beef and its export to Japan.
(2) Is the processed beef then deducted from the regular meat export quota between Australia and Japan.
(3) Is the processed beef independently sold by Iwasaki interests in Japan or is it disposed of through normal channels and dealers when it arrives in that country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of any arrangements between the Iwasaki interests in Queensland and any export meat processing firm for the preparation of beef for export to Japan. Such arrangements, if they exist, would be commercially confidential between the interested parties. The preparation of meat for export is subject to controls under the Exports (Meat) Regulations and must be prepared in a registered export establishment.

(2) All beef exported by Australia to Japan enters that country under a global import quota. There is no regular meat export quota between Japan and Australia. In 1980-81 Australia supplied 93,000 tonnes or some 74 per cent of total Japanese imports of beef and veal of 125,000 tonnes.

(3) Apart from a small percentage (around 10 per cent) all beef and veal imports into Japan and their distribution are controlled by the Livestock Industry Promotion Corporation, a semi-government authority.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the report on poverty measurement (at page 142) criticise the lack of Australian data and call for an extension of the proposed household expenditure 'in the middle of the decade'; if so, what steps is the Government taking in planning the survey to:
(a) upgrade the sample size of the proposed survey;
(b) extend the scope of the questionnaire to be used; and
(c) provide additional resources to ABS to develop other measures of income and expenditure inequalities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Although the report on poverty measurement (page 142) contains some suggestions about enhancing the usefulness of the proposed Australian Bureau of Statistics survey on household income and expenditure, it does not specifically criticise the lack of Australian data.

The Statistician plans to commence detailed design of the survey in July 1982 and as a preliminary step users will be consulted concerning the data they would like. The size and scope of the survey will depend on the range of user requirements thus identified, taking into account financial and other resource costs, together with the need to minimise response burden and to avoid undue intrusion of the privacy of informants.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister say in answer to Question on Notice No. 1243 that as a result of Australia Post's incorrect advice a Mr Blackett-Ord had 'suffered no loss of expected income'.
(2) Did Mr Blackett-Ord suffer a loss of value in his capital investment in a non-official post office.

(3) Whether or not Australia Post is legally bound to compensate Mr Blackett- Ord for loss of his capital, would it be the honourable thing to do, to compensate him fully for all loss consequent on Australia Post's mistake.
(4) Has Australia Post requested any legal advice on this matter; if so, what was the nature of the advice sought and what was the advice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The terms and conditions of appointment as non-official postmaster include a provision that a post office has no monetary value and cannot be disposed of by sale from one person to another. This precludes any capital investment in a non-official post office business. Prior to his appointment as non-official postmaster, Mr Blackett-Ord was advised formally of these conditions. He acknowledged that advice in writing.

Mr Blackett-Ord's capital investment related to his purchase of the sub- newsagency business in conjunction with which the Mount Lewis non-official post office had been conducted. Any loss of value of that capital investment would have related to the purchase and re-sale of the sub-newsagency.

(3) As explained in (2) above, Mr Blackett-Ord's capital investment related to the sub-newsagency business and not to the non-offical post office. Australia Post considers it has no obligation, legal or otherwise, to compensate Mr Blackett-Ord for any alleged loss of capital investment associated with the purchase and re-sale of that sub-newsagency business.

As explained in my answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 1243 which appeared at page 2739 of Hansard of 26 November 1981, Mr Blackett-Ord was compensated fully for any loss of expected income while he held the appointment of non- official postmaster at Mount Lewis.
(4) Yes. The Attorney-General's Department has been consulted on the question of entitlement to compensation for loss of expected income and for capital loss.

The legal advice given was that Australia Post could legally vary the rate of remuneration payable to Mr Blackett-Ord to match the amount quoted in the original notice of appointment. This was done and Mr Blackett-Ord suffered no loss of expected income during the whole period of his appointment as non- official postmaster at Mount Lewis.

Formal and detailed advice was given to Mr Blackett-Ord's solicitors by the Attorney-General's Department, on behalf of Australia Post, that no claim for loss of capital or other damages could be entertained.

(6) What are the answers to (1), (2), (3), (4) and (5) for all new postal boxes installed by Australia Post since 1 January 1976.
(7) Has there been any change in the criteria according to which Australia Post decides to install, or remove a postal box, if so what are the details of criteria before and after that change.
(8) As a result of any of those changes will postal boxes be removed in the near future at a rate which is greater than it was in the recent past, for example from 1 January to 31 December 1980.
(9) As a result of any of those changes will postal boxes be installed in the near future at a rate which is greater than it was in the recent past, for example from 1 January to 31 December 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Approximately 2200 posting boxes were withdrawn during the period 1 January 1976 to 31 December 1981.
(2) Records of individual locations are not available but a breakdown of the total by State and metropolitan/non-metropolitan area follows:
NSW Vic. Qld SA WA Tas. Total
(3) and (4) Detailed records are not available.

(5) The posting boxes were withdrawn in accordance with Australia Post's policy which is designed to ensure an optimum network of postal facilities, meeting the changing needs of the community. A posting box may be withdrawn where less than 30 articles are posted per day and where alternative posting facilities are located within 800 metres road distance. It has been the practice, however, since early 1980, to consider for withdrawal only those posting boxes in which less than 10 articles are posted each day.

(Note: The special needs of the aged, the sick and the disabled are taken into account wherever possible. Street posting boxes have not been withdrawn, under normal circumstances, if located near a hospital, an elderly people's home or an institution, etc, which caters to the needs of the aged or disabled.)

NSW Vic. Qld SA WA Tas. Total

(v) See (5) above for Australia Post's policy objective.
A new box may be provided beyond 800 metres road distance of an existing posting facility, provided at least 30 articles a day could be expected to be posted in it.
The preferred locations for posting boxes are shopping centres, busy commercial and industrial areas, transport terminals and large institutions such as hospitals.

(7) The criteria for installing and withdrawing posting boxes have not changed for some years, with one exception. As mentioned in (5) above, the ciriteria for withdrawing posting boxes have, since early 1980, been modified in practice, so that only posting boxes receiving less than 10 articles daily are now considered for withdrawal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is The Minister for Health aware of recent concern about the use in Australia of urea formaldehyde foam (insulation) sprayed into buildings.
(2) Has Canada banned the use of such insulation.
(3) In a survey of one thousand homes in Connecticut was it found that thirty per cent of the occupants suffered continuous adverse health symptoms.
(4) Have similar symptoms been reported in Australia.
(5) Are these symptoms due to emissions of formaldehyde gas.
(6) Is this insulation being used in housing and government buildings in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Acting Minister for Health, I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of recent concern about the use of urea formaldehyde foam insulation sprayed into buildings.
(2) Canada has banned the use of urea formaldehyde foam insulation until the government is satisfied that manufacturers are able to produce a product which is stable and can be used safely.

(3) I am unable to confirm that there was such a survey in Connecticut. However , two scientific papers concerning surveys conducted in Connecticut refer to the investigation of a total of 173 complaints which alleged associated health effects. It is reported that individuals in 65 per cent of the households investigated continued to experience symptoms an average of 2.3 years after installation of the foam.
(4) Similar symptoms have been claimed in Australia and have been brought to the attention of the National Health and Medical Research Council.

The matter has already been considered by the relevant committees of the Council and on their advice the Council has established an expert working party to investigate the potential health effects of the use of the foam in Australia. Data is being assembled for consideration by the Working Party in early February 1982.
(5) It is not known whether these symptoms are due to emissions of formaldehyde gas but they are similar to those classically associated with formaldehyde toxicity.
(6) This insulation is being used in Australia. However, as far as can be ascertained urea formaldehyde foam insulation has not been used in major Commonwealth buildings.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Science and Technology: Contract Work

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What functions of the Department under the Minister's supervision are now performed on a regular basis by private contractors and have been taken over from Commonwealth employees since:
(a) The report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions.
(b) January 1981.
(c) January 1980.
(d) January 1979.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No departmental functions are now being performed on a regular basis by private contractors which were previously performed by Commonwealth employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 (Hansard, page 826) Senator Lewis asked me , as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Why was it necessary to purchase a house in the suburb of East Killara which, I understand, is in New South Wales?
Why was it necessary to purchase a house for $140,000 to accomodate a senior defence officer of the Army?
Are there any adjacent military establishments which would require the purchase of a house in this prime location?
What is the normal cost of building a house to defence standards on government land for senior officers?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The house was acquired by the Department of Defence for use by a senior Navy officer appointed to any one of the several naval establishments in the vicinity of Sydney Harbour. There is an acute shortage of housing which is reasonably close to such establishments, and which meets the standards appropriate for senior Service officers.

The house was transferred to the Department of Defence from a Commonwealth authority which previously owned it (the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation). The transfer followed procedures which normally apply in such situations: After notification that the Corporation no longer required the house, the Department of Administrative Services asked other Commonwealth departments if they had a need for it, before considering its disposal. Thus, although the house was transferred to the Department of Defence at its taxation valuation ($140,000), the acquisition involved no additional outlay by the Commonwealth, in real terms.
The current cost of building a house to standards appropriate for senior officers is around $54,000. To this would be added the cost of land, which would vary with the location.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 (Hansard, page 824) Senator Macklin asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the result of the United States Department of Commerce countervailing duty investigation against Australian lamb exports.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Following the withdrawal of the joint petition, alleging that the Australian Government grants subsidies to producers and exporters of meat, by the United States National Woolgrowers' Association and the United States National Lamb Feeders' Association the United States Department of Commerce formally terminated the investigation on 1 October 1981. From this date all bonds posted since the preliminary determination was made in July have been released. It is understood that similar action against New Zealand has also been withdrawn. I am personally very pleased as is the Government to see the end of this matter.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting: Police Exercises

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1981 (Hansard, page 844) Senator Primmer asked the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: How many Victorian police recruits have been injured in unarmed combat and other exercises carried out in preparation for the security arrangements surrounding the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting? What was the nature of their injuries?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Nine Victorian police recruits were injured in training exercises for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. All of the injuries were of a minor nature only, and no recruit was absent from duty as a result.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1981 (Hansard, pages 849-850) Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the high rate of epidural anaesthetics used in childbirth, and the possible side effects of local anaesthetics on the newborn child.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

It is claimed that epidural anaesthesia using local anaesthetics can render childbirth painless and has advantages in protecting the unborn child (foetus) from undesirable side effects which may result from over breathing by the mother. It is also claimed to reduce the adverse effects of stress on the muscle tone of the womb. In expert hands, using carefully selected anaesthetic agents at optimal doses, epidural anaesthesia can thus be argued to be of benefit to both mother and child.

The Secretariat of the National Health and Medical Research Council has recently carried out a preliminary search of the scientific literature relating to the possible effects of local anaesthetic agents on the foetus and the newborn child. The search has indicated that under certain circumstances adverse effects on the foetus and/or the newborn children have been reported which may be attributable to the use of local anaesthetic agents administered during childbirth by a variety of techniques, including the epidural route.

The matter is, however, quite complex, and I agree that there would be an advantage to the community in having it subjected to proper scientific evaluation. Accordingly, I have arranged for the matter to be referred to the appropriate committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council for evaluation and report.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-Police Activities

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard, page 889) Senator Keeffe asked me a question, in several parts, relating to alleged police activities during the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM). In accordance with the undertaking I gave at the time, I referred the question, so far as it may have had some relevance to the Australian Federal Police Force, to the Minister for Administrative Services. The Minister's response appears at page 2181 of Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: I also undertook to give consideration to any aspects of the question relating to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. I now advise that no members of the organisation were sworn in as members of the Victoria Police Force during CHOGM.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1265) Senator Hamer asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Education a question without notice concerning the Tertiary Student Loans Scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government approved its intention to introduce a tertiary student loans scheme in 1982. Details of the scheme are currently being worked out in consultation with the banks. I am aware that the British Government considered a report on a proposed student loans scheme but I understand decided not to proceed. The scheme being proposed for Australian tertiary students would differ from the one considered by the British Government in that it will consist of bank loans with tertiary institutions playing a part in administration. Arrangements for the scheme, including eligibility requirements , will be announced at the earliest possible date once negotiations with all parties are complete.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1372) Senator Gietzelt asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice.

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of the need in the community for the provision of adequate child care and pre-school facilities? Will the Government take steps to encourage the use and development of child care and pre-school facilities by making provision for tax deductibility of such pre- school, kindergarten and child care facilities?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Where a pre-school, kindergarten or child care centre is predominantly a school providing full-time education appropriate to the age of the child, a taxpayer may claim, as rebatable expenditure eligible for the concessional rebate of 32 cents in the dollar to the extent that the total rebatable expenditure exceeds $1590, that part of the fees paid to the centre which relates to the education component of the service provided by the centre, up to a maximum of $250 per child per year.

In addition, where a public fund is established and maintained exclusively to provide money for the acquisition, construction or maintenance of a building used, or to be used, as a school by a government or public authority or by a society or association which is carried on otherwise than for the purposes of profit or gain to the individual members of that society or association, gifts of the value of two dollars or more to the funds are allowable deductions under the gift provisions of the income tax law. A fund established to provide for a building for use by a pre-school, kindergarten or child care centre as a school providing full-time education appropriate to the age of the children attending it, may qualify under this provision.

If, however, the honourable senator is proposing that an income tax deduction should be provided for expenses incurred by a parent or guardian for child care services provided by a pre-school, kindergarten or child care facility, this matter was considered by the Government in the deliberations preceding the 1981 -82 Budget. It was decided, however, that the budgetary position was such that it was not possible to include such a concession among the various proposals announced in the Budget speech.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1443) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to the outstanding Defence statement made by the Minister for Defence in the House of Representatives yesterday with reference to the intention to build two FFG-type ships at the Williamstown Naval Dockyard subject to satisfactory resolution of a number of problems affecting productivity there. This is a delightful euphemism which, of course, we would expect from this Minister. Can the Minister give the House an assurance that unless all doubts about Williamstown Naval Dockyard being able to honour its contracts are removed, by the unions entering into a legally binding undertaking not to strike, indulge in bans or demarcation disputes, the Government will place the two FFG follow-on destroyer contracts with other Australian yards? In this regard, will the Minister include North Queensland Engineers and Agents, the builders of the Fremantle class ships, with other Australian yards?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There are a number of options open to the Government concerning the construction of follow-on destroyers including building them at Williamstown Naval Dockyard or ordering them from the United States. There is also the possibility of construction in another Australian shipyard.

The facilities at WND have been extensively modernised over the last few years and are well suited for building Naval vessels of the FFG type. The workforce has skills specifically related to destroyer construction and these skills are important for the support of the fleet.
Nevertheless the Government has made it clear that orders for ships from WND are conditional on improved productivity. Improvement in industrial relations is an essential part of this.

Should the Government decide to build FODs at a yard other than WND, consideration will be given to the other construction options including building the ships at North Queensland Engineers and Agents and other Australian shipyards.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Union Ban: Flag of Convenience Ships

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1439) Senator Lewis asked me questions without notice concerning flag of convenience vessels, the bans applied to them and the costs of the bans. Further, he sought information about the Mineral Transporter and Department of Transport inspection procedures for overseas vessels.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with further information in answer to the honourable senator's questions:
Delays due to the flag of convenience bans have been as much as four months for vessels scheduled to load coal at Newcastle and Port Kembla.

The bans have resulted in the loss of some 2,000 ship days at a cost of about $25m. In addition to this, there could be costs related to the loss of coal export markets which would be difficult to quantify.

The Mineral Transporter was in Sydney from 16 July to 30 October 1981. Repairs made in order to comply with international regulations for safety at sea and the Navigation Act included temporary repairs for collision damage to the vessel in way of the forecastle and No. 2 Starboard Wing Ballast tank and repairs to the vessel's structure and equipment to make good deficiencies found in the inspection of the vessel. A list of the deficiencies found, other than damage caused by the collision is at Attachment 'A'.

In accordance with control provisions of the International Convention for Safety of Life at Sea, 1960, and the International Convention on Load Lines, 1966, Marine Surveyors of the Department of Transport carry out inspections of overseas ships in Australian ports. The inspections of vessels under the control provisions of the Convention are carried out in accordance with the guidelines published by the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organisation (IMCO).

The Department of Transport maintains a record of overseas ships which have been found not to comply with Convention requirements, when inspected in Australian ports. Details of such ships are forwarded to IMCO, the Flag State and the relevant Classification Society. A list of overseas ships found to be ' sub-standard' since 1 November 1979 is at Attachment 'B'.

The major areas of corrosion found on the 'Mineral Transporter' were related to side rails, catwalks, sounding pipes, engine room ventilators and hatch covers. There was also a considerable superficial wastage of the upper deck including equipment and fittings used for the former oil carrying function of the vessel. These fittings were not required for the voyage in question as the vessel was to transport coal.
