ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1537) Senator Watson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the Senate, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, by stating that it has been rumored that there is some slack at the Industries Assistance Commission because of the shortage of references before Commission. In the past the efficiency of private industry has been the target of some comment. Recognising the Commission's expertise in this area, will the Government consider putting a request to the Commission to report upon the efficiency and cost effectiveness of transport by sea and the impact that these costs have on Australian industry and the Australian economy.
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The IAC at this time has a very heavy workload. As well as having a number of industry specific references on hand it also has a number of major references with economy wide significance which are due for report early in 1982. These include the topics of general reductions in assistance to industry, budgetary assistance, export incentives and the customs bylaw system.

In relation to the particular question, in mid 1980 the Government asked Sir John Crawford to chair a committee of shipowner and union representatives aimed at identifying problems and suggesting ways to improve the commercial viability of Australian shipping.

The Government has now received the Committee's report entitled ' Revitalisation of Australian Shipping-An Overview' and will be examining the report and discussing its recommendations with the shipping industry. In these circumstances, a reference to the IAC on sea transport would be inappropriate at this time. I am advised that implementation of the 'Revitalisation' report would require significant changes in attitude by all parties to the industry, and to request a further report would impose unnecessary delays.

On the other hand the Government recognises the expertise of the IAC and that it is an appropriate body to carry out inquiries on topics having economy wide implications. If the Government considers it necessary for further study on the efficiency and cost effectiveness of transport by sea, an IAC inquiry would certainly be an option which would be considered.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Air Services between Canberra and Sydney

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1538) Senator Reid asked me a question without notice concerning air services between Canberra and Sydney and their publicity.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

In view of the number of cancellations of Canberra services I raised the matter with both Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia and indicated in the strongest terms that such a practice is quite unacceptable to travellers and the Government.

The airlines have indicated that the demand for air travel on the Canberra- Sydney route has dropped markedly since higher air fares were introduced following consideration of the Holcroft Report. To cater more adequately for this reduced demand, both airlines have reduced by about 10 per cent the scheduled capacity on the routes to and from Canberra in their timetables which commenced on 25 October 1981.

With regard to the honourable senator's comments on advertising I understand the Airlines of New South Wales service introduced between Canberra and Sydney is being advertised. This, however, is a matter for the airline and I have no role in the corporate decisions which determine the amount of publicity to be given to each Ansett service.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines: Minor Route Services

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1634) Senator Watson asked me a question without notice concerning the withdrawal of Trans Australia Airlines from F27 routes and whether such withdrawals inevitably mean TAA's future will be with large aircraft servicing the major cities of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TAA has indicated for some time that many of its F27 services are unprofitable and require either cross-subsidisation or direct subsidy for services to continue, highlighting that services by other operators with smaller aircraft would be more suitable for these routes.

The transfer of these services to regional and commuter operators and the eventual phasing out of F27 aircraft from TAA's fleet will limit its ability to service some of the smaller centres. Based on the current position in regard to intrastate licensing in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia where TAA presently has no traffic rights, its present fleet planning provides for an eventual all jet fleet with a minimum aircraft size equivalent to the DC9. With this minimum aircraft size TAA will be capable of servicing some 30 major centres throughout Australia which together account for almost 94 per cent of scheduled passengers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1631) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice regarding the proposed new terminal at Hobart Airport and the erection of a special building, away from the present terminal, to serve existing traffic.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The possibility of modifying the existing terminal to cater for international traffic has been considered. The concept has the advantage to Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia of co-locating the international operation with their domestic operation. However, it involves a continuation of the present unsatisfactory arrangement where furnishings are shifted before and after every international flight and requires closure of the present public area during international operations. It has no capacity for expansion and it would be almost impossible to allow use by operators other than TAA and Ansett. The proposal is less than desirable from an aviation security aspect and is strongly opposed by Customs, Health, Immigration and Federal Police.

The Department of Transport proposal is for a separate building, some forty metres north of the existing terminal, of a size suitable for existing traffic, but with the capability of being expanded should this be needed in the future. The building can be constructed and operated without affecting domestic traffic and public convenience. This proposal is also favoured from the user Department and Aviation Security aspects. Either proposal is of the same order of cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1981 (Hansard, pages 1631-1632) Senator Sibraa asked me a question without notice concerning Canberra-Sydney air services and, in particular, whether the Government would consider giving East-West Airlines full access to Sydney-Canberra and Sydney-Melbourne routes in order to improve services and lower fares.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Government is committed to the continuation of the two-airline policy. This was ratified by this Parliament in the passing of the Airlines Agreement Act 1981.

Provisions were included in the 1972 Airlines Agreement which then applied to allow operators such as East-West to seek the Minister's approval to provide services over trunk routes. It was on the basis of being a specialist service that East-West applied for and received approval for the 'no frills' service between Sydney and Canberra.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1715) Senator Robert Ray asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning population coverage and effectiveness of the health insurance arrangements. I undertook to pass to the Minister for Social Security that aspect of the question relating to the take-up of health care cards. An answer to that was provided on 24 November (Hansard, p. 2442).

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information in respect of the population coverage:

On the basis of information available to my Department at this stage, indications are that approximately 11 per cent of the population for medical and seven per cent for hospital may not have cover through either registered private health insurance funds or equivalent Commonwealth Government assistance at 31 October 1981. These figures are preliminary and are based on a sample of health funds. Therefore, they may be subject to later variation.
The estimated position of the proportion of the population covered by the various categories is as follows:
per cent per cent Basic private insurance with registered funds
67.5 71.6 Pensioners and dependants 13.4 13.4 Unemployed 3.4 3.4 Low income and migrants (1) 2.0 2.0 Repatriation and Defence 2.5 2.5

Note-(1) The figure represents the estimated coverage of persons who have established eligibility as health care card holders. A further 1.3 per cent of the population could possibly be covered under the low income arrangements.
Of the estimated persons not covered (11 per cent for medical and seven per cent for hospital) further factors are relevant:
(a) free hospitalisation for Queensland residents and extension of eligibility for free hospitalisation in other States beyond requirements of Commonwealth; and
(b) some coverage (assumed to be minor) by unregistered commercial insurers.

The overriding aim of the Government's new health policy is to ensure that all persons living in Australia have access to high quality health care at a cost both the individual and the community can afford. The most equitable and appropriate means of achieving that goal is through a combination of special assistance schemes for those people in genuine need and for those who are not, the subsidisation of private health insurance to enable them to contribute towards their health costs.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Sales Tax on Record Produced by Debney Park High School

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1804) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It is a somewhat parochial question for Victorian senators. I refer the Minister to the fact that Debney Park High School is seeking to raise some $30,000 to $40,000 for a music scholarship fund, which is to be raised by selling a record featuring the Debney Park High School band, about which I think the Minister knows. I refer to the fact that almost all those involved in the project have given their services freely but, despite representations, the Treasurer has refused to exempt the record from sales tax, which amounts to 37c for each $2 record. I ask: Will the Minister take up this matter with the Treasurer again and make further representations to him about it?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There is a provision in the sales tax law that exempts goods for use and not for sale by a non-profit university or school. That provision, item 63A in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, does not extend to goods produced for sale by a school and there is no other provision in the law to exempt the record in question from sales tax.
There is no discretion vested in the Commissioner of Taxation to grant exemptions not authorised by the law. An amendment to the law would be required to provide the exemption sought.

Arrangements have been made for the matter to be brought forward in the next review of exemptions under the sales tax law. In the meantime the record in question will be subject to tax, as are other records with which it competes in the marketplace.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November 1981 (Hansard, page 1926) Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the health insurance arrangements as they affect overseas students in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The Government is aware of the various problems and difficulties faced by overseas students in Australia. However I would point out that as a result of the changes to the health insurance arrangements on 1 September 1981, the community generally is required to contribute to the cost of medical and hospital services-either by personal payment or through health insurance. An exception is made only in the case of pensioner health benefits cardholders and health care cardholders, who are eligible for free bulk-billed medical treatment and free treatment in public hospitals.

All overseas students may take out private health insurance upon their arrival in Australia and be eligible for fund benefits after a two month waiting period . No waiting period applies to the Commonwealth benefit of 30 per cent of the schedule fee. Students may also take out Australian private health insurance before they depart for Australia. In this respect they are in the same position as Australian residents.
The eligibility criteria under the Health Insurance Act in respect of overseas students, for health care card entitlement are as follows:
(a) applicants must be Australian residents; that is, their stay in Australia must have exceeded a total of six months in the 12 months preceding the time of application for a card;
(b) applicants must not be dependants in the sense of being a child for whom family allowance is payable or a spouse for whom additional unemployment benefit is or would be payable;
(c) applicants must not be wholly or substantially dependent on a resident of a country other than Australia; and
(d) applicants must meet the income test which applies to low income applicants for Health Care cards.

The Government believes that the criteria are fair and not ungenerous and ensure that students and their dependants who are in genuine need, and not under guarantee of financial support from persons or establishments outside Australia, will be covered under the health care card arrangements. All things considered, overseas students are treated no differently to their Australian counterparts.

Overseas students who are studying under Australian university (or other institutional) scholarships, where no specific allowance has been made in respect of reimbursement for hospital and medical expenses, are generally eligible for a health care card.

In regard to students who are holders of scholarships administered by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau or by the Commonwealth Department of Education, it should be noted that the sponsoring agency guarantees to cover the cost of all hospital and medical expenses for each student in excess of $45 in any one year. This arrangement also covered dependants of these students for the period 1 September 1981 to 1 November 1981. From 2 November 1981, however, dependants of these students are generally eligible for a health care card.

The Government is not prepared to provide free health care cover to overseas students for a set period after their arrival in Australia, or to disregard money received from home countries as income when assessing their eligibility for health care cards. Such a policy would provide concessions to overseas students which are not available to Australians, and would therefore represent an inappropriate charge on the public purse.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 November 1981 (Hansard, pages 2002-2003) Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the revised health insurance arrangements, which came into effect on 1 September 1981, as they affect remote Aboriginal communities.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

In formulating the new arrangements, detailed consideration was given to the requirements of persons in special need, including Aboriginals. It was decided that the issue of health care cards, which identify people as eligible for special assistance with their medical and hospital costs would be confined to persons meeting the following criteria:
1. Migrants or refugees in their first six months in Australia.
2. Unemployment or special benefit recipients with income, apart from benefit, not exceeding $40 per week (single) or $68 per week (married).
3. Low income earners (the current income limits are set out below; they are adjusted every May and November):
Married-joint income of less than $165 gross per week, including pension if any, plus $20 for each child.
Sole parent with one child-income of less than $165 gross per week, including pension if any, plus $20 for each additional child.
Single person-income of less than $99 gross per week, including pension if any .
There is no discretion in the legislation to recognise people other than those who meet these criteria.
A public awareness program was undertaken to inform the public of the new arrangements, including:
a direct telephone enquiry system for the cost of a local telephone call;

'self help' audio visual kits for use by Department of Social Security offices to enable special need groups (such as Aboriginal fringe dwellers and people in small towns) to learn of the new arrangements;
arrangements for departmental officers to participate in talk back, interview and other media programs on commercial, Australian Broadcasting Commission and ethnic radio and television;
provision of special briefings for media personalities conducting personal advice and welfare oriented columns or programs.

Briefings for doctors or their receptionists, social workers and public hospital staff, et cetera., have taken place to enable these people to assist persons identified as being in special need, including Aboriginals, who may have difficulty in understanding the new arrangements, and in particular, to provide advice regarding the steps to be taken in applying for and using health care cards. The Department of Social Security is seeking to assist Aboriginal communities in view of their special needs. They are able to advise a doctor, by telephone, whether a particular person holds health care card entitlement and the number of that card. Also, it should be noted that health care cards may be located centrally, for example, at a health centre, council office or with a community welfare worker.

The card can also be kept by a doctor or health sister. These measures should assist in overcoming any problems which may arise in identifying persons in special need who do not carry or who have lost their Health Care cards.

Bulk-billing arrangements have continued for persons in special need and an additional facility has been introduced which allows these people to obtain their medical benefits through the health insurance funds. Previously free medical services for people in special need depended on whether the doctor agreed to bulk-bill the patient for the services. The payment facility through the funds now ensures a greater availability of medical care from doctors who did not wish to participate previously in the bulk-billing arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 November 1981 (Hansard, pages 2006-2007) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a supplementary question concerning the strike of the dancers of the Australian Ballet Foundation and in view of the strike has the Government considered withdrawing the grant of $1.6m made to the Australian Ballet Foundation in the Australia Council's appropriation for 1981-82.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australia Council has confirmed that the dispute was settled on 16 November 1981 with the dancers accepting the proposals put forward by the Board of the Australian Ballet Foundation. The terms of settlement of the dispute, as I am advised, are as follows:
The Administrator, Mr P. Bahen, not to be involved in artistic decisions and to have no contact with the dancers;
former prima ballerina Marilyn Rowe to be appointed as an adviser to the Artistic Director, Marilyn Jones;
a management consultancy company to be engaged to investigate a re-structuring of the company;
dancers to elect a member of the Ballet Board (not necessarily a dancer);
dancers' representatives to take part in the engagement of senior artistic staff;
variation to award relating to amount of rehearsal time, and to increase numbers of dancers to cover injuries and illness; and
longer breaks between change of programs in order to achieve higher production and artistic standards.
No consideration was given by the Government to withdrawing the grant made to the Australian Ballet Foundation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2084) Senator Button asked me the following question without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate:

ANSWER.PARA: Did the Minister for Primary Industry on 24 September enter into a stabilisation agreement to apply to the dried fruits industry? Does this arrangement provide assistance to the dried fruits industry? Is it a fact that no reference of this matter was made to the Industries Assistance Commission as required by the Industries Assistance Commission Act? If so, why?
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 24 September 1981 the Minister for Primary Industry announced that the Government was ready to introduce an underwriting arrangement to apply to the production of dried sultanas from the 1982 to 1986 seasons. The Minister said that the offer to introduce the scheme had been made following detailed discussions with the Board of Management of the Australian Dried Fruits Association and, if the response from the industry were favourable it was intended to introduce legislation in the Budget sittings.
The arrangement was accepted by the industry, and the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill was introduced into Parliament on 29 October.

Development of the scheme provided in this Bill stems from an inquiry made by the Industries Assistance Commission into the dried vine fruits industry, and reported on in 1976. Additionally the Commission made reference to some aspects of the dried vine fruits industry in its 1979 report on grapes and wine.

After examining the Commission's 1976 report the Government announced in November 1977 that it would extend the then-existing stabilisation scheme to cover the 1978 to 1980 seasons and that there would be a review at the end of the second season with a view to determining long-term action.
The foreshadowed review was begun late in 1979 and it has now resulted in the introduction of the Bill which I have mentioned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 November 1981 (Hansard page 2084) Senator MacGibbon asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned long term contracts for meat exports from Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of the allegations made in an article in the Land newspaper of 29 October 1981 relating to approaches by a number of countries to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) for long term agreements.

The Chairman of the AMLC, Mr R. G. Jones, has responded to these allegations and his rebuttal was published in the Land edition of 5 November 1981. Briefly the AMLC has offered the following responses on each individual allegation.

(1) Korea-During 1979-80 South Korea encountered internal economic difficulties and a domestic oversupply of pork and poultry meats which led it to suspend meat import purchasing in August 1979. Korea recommenced imports in March 1981 and up to November 1981 Australian exports to Korea totalled 32,133 tonnes.
(2) Egypt-With the stated aim of gaining food security and credit terms advantages, Egypt has sought to negotiate long-term contracts stipulating both quantity and price.
Australian exporters naturally are not prepared to contract on a long-term price arrangement-nor is AMLC. Traders are also not happy with bid and performance bonds required by Egypt.

ALMC was prepared earlier this year to use its trading powers if Egypt wished to deal on a government to government basis, but importing authorities in that country continued to negotiate with individual exporters and consortia.

(3) Mexico-In March 1979 AMLC quoted for an initial trial shipment of 1685 tonnes of boneless beef. Mexican authorities failed to take up the offer following strong political reaction by domestic livestock producers to the idea of beef imports.

Suggestions of exporter resistance appear to be confused with rumours at the time that Mexican cattlemen offered the Mexican Government 50,000 head of cattle at prices approximating US 40 cents per lb. liveweight to head off imports.
(4) Algeria-Algerian representatives visited the AMLC in April 1981 to discuss possible long term arrangements with the intention of purchasing meat at '' favourable'' prices.
AMLC circulated to industry Algeria's specific requirements.

(5) Malaysia-In March/April 1981 a Malaysian delegation visited Australia to investigate purchase of beef slaughtered according to Islamic religious rites to replace some of West Malaysia's livestock imports.

The West Malaysian government decided in October 1981 to call a tender for 500 tonnes of halal boneless beef cuts for delivery January/March 1982. It is likely the beef will be purchased from Australia.
(6) Libya-Australia has supplied live sheep to Libya and will tender for additional contracts in 1982. Libya has expressed interest in purchasing lambs for fattening but not sheepmeats thus far.
(7) Iraq-Trade negotiations continued with Iraq until interrupted by the outbreak of the Iraq-Iran conflict. For the period January/November 1981 Iraq purchased 5,323 tonnes from Australia.

With regard to long-term agreements, the Corporation does have the power to engage in export trading of meat and live- stock in its own right. However the basic policy of the AMLC is that it will only use its trading powers when it considers that it can get a better return than private traders, when requested to do so by industry or when the importing country wishes to deal on a government to government basis. Australian producers have not shown keenness to agree to long-term agreements where quantities and prices are predetermined on the basis that other more lucrative markets may arise in the course of a long- term agreement. The United States market sets the floor price for our beef exports and in times of unrestricted access to that market, Australian exporters would not be in favour of a long-term agreement to supply another less lucrative market.

The question also suggested that Australia should pursue long-term contracts particularly in light of the United States countercyclical meat import legislation which is designed to restrict beef imports when domestic production is high. In this regard it should be noted that restraints did not operate in 1981 as meat imports were below the level which would trigger quotas under the legislation. The United States Secretary of Agriculture announced on 24 December 1981 that restrictions would not operate during the first quarter of 1982. Further estimates of imports will be made in 1982 before the commencement of each quarter and if the estimate of imports still remains below the '' trigger point'' no restrictions will operate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2075-2076) Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Treasurer the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister for Finance aware that artists, including those artists who are part time lecturers in tertiary institutions in photography, print-making and drawing, pay a sales tax on raw materials or equipment at the rate of 30 per cent. In view of the difficulty that artists have in establishing themselves in Australia and the fact that they pay luxury tax on their final product, will the Government review the granting of a concession on the purchase of raw materials in similiar fashion to that applied to aids to manufacture in the manufacturing sector.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

As previously advised on this matter (Hansard, 12 November 1981 at page 2076) artists who produce works of art that are not for sale are obliged to bear tax at appropriate rates on any taxable raw materials that they purchase. Much the same position applies with persons who produce other kinds of goods as a hobby or in the course of preparing themselves for a trade, profession, etc. The question of exempting materials purchased by those persons also has to be taken into account when looking at the question of granting such a concession to artists. The matter will be kept under consideration when the Government is next considering extension of sales tax exemptions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November 1981(Hansard, page 2194) Senator Button addressed a question, without notice, to me in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. The question concerned the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Commission on the radio program National Farm Report on 11 November 1981, Mr O'Connell stated that he had informed the Wool Council earlier that an increase in test charges of between 20 per cent and 40 per cent after the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority could be foreseen.

On the following day the chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, on the same program, expressed the opinion that, although it would be very difficult to be specific, he would have considerable doubt if cost increases for AWTA services related to the impending change of status of the organisation would reach the figures mentioned.

The extent of any future increases of costs of operating the AWTA will undoubtedly depend largely on the attitudes and skills of the management of the new wool testing organisation. Accordingly, it would not be appropriate for the Government to comment on any estimates of costs at this time.

The Government is determined to proceed with the sale because the reasons for its decision are as cogent now as they were when announced by the Prime Minister in the Parliament in April. I have been informed by letter from the Australian Council of Wool Buyers, the National Council of Wool Selling Brokers of Australia, the Federal Council of Private Treaty Wool Merchants, the Wool Scourers and Carbonisers Association of Australia and the Wool Textile Manufacturers of Australia, that they accept the decision of the review of Commonwealth Functions to sell AWTA.

When AWTA is in position to meet all of its own costs directly, producers will know exactly what they are paying for wool testing services. If the present efficiency of the AWTA is not maintained the way will be open for opposition companies to enter the field knowing that they can compete with AWTA on an equal footing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2255) Senator Button asked Senator Carrick the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it true that the Prime Minister has offered to help Queensland subsidise Trans Australia Airlines services to western Queensland? Does this indicate that the Government's user pays philosphy will be applied selectively? For example, does it mean that, when and if the profitable parts of Telecom Australia are sold to private enterprise, the Government will directly subsidise the losses on rural telephone services, which are currently running at $230m a year?
The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:
The Government is concerned about the isolation of western Queensland communities should their air services be threatened.

This issue has been discussed by the Prime Minister and the Premier of Queensland. As a result of the meeting, TAA, the Commonwealth and the State officers are examining options for future operations which maintain air services to the communities currently served by TAA.
It is expected that decisions on future arrangements for air services to western Queensland will be taken quickly by the respective Governments.

In respect of the questions concerning application of the user pays philosphy, the Holcroft Inquiry into domestic air fares recommended that where the Government decides that a community shall be provided with an air service which requires a subsidy for its viable operation, the subsidy be explicitly provided so that its cost is borne by the community as a whole and not only by other air travellers as a cross subsidy. The Government has accepted this recommendation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2255) Senator Thomas asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the Senate, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. I refer to questions previously asked by Senator Puplick on 26 February and by me on 12 March relating to the importation of gold chain. The Industries Assistance Commission, in report No. 274 dated 6 August and entitled Chain of precious metal, has recommended that the duty on chain falling under tariff item 71.14 and currently dutiable at two per cent be subject to duty at 25 per cent, which is the same level as is applied to chain jewellery which falls within item 71.12.9. The report also recommends a review of the whole industry in 1986. Will the Minister advise whether the Government will accept the report of the IAC and, if so, whether speedy implementation can be made of the recommendation to lift duty under tariff item 71.14 from two per cent to 25 per cent to prevent some importers from taking advantage of what seems to be an anomaly in tariff provisions covering the importation of gold chain?
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

To Senator Messner's answer, that is 'I recall the questions on this subject that were asked by Senator Puplick some six months ago and earlier by Senator Thomas. It is true that the industries Assistance Commission did recommend a change in the rate of duty applicable to precious metal chain-two per cent-as distinct from that chain which constitutes jewellery, to which a tariff of some 25 per cent applies. The Government has decided to accept the recommendation in the report and has applied the higher rate to precious metal chain since 30 October. I understand that that was the date upon which the announcement was made. I will check for the information of the honourable senator whether that was the actual date of implementation of the new decision.'

I would add that: The Government decision to accept an IAC recommendation to impose a duty rate of 25 per cent on chain of precious metal falling to tariff item 71.14 took effect on and from 30 October 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2261) Senator Kilgariff asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. The honourable senator's question was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the Minister's attention to the abundance of camels in the Northern Territory and to the fact that export camel meat is classified as game meat and is therefore required to be processed through a registered game meat export establishment. There are no game meat export abattoirs in the Northern Territory. As this industry could be one of significance in the Northern Territory, employing members of Aboriginal communities and providing an alternative source of income, will the Government reconsider classification of camel meat with a view to amending the regulations to allow camels to be slaughtered for export under normal conditions, as for beef, at local abattoirs ?
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following information:

The existing provisions of the Exports (Meat) Regulations only provide for camels to be slaughtered in the field as game meat. Game meat premises must comply in full with the relevant provisions of the Export (Meat) Regulations and all current export requirements. These include requirements relating to siting, water supply, construction and hygiene.
If it could be shown to be desirable to amend the Exports (Meat) Regulations to include camels as animals which may be slaughtered in an abattoir, I would be prepared to consider such action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2259) Senator Martyr asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education a question without notice concerning the O'Brien case at the University of Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The University of Western Australia is established under State legislation. Details of the University's finances can be obtained from the Annual Report of the University Senate. I understand that the audited financial statements for the University for 1980, which are issued as a separate document, are also available.

Commonwealth grants to the University of Western Australia are provided through States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) legislation. Application of these grants, within the conditions imposed by the States Grants legislation , are a matter for the University.
Questions relating to the resignation of the former Chancellor or to the Vice- Chancellor's reports to the University Senate are also matters for the internal management of the University.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2341) Senator Archer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs carried out a close monitoring of the transfers of quotas in the clothing import section? Has there been any significant change in the groups of holders such as manufacturers, agents, wholesalers and retailers? Is this according to the plan that the Department has in mind? Is it seen to produce any effect in the market place? Has the Department any plans to accelerate or to retard that position?
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The transfer of textile clothing and footwear quotas between importers is an integral part of the quota allocation system. Although transfers are processed through the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs no monitoring , other than that necessary to establish the bona fides of the transferee as a legitimate importer, is undertaken.

(2) Since the new seven year program of assistance for the textile clothing and footwear industries was announced there has been some rationalisation of quota holdings through the transfer arrangements. Some of the larger well known retailers have figured prominently in these transfers.

(4) The Department is not aware of any significant effect in the market place resulting from quota transfers. However, the Government has established a Textile Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee to provide advice to the Minister for Industry and Commerce and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs on the following matters arising out of the new seven year program: (a) assessment of progressive market growth and related achievements to quota levels; (b) administrative changes which may be necessary to ensure that the Government's objectives under the new program are achieved; and (c) monitoring and report on the situation during the course of the program.
As part of its operation the Committee will consider submissions from all interested parties and sections of the industries involved.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Disabled Persons: Access to Australian Embassy in Washington

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2340) Senator Coates asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that the Australian Embassy in Washington has no ready access for disabled people such as those in wheelchairs? Is it one of the few public buildings in that city not so accessible? Does the Government have a policy on making buildings accessible to the disabled and does this policy apply to buildings overseas? Will the Government, in this International Year of Disabled Persons, take some action to remedy the position?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commonwealth has approved the provision of funds for the modification of appropriate Australian Government buildings both within Australia and overseas to make the buildings more readily useable by disabled persons.

In regard to the Washington Chancery building, funds were provided on 12 November 1981 for the construction of a ramp to the main entrance and modification of the toilets on the ground floor of the building to facilitate access and use by disabled persons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2338) Senator Reid asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services a question without notice concerning picket lines of schools in the Australian Capital Territory when teachers are on strike.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Subsequent to the decision to picket schools taken at the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation Conference in November 1981 a petition signed by 331 teachers has been received by the President of the Federation.

This petition requests that a special conference be called to consider rescinding the motion passed at annual conference. As the number of signatures on the petition represents 10 per cent of the membership of the Federation a Special Conference has been called for Wednesday, 17 March 1982.
No picket action was undertaken by Australian Capital Territory teachers during the final 1981 school term.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2438) Senator Crichton- Browne asked me a question, without notice, concerning the findings of the Bureau of Transport Economics' report 'An Assessment of the Australian Road System: 1979' and the basis for the future distribution of Commonwealth road grants to Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to Senator Crichton-Browne's question:

In its 1979 Roads Report, the Bureau of Transport Economics made no recommendations in relation to the future distribution among States of Commonwealth roads assistance. Rather, the Bureau has assessed an overall level of economically warranted roads investment for each State and Territory over the period 1979-80 to 1983-84. The question of the relative contributions by Commonwealth, State and Local Government towards an economically warranted program was not addressed in the report.

The Commonwealth has never distributed its road grants purely on the basis of population size. Prior to 1969-70, Commonwealth road grants were distributed among the mainland States according to a formula which attached equal weighting to area, population and the number of registered motor vehicles. Between 1969- 70 and 1977-78, the distribution of Commonwealth road grants was brought more closely into line with road needs as assessed by the former Bureau of Roads. These assessments took account of a wide range of economic and social factors including projected usage of roads, road user benefits, construction and land acquisition costs. The former Bureau of Roads also examined the different capacity of State and Local Governments to finance road programs in each State.
Since 1977-78, State funding relativities have remained constant. Western Australia's share is currently 12.7 per cent.

As to the future, the Commonwealth will take account of the road needs of all States, including Western Australia's, when determining the apportionment between States and the Northern Territory of the levels of funds it has undertaken to provide over the three years 1982-83 to 1984-85.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2493) Senator McLaren asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that the 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment Support Company based at Townsville is engaged in regular and intense riot control exercises with particular emphasis being given to the use of flexiglass shields, tear gas and batons.

If this is a fact, will the Minister inform the Senate of the purpose of this specialist training and whether it has been ordered because of the recent statement by Mr Charles Perkins concerning the forthcoming Commonwealth Games to be held in Brisbane and the report yesterday that the Queensland Police Minister, Russ Hinze, has received Cabinet approval for security legislation which could be put into use during the Games next year.
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
No Defence Force training of the type described by Senator McLaren has been undertaken or ordered.
However it is a fact that all elements of the Defence Force need to do a certain amount of training to enable them to give assistance to the civil law enforcement authorities if called upon to do so.
1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment is no exception in this regard and has done some training recently.
Such training can include various forms of crowd control but does not normally involve the use of shields, batons and tear gas.
These items were not used in the training in Townsville.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2599) Senator Macklin asked me a question, without notice, directed to me in my capacity as representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. The question concerned alleged gassings by Australian soldiers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
My Department has no record of any involvement of prisoners in gas tests, and I have great difficulty in believing that such a thing could have occurred.

I am not in any way questioning the motives of the author of the letter you have received, but I suggest that its contents would raise serious doubts in the mind of a researcher. For example, I know of no evidence whatsoever that Japanese forces landed on Australian soil during World War II, nor that a group of 76 Australian soldiers were killed in one engagement near Darwin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2599), Senator Watson asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the possible provision of assistance to Poland in the form of beef shipments by the Australian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Government has decided to defer consideration of any economic support for Poland following the military takeover on 15 December 1981, until the picture becomes clearer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What advisory committees and councils are now in existence to give advice to the Minister and the Department of Social Security.
(2) On which of these committees and councils will the members receive payment and/or expenses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by the National Consultative Council on Social Security, formerly known as the National Consultative Council on Social Welfare. There are also eight State and Territory consultative committees which advise the Department of Social Security at the State level, on Commonwealth Government social security and welfare programs administered by the Department.

The National Advisory Council for the Handicapped whose Secretariat is located in my department, advises the Commonwealth Government on all aspects of its policies affecting the rehabilitation of handicapped people.

(2) Members of all these bodies currently receive remuneration and the payment of travel and accommodation expenses for their attendance at meetings, unless they are Commonwealth or State public servants, in which case no remuneration is paid.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What official engagements did the Minister for the Capital Territory have on Tuesday 7 July 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: Official opening of the Careers '81 Exhibition at the Bruce College of Technical and Further Education, Canberra.
Attended reception for delegates participating in the Australian Legal Convention, Government House, Hobart, followed by official dinner commitment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General satisfied himself as to whether the Commonwealth Crimes Act is or is not applicable to employees, representatives or others associated with private interests who may receive Government information not generally available.
(2) If so, did the Attorney-General arrive at his decision on advice from his advisers or did he undertake action to satisfy himself on this point.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Crimes Act 1914, in particular section 79, applies, in the circumstances indicated in the Act, to the disclosure of official information by persons who are not officers or employees of the Commonwealth.

(2) The question does not indicate the occasion or the purpose on, or for, which I am supposed to have satisfied myself on this matter and accordingly the question cannot be answered in so far as it seeks information on this aspect.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister's Department aware of any information, disclosed in submissions to it, advice available to it or public documents such as Auditor- General's Reports, which suggests that the Department and instrumentalities under the Minister's responsibility are forgoing revenue because of insufficient staff.
(2) How much revenue is alleged to have been forgone.
(3) Approximately how much revenue does the Department estimate may have been forgone.
(4) When did the information or items of information become available to the Minister's Department.
(5) What has been done to improve the situation.
(6) What are the details of any staff rearrangements that have been made as a result of action in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Auditor-General's Efficiency Audit Report on the Department of Administrative Services Property function, dated April 1980, observed in respect of the revenue leasing function that revenue may have been forgone or increased Commonwealth expenditure resulted because of lack of or infrequent inspections of the leases. The Auditor-General in his report of March 1981 refers also to the Sydney office of my Department's Purchasing Division. The Auditor-General estimated a backlog of ten man-years in checking claims from contractors arising from staff shortages.
(2) No estimate was given. An estimated $2.2 million could remain unrecovered.
(3) No acceptable estimate has been calculated. Efforts are aimed at reducing the backlog to zero, and accordingly avoiding any loss of revenue.
(4) April 1980. During examination of outstanding claims for 1979-80.

(5) Pursuant to the Report referred to under (1) and to the decisions of the Government on the review of Commonwealth Functions, action is being taken progressively to review all Commonwealth property to identify properties surplus to requirements or for which there is no requirement for up to two years. Properties which are temporarily surplus are being offered to the public at full market rentals. Rentals on existing leases of property not immediately required for Government purposes are also being reviewed to achieve maximum revenue. The Financial Services Section of the Purchasing Division has been the subject of an approach to the Public Service Board aimed towards providing a more appropriate organisation to handle the workload. The Public Service Board approved a revised and enhanced organisation structure in May 1981. It has also been agreed that the Board would be prepared to review the organisation structure if, in the longer term, it is considered to be inadequate. The arrears in work are a matter of considerable concern, but there is, of course, a question of balancing the need for adequate investigation of claims against the cost to the tax payer of such investigation. In this regard the Department is to conduct a review in the near future aimed at seeing if there can be improvements in the operational efficiencies of the Financial Services Sections. The review will consider such aspects as scope for auditing company systems and controls versus detailed claims checking, the possible use of private financial firms and the adequacy of existing claims documentation.
(6) To facilitate this review of Commonwealth property, some additional staff capacity is to be provided. See (5).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What decisions were made in the Review of Commonwealth Functions which directly and specifically affect the Minister's Department.

(2) In what ways will general decisions made in the Review of Commonwealth Functions to (a) reduce by 2 per cent the number of Commonwealth employees in areas subject to staff ceilings over 2 years, (b) reduce by 3 per cent the departmental expenditure on furniture, repairs, property, leases and administration,
and any other general decisions in the Review, affect the Minister's Departments
(3) At the time of the Review approximately what amount were each of those decisions estimated to save or cost the Department.
(4) What steps have so far been taken within the Department to implement the decisions referred to in (1) and (2).
(5) How many people have been inolved in the arrangements to implement the decisions and approximately how many man-days have been involved so far and how many more will be expended overall.
(6) Approximately how much has the Department paid in salaries to implement the decisions and how much more will be paid in future.
(7) Have initial estimates of approximate savings on costs been borne out.
(8) What are present estimates of eventual savings resulting from each of the decisions referred to in (1) and (2).
(9) Were the decisions mentioned in (1) and (2) expected to yield staff savings : if so, what staff savings were estimated to result from implementation of the Review.
(10) What money savings will result from any staff savings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The RCF decisions listed in the appendix to the Prime Minister's statement to the House of Representatives of 30 April were categorised, where appropriate, by department.

(2)(a) Staffing implications of all RCF decisions, to the extent that these implications could be assessed at the time, were taken into account by the Government in setting provisional staff ceilings for 1981-82. Details of the ceilings for individual departments were stated at page 90 of the Public Service Board's report to parliament for 1980-81. Those ceilings may need to be varied in the light of RCF reviews or investigations currently being undertaken or yet to be commenced, or in the light of the disposal of Commonwealth assets. Where further studies already undertaken have shown that variation of ceilings is warranted appropriate adjustments have been made.

(b) Deparments' funding requirements for these categories of expenditure for 1981-82 were reassessed during the budget process in the light of the review decisions and other relevant considerations, and the outcome of those reassessments has reflected in the bids for, and decisions on, funding provided in the 1981-82 budget. It is not practicable to separately identify the effects on departments of the specific decisions mentioned as distinct from the effects of other considerations bearing on budget funding decisions, all of which were reflected in the estimates tabled with the 1981-82 budget.

(3), (7), (8), (9) and (10) In answer to Question no. 723 from the honourable senator it was made clear that the Review of Commonwealth Functions was not primarily an exercise in cost cutting. The focus of the review was on streamlining and fining down Commonwealth operations by withdrawing from areas more appropriately handled by the States and private enterprise and rationalising a number of Commonwealth activities. While eventual ongoing savings compared with the cost of continuing programs on the basis of then existing policies were estimated to be 'of the order of $560 million' it was explained in that answer why more precise figuring was not provided at the time and that the figures did not make allowance for savings for a more diffuse kind. It is in the nature of estimates that they may not be completely accurate and that the degree of inaccuracy, if any, may not be precisely known.

The effect of RCF decisions on estimates of budget outlays is combined with that of other Government decisions (including the 1981-82 budget measures) and with changes in underlying parameters affecting estimates. It is not practicable to separate out the financial effects of each of the many interacting influences on the financial estimates. To attempt such an exercise would involve a major effort on the part of all departments and authorities which I am not prepared to authorise.

I am able to inform the honourable senator, however that, taken as a whole, the savings on the 1981-82 forward estimates achieved through the current budget ( which reflects effects of a range of RCF and other decisions) were well in excess of the figure of $560 million estimated as the order of ongoing savings eventually to arise from the RCF exercise. The Government will, of course, also continue to pursue further savings through the implementation of those RCF decisions currently outstanding.

The Prime Minister's statement of 30 April indicated an expected total staffing reduction of 16,000-17,000. The rate at which staff savings will be achieved can be expected to vary widely as between one decision and another. The implementation of some decisions will inevitably take much longer than others, for example the disposal of Commonwealth assets, the review of the Defence organisation, the Australia Post and Telecom reviews. Savings possibilities will in some cases only become clear as reviews proceed. The Government is closely monitoring the achievement of savings against particular decisions.

(4) As at the end October 1981, approximately 270 of the Governments' decisions arising from the review had been implemented or were close to final implementation, of a total of some 350 decisions. Implimentation of the remainder is being pursued by responsible Ministers and is oversighted by a Cabinet Committee chaired by the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

(5), (6) The process of government administration constantly involves implementation of decisions: the implementation of RCF decisions has in general proceeded as part of that process rather than with separate resources. Separate records have not been kept of the resources applied to implementation of RCF decisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many pensioners in aged and disabled persons' accommodation receive supplementary assistance.
(2) Will these pensioners be reassessed for eligibility under the new supplementary assistance rules; if so, how often.
(3) What is the expected effect of the new rules on organisations operating aged and disabled persons' accommodation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The information requested is not available.

(2) During December 1981 the Department wrote to all pensioners in receipt of supplementary assistance, including those in aged and disabled persons' homes, to obtain the information necessary to assess entitlement under the amended supplementary assistance provisions which came into operation on 1 February 1982 . It also wrote to non-home owning pensioners who do not receive supplementary assistance but who may become eligible under the new provisions, that is because of the revised income test. Subsequent assessment of eligibility will be carried out when the pensioner's circumstances change and in conjunction with normal pension reviews.

(3) The new provisions have not been designed to assist organisations operating aged and disabled persons accommodation but to assist the more needy pensioners in meeting rent charges or costs of their board and lodging. It is probable, however, that some institutions increased their charges as a result of the new provision as charges are often related to a proportion of total income.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is Telecom permitted to 'undertake investments that return the cost of capital whether funds are found at home or overseas', as recommended in the McKinsey Report, if not why not; if so, what are the details?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. Like all Commonwealth and State authorities, public borrowing proposals by Telecom are subject to authorisation by the Australian Loan Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question on notice on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has Telecom adopted the prospective rate of return approach to investment as recommended in the McKinsey Report; if so what are the details, if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. The recommendations of the McKinsey Report form integral parts of a proposed telecommunications development program; they were not intended as individual recommendations for independent implementation. The Government has forwarded the McKinsey Report for consideration by the Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the McKinsey Report contain the following suggestions:

(a) Improve market information, particularly on requirements of major business customers. Differentiate service provision, for example, by offering a faster connection time at a higher price, offering new services such as call charge recording (CCR) for STD as an option, as Telecom intends, and providing a sale option on all terminal equipment.

(b) Provide market input into the introduction of new technology into the network. Specifically, we recommend accelerated replacement of switching equipment to provide custom calling features to subscribers sooner.

(c) Develop issue-oriented business and product planning over a 5 year time horizon. Telecom does extensive technical and financial planning but comparatively little market or business planning. Product/market plans need to be developed for new services that cater for customer needs by spelling out type and timing of new service offerings as well as pricing policies to encourage use of the service. A business perspective on critical issues is also required. Taking a 5 year horizon allows Telecom to integrate market needs, technology changes, and its own capabilities into its planning.

(d) Co-ordinate functions in the organisation better to improve speed and quality of response to customers, by encouraging 'account management' and project management approaches and by attempting to change the prevailing function-oriented management style.
(2) What has been done since the report was handed down to implement each suggestion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Telecom has taken the following action in respect of each item:
(a) Market Information on Major Business Customers

Appointment of a number of Account Managers in Sydney and Melbourne areas, with each Manager being responsible for assessing the needs of major business customers in his particular segment of the business and commercial community.
Continued liaison with representative groups of major telecommunications users.
Increased Market Research activity on customer attitudes and product/service requirements.
Different grades of service have already been prescribed for peak and off-peak STD trunk traffic periods.
Currently investigating the possibility of differential charges for service installation and maintenance required to be undertaken outside normal hours.
New services e.g. STD/CCR to be offered as an optional service
Sales Option on all terminal equipment
Sales option introduced already on some equipment, for example, PABX's and Multicom's.
Extension of the concept to other product lines is being considered.
(b) Earlier replacement of switching equipment to provide custom calling features

The McKinsey recommendations are supported and the acceleration of the exchange modernisation program will be kept under review, having regard to the prevailing level of capital which can be allocated for this purpose and other network demands, as well as Telecom's own commercial performance.
(c) Business and product planning over a 5 year time horizon

A Business Development Directorate has been established to undertake strategic business planning. In addition, individual product and resource plans for up to five years are being developed consistent with Corporate Strategy and Policy.
Project Management and function oriented management style
Telecom has re-arranged its organisation and certain functions have been brought together in structured business units.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps have been taken in line with McKinsey Report recommendations to improve the customer focus of Telecom Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the honourable senator to my reply to Senate Question No. 1356.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amounts of cocaine have been seized by the Australian Federal Police and/or customs officers in the past two years.
(2) On what dates did each seizure take place.
(3) How have the Federal Police or customs officers disposed of the drug.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Federal Police is taking steps to counter any increase in cocaine trafficking in Australia. An Australian Federal Police drug liaison officer recently visited South America for the purpose of improving the exchange of intelligence regarding cocaine. Furthermore, an Australian Federal Police drug liaison officer will be making regular visits to the Pacific Island area.
Australian Federal Police officers have also been involved in a variety of other drug related arrests and seizures performed by State Police Forces and the Bureau of Customs.

A policy of maximum co-operation with the States in drug matters, particularly by combined operations in Joint Task Force investigations and sharing of criminal intelligence information, leads to many arrests and seizures that are conducted at a State level.
(2) Cocaine seizures made by the Australian Federal Police and Bureau of Customs during the period 1 October 1979 to 23 October 1981:
(3) Those seizures of cocaine on which all action has been completed have been destroyed by incineration.
Those seizures which are the subject of outstanding court action or follow-up investigation are held in secure storage under the control of the Australian Federal Police.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Telecom Australia required by any agreement or understanding to maintain any commercial radio or television stations and/or transmitters in Australia; if so, what stations.
(2) What has been the cost of any such servicing over the past five years, and what money has been received by Telecom from licensees or any other source for carrying out this work.

(3) Have there been any occasions when obsolete or out-of-production valves have had to be supplied as replacements in any commercial installations serviced by Telecom; if so, has the full cost of replacement been recouped from the licensees involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the early 1960's the Government established policy and guidelines enabling commercial television operators to benefit from the shared use of Government provided television transmitting station facilities. It is a requirement of this policy that where commercial television equipment is installed at a Government funded station, the commercially owned and shared equipment is maintained by the staff associated with the National Television Service. Prior to July 1975 such commercial television transmitting plant was maintained by staff of the Postmaster-General's Department. Since July 1975 this responsibility has transferred to Telecom who carry out broadcasting transmitter functions on an agency basis for the Department of Communications. A list of stations where national facilities are shared with commercial television operators is attached.
(2) The total cost of running the shared stations by Telecom is charged against the Department of Communications appropriation.
In turn, receipts from commercial licenses for fees for use, capital contributions and contributions towards maintenance costs are made payable by the licensees to the Receiver of Public Monies.
Over the past five years to the end of June 1981, receipts were:
Fee for use and capital contributions-$1,038,000

(3) All replacement parts including valves supplied and fitted to commercial transmitting plant by Telecom maintenance staff have been charged at full cost to Telecom together, where appropriate, with import duty and sales tax.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Where national service officers, holding degrees or diplomas in engineering, arts, commerce, science, economics or education, accepted short service commissions or permanent commissions in the Regular Army, were these officers promoted immediately to first lieutenant and their seniorities backdated in that rank to bring them into line with direct entry graduates and diplomates and to give them advancement upon national service officers with similar qualifications who chose to remain national servicemen.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The officers referred to were promoted lieutenant providing they had a minimum of nine months commissioned service as second lieutenant. Their seniority was adjusted to equate them with OCS graduates with equivalent qualifications and length of service.

This adjustment was not related in any way to direct entry officers. Entirely different appointment conditions apply to direct entry officers and rank and seniority varies in accordance with individuals specialist qualifications.
It was not designed to give advancement over national Service officers to whom different conditions of appointment apply having regard to their limited period of service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Would the widow of a national serviceman or national service officer, killed in action, receive a lower financial entitlement because the rank of that serviceman or officer at the time of death was lower than it would have been if that serviceman or officer had not been a national serviceman or national service officer but had been instead a member of the Regular Army.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The financial entitlements of the widow of a national serviceman would be directly related to the substantive rank held by the member at date of death, as is the case for members of the Regular Army.

It is not appropriate to make the general comparison implied in the question of the relative ranks of national servicemen with members of the regular Army because of variables stemming from different career patterns.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Was the lower rank (second lieutenant) given to national service officers holding degrees or diplomas in engineering, science, arts, commerce, economics and education, as against the higher rank (first lieutenant) given to former national service officers and other Regular Army Officers holding the same qualifications, a penalty or a prejudice imposed on the military employment of national service officers because these officers were or might become liable to render service under, or to comply with requirements of, the National Service Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. It was the policy to appoint national service officers holding degrees or diplomas as second lieutenant, the same rank as for officers not holding degrees , in the interests of overall uniformity.
There was provision to grant higher temporary rank to officers holding degrees or diplomas when filling a higher appointment in which continuous use was made of their qualifications.
On appointment to short service commissions in the Regular Army, the higher rank of lieutenant was given to all selected applicants-including ex national service officers-holding degrees or diplomas.
