QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Defence, as a result of a question asked in the House of Representatives on 22 October 1981 by the member for Melbourne Ports, Mr Holding, M.P., write to Mr Holding enclosing documents marked Attachments A to D .

(2) Did the attachments list the locations at which mustard gas tests were carried out during World War 2; if so, were the locations listed as Townsville, Singleton, Forbes, Grafton, Innisfail, Tully, Cairns, Humpty-Doo, Darwin and Port Wakefield.

(3) Did records requested by the Department of Defence, before the Minister's reply, show no evidence of tests being carried out at Port Wakefield; if so, why was Port Wakefield still included in the list of locations in (2).

(4) Was extensive testing carried out at various other localities, including Nhill, during World War 2, and did dumping and neutralising of mustard and phosgene gas bombs take place at Nhill after the War; if so, why was Nhill not included in the list.
(5) Will the Minister provide a complete list of all localities where tests were carried out or bombs dumped or neutralised, for the benefit of veterans making compensation claims.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The locations referred to were listed as locations at which chemical warfare experiments took place during World War II. The list was contained in an answer given in 1975 by the then Minister for Defence to House of Representatives Question No. 1950 (see Hansard of 20 August 1975).

(3) I am now advised that that answer to House of Representatives Question No. 1950 was based in part on documentary evidence that at least 2 tests were carried out at Port Wakefield on 1-2 February 1944. These trials were designed to test 25 pounder shells filled with chemicals.

(4) I assume that the list of locations in that answer did not purport to include those places, such as the Royal Australian Air Force Air Armament and Gas School at Nhill, where field training exercises were carried out to prepare Servicemen to defend themselves against gas attacks. Nor, I assume, did the list purport to include those places where chemical warfare stocks were stored and/or disposed of after the war. I am advised that no records have been found to indicate that dumping of mustard gas or phosgene gas took place at Nhill.

(5) There are difficulties, some of which are illustrated by the answers to earlier parts of this question, in providing an unchallengeable listing of all localities at which veterans may conceiveably have experienced some exposure to chemical warfare agents. Rather than attempt to do so, I repeat the statement I, and successive Ministers before me have made that any veteran who believes his health has suffered because of his war service and who wishes to make a claim for compensation should approach the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Relevant documentation is available to individuals and to that Department through Australian Archives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there an impending suspected epidemic of dengue fever that is moving down the Queensland coast from Thursday Island to at least Gladstone; for which, at present there is no effective defence.

(2) Is the Queensland Institute of Medical Research currently involved in research into isolating a vaccine to combat dengue fever and, indeed, is the collating centre for international research in this field under the auspices of the World Health Organisation.

(3) Has the Minister been notified that the Institute is in urgent need of $50, 000 to continue this vital research in an effective way in view of the fact that a more virulent strain which causes severe haemorrhaging, is currently attacking South East Asia and is likely to be brought into Australia this summer by travellers; if so, will these urgently needed funds be made available to this highly regarded institute in order to ensure that an effective vaccine is developed to combat this highly debilitating disease.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Dengue fever has been reported and the diagnosis confirmed by laboratory investigation in northern Queensland, with an extensive outbreak occuring on Thursday Island and on the mainland as far south as Townsville.

An effective defence against the spread of this disease exists in vector control and the elimination of the aedes mosquito which transmits the disease from man to man. There is no vaccine yet available.

The Australian Government has contributed to vector control measures under the Australian Encephalitis Control Program since 1975. Queensland has participated for the first time in this program in 1981-82.

The Department of Health organises a national vector control course for the training of personnel in vector control measures at Mildura each year. In November 1981 six officers from Queensland attended this course.

(2) The Queensland Institute of Medical Research (QIMR) is a World Health Organisation Arbovirus Research and Reference Centre. Research at QIMR is related to the development of a dengue vaccine, although not specifically directed to this purpose. The main research to develop such a vaccine is being done in Bangkok.
(3) Initial discussions on programs with the Institute have been held at officer level but no formal proposal has yet been developed.

The urgent need is for effective vector control and mosquito eradication. These measures succeeded in keeping Australia free from the disease from 1955 until late 1981 even in the absence of a vaccine.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Are students from overseas, sponsored by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, precluded from changing to a Ph.D. course if they enrolled originally for a masters degree; if so, are potential students, especially in Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia advised in writing before they have enrolled; and if not, will the Minister for Foreign Affairs ensure that they are so advised in future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Students sponsored by the Australian Development Assistant Bureau may upgrade their studies from masters to doctorate level if this was provided for in the original offer of awards made to their home governments, but not if masters studies only were requested and offered. Before they come to Australia, students are orally briefed about their awards and are required by Australia's overseas missions to sign an acknowledgement that the type, level and duration of the training offered are acceptable to them.

The nominating procedure requires developing country governments themselves to select candidates for Australian awards and specify the types and level of training required. The Bureau then sets about placing and enrolling the students in accordance with these wishes and offering the appropriate awards to the home government. The students may not enrol themselves nor do they receive the award offers direct from the Bureau. The home governments are informed of the conditions of the awards by the appropriate Australian overseas missions and it is the responsibility of those governments to pass that information on to their students. Many do so in writing. In addition our overseas missions themselves reinforce this information in routine predeparture briefing of the students, ask students to sign an acknowledgement that the training offered is acceptable, and the students are further briefed by the Bureau's Regional Offices upon their arrival in Australia.

These procedures were designed to achieve the primary goals of Australia's development training program. It should be understood that it is not the aim of that program to develop to the utmost the academic talent of the gifted individual student. It is primarily the aim to help the governments of developing countries to meet their needs for skilled manpower in their own development programs according to priorities which they themselves consider to be appropriate. Thus the awards under the program are given by the Bureau on behalf of the Australian government to the governments of developing countries.

Developing countries do of course nominate candidates for doctoral studies, and students nominated for these are often initially placed at the masters level with a view to upgrading to Ph.D if their performance warrants it. This is allowed for in the original award offer. Students who may not upgrade in this way are those for whom study at masters level only was asked for by their governments and for whom masters awards only were offered by the Bureau and accepted by those governments, as well as for those whom Ph.D studies were requested by their governments, but whose academic background or other factors only permitted an award to be offered at masters level.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What cabin pressure is normally maintained at altitudes between 9,000 and 12,000 metres for the following aircraft: (a) Boeing 747; (b) Boeing 727; (c) Douglas DC9; and (d) Airbus 300?

(3) Are there any known studies of the possible health damage caused by drinking alcohol at low atmospheric pressures?
(4) Is there any special danger from long flights at low pressures for people with heart or respiratory ailments, with or without drinking alcohol?
(5) Have Australian airlines ever warned passengers of possible dangers from lengthy altitude flights?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Measurement of cabin pressure is usually expressed in terms of cabin altitude. The cabin altitudes normally maintained are as follows:
(a) Boeing 747 3,200 ft 6,400 ft (b) Boeing 727 3,800 ft 7,000 ft (c) Douglas DC9 6,400 ft 8,400 ft (at 10,668m, the maximim operating altitude) (d) Airbus 300 4,600 ft 7,900 ft

(2) Annoxia or hypoxia is a reduced supply of oxygen to the body's tissues and organs. Some reduction in oxygen supply occurs at every height above sea level. At the cabin altitudes referred to above, the reduction is within tolerance except for individuals with seriously impaired reserves of oxygen.
(3) While studies have been carried out on the effects of alcohol on flight crew performance at low atmosphere pressures, there are no known studies in relation to passenger health.

(4) People with advanced heart or respiratory ailments may be more susceptable to the effects of hypoxia on long flights and may require supplemental oxygen which airlines are required to carry in the subject aircraft.

(5) Except as noted in (4), there cannot be said to be any dangers to passengers in prolonged flights at altitudes normally used in passenger operations, nor would it be practical for airlines to issue general 'warnings'. One of the functions of airline medical departments is to evaluate likely effects of flight on intending passengers whose medical conditions are notified to them, either directly by the passengers or through booking clerks.

(3) Will the States be approached in order to obtain a national measure of lead levels in the soil attributable to leaded petrol.
(4) Do the levels of lead attributable to leaded petrol in the soil or on the leaves of plants (as indicated by CSIRO tests) constitute a health risk.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The monitoring of pollutants in soils, except in Commonwealth territories, is essentially a State responsibility. I am unaware of any program for the monitoring of lead concentrations in soil in Australia other than that carried out by the CSIRO, to which Senator Childs has referred.

(4) The Commonwealth Department of Health has advised that lead is a toxic substance with no known beneficial physiological effects. Hence the amount of lead in the environment capable of absorption by humans should be reduced to a minimum. Lead in soil has the potential to enter the human food chain and so contribute to lead uptake by man via crops and animal foodstuffs. The Department of Health has also advised that the lead levels in soils near Adelaide reported by the CSIRO are at present low and would not make a major contribution to the total uptake of lead. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any studies been conducted into the effects Electromagnetic Pulses ( EMP's) from one or more high altitude nuclear explosions could have on Australia .
(2) Could a small number of 10 megaton thermonuclear weapons detonated 400 kilometres above Australia knock out the entire electrical power grid and the entire civilian telephone network.

(3) Could electromagnetic pulses damage or destroy nearly every unprotected piece of electronic equipment in the country, including computers, television sets, radios, electronic controls in planes and cars, instruments in laboratories and hospitals, electronic networks in factories and mills.

(4) Would such EMP's destroy or cripple large sections of the military command, control and communications system; if so what measures have been taken, or are planned to be taken, to protect the military command, control and communications systems from EMP's.
(5) What measures have been taken to protect electronic information banks from both EMP's and sabotage, such as occurred to the United States Army Mathematics Research Centre.
(6) What would be the effects on Australia's economy if every computer in the country was destroyed or rendered useless.
(7) What effects would the detonation of a 10 megaton nuclear device at an altitude of 400 kilometres above Sydney or Melbourne have.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Some studies on EMP have been undertaken in Australia. The Government is also aware of studies carried out overseas on requirements for protection against EMP effects in the unlikely circumstances of superpower nuclear conflict .

(2) to (4) The studies undertaken in Australia indicate that one or more high altitude nuclear bursts over Australia could extensively disrupt and damage unprotected communications circuits and facilities. These are, however, unlikely circumstances, even if global conflict-itself a very remote possibility-were to occur.

The studies undertaken in Australia provide a basis for assessing the relative vulnerability of key systems, and assist in the development of protection criteria for communications circuits and facilities. Consideration is given to EMP survivability in the procurement of new defence electronic equipment. Security requirements preclude detailed discussion of these matters.

(5) to (7) There is no conceivable strategic benefit from an EMP attack against Australia aimed at targets suggested by the honourable senator. Nuclear attack against Australia, if it occurred at all, would be in the context of global nuclear war. Nuclear war would, even if Australia were not attacked, have more severe long-term implications for Australia's economy than the loss of computer data banks. The policy of successive Australian Governments has been to do all within Australia's power to assist in the deterrence of nuclear war. It remains the Government's view that nuclear war is a remote and improbable prospect, and will remain so providing adequate deterrent measures are sustained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Acting Minister for Health I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Die-cast box prototypes of the NAL/CSIRO aid system were received by NAL on 25 November 1981. After thorough assessment, the units will be returned to Plessey Australia Pty Ltd, for design adjustments prior to building of pre- production models in the final case. These models will be subjected to environmental tests and field trials. The first delivery of production units will occur in December 1982. Following acceptance, testing and familiarisation, distribution will commence locally early in 1983.

(2) NAL/CSIRO radio frequency aids will be distributed as normal hearing aids and are intended for use at home as well as at school. The technical innovation and sophistication of this system are major reasons for delay in development, but the advantages are sufficient to warrant this course. The initial deliveries of aids will be fitted to children with the greatest need coupled with capacity to benefit from the system. The specific children will not be nominated until much closer to the delivery date. It will take several years for the system to be provided to the majority of children who could benefit and to those adults for whom the special features of the system would be of advantage.

(3) The Department continues to offer services which include maintenance of existing NAL issued systems; adjustment, evaluation and testing of privately obtained systems, on request, as well as modification of NAL aids (where possible) to operate with privately obtained systems.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In all 149 contracting States of the Convention on International Civil Aviation, operational control services, similar to those provided in Australia by the Department of Transport, are provided to aircraft. However, there are differences in the manner in which operational control functions are shared between the aeronautical authority, the operator and the pilot-in-command.
(2) and (3) The information sought by the honourable senator would require considerable resources to obtain and the Minister is not prepared to authorise the use of scarce resources for the task.

(4) 177. There personnel are not employed solely on operational control duties. Operations controllers also provide an aeronautical information service and are specially trained to co-ordinate emergency services to aircraft in distress and to assist in maritime search and rescue actions.

(2) What were the occasions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The in-principle approach generally followed in relation to the handling of industrial situations is that there should be no negotiations between the parties on the merits of claims while work bans and work limitations remain in force. On the other hand it is normal for discussions to continue aimed at securing a lifting of work bans and limitations in order that the merits of claims may be considered in an atmosphere free of industrial duress.

In practice it is not always possible to totally divorce discussions aimed at removal of all industrial action from consideration of the merits of particular claims that may have given rise to that industrial action. The involvement of third parties, e.g. arbitral tribunals often makes the maintenance of such a distinction difficult.
Records are not maintained that would permit a more specific answer to the question.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Statistics Collections: Review of Commonwealth Functions

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 563) Senator Jones asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. The honourable senator's question was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No doubt the Minister's attention has been drawn to the many reports that an outbreak of food poisoning had occurred in the State of Victoria and that the State Health Commission had warned people not to eat any salami produced by Tibaldi Small Goods (Australia) Pty Ltd as well as to further reports that three other companies which produce salami had found bacteria in the salami produced. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether any steps have been taken to identify meat used in the production of these or other smallgoods and whether any species test has been taken from meat or meat by-products sold on the Australian home market?
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following information:

(1) The Victorian Department of Agriculture conducted an extensive species testing survey of raw meats used for sausage manufacture in 1980. During 1981, such species testing involved the testing of meat at the Tibaldi premises. I am advised a program to monitor meat and smallgoods on the domestic market was introduced on 18 January 1982.

(2) In accordance with controls imposed nationally by the Australian Bureau of Animal Health, meat and processed product produced for export is sampled by species testing. The Australian Bureau of Animal Health has suggested to domestic meat inspection authorities that testing of domestic product would be desirable.

(3) My advice is that, as at 20 January 1982, only the States of Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia are conducting a routine species testing program on domestic meats. The next meeting of the Standing Committee on Agriculture will be considering this matter further.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 555) Senator Gietzelt asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: It is a fact that the Minister for Primary Industry has said that he would be embarrassed if he were in charge of the Australian Federal Police, referring to the investigation into meat substitution? In what way would the Minister be embarrassed? Does the Minister agree with the Minister for Primary Industry that the Australian Federal Police has the responsibility of stopping fraudulent behaviour but it has to produce evidence to justify prosecution of offenders? On how many occasions have allegations of improprieties or breaches of regulations in meat inspections or the meat export industry been investigated by the Australian Federal Police and with what result? I appreciate that the Minister might not have these facts. If he does not, would he be prepared to make a statement to the Senate at a later time itemising the allegations and the result of police inquiries?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

As the honourable senator is aware the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Sir Colin Woods, KCVO, CBE, QPM, is responsible for the control of operations of the Australian Federal Police. It is not within the ambit of powers given to the Minister to direct the course of, or otherwise interfere by any means in, any investigation being carried out by the Australian Federal Police.

My colleague, the Minister for Primary Industry has stated (House of Represenatives Hansard of 9 September 1981 page 1062) that he was referring to comments made by the Commissioner about the conduct of past police investigations in this matter.

The Commissioner, whose high standards are well known, was providing a professional view after an examination of the reports of past investigations. He informs me that he does not perceive any cause for embarrassment. The use of expert police resources is a matter of constant review of priorities and professional judgment and in the absence of evidence of a wide-ranging scheme most matters referred locally by departmental representatives will be dealt with locally on their face value.

The Commissioner has advised that with hindsight and in the light of recent developments, it is possible that more vigorous inquiries into allegations in past years may have produced sufficient evidence to warrant prosecutions. The Commissioner assures me that the present investigation is an extremely thorough one.

As the honourable senator knows, several persons have been charged recently in Victoria under the Commonwealth Crimes Act as a result of the current Australian Federal Police investigation. It would therefore not be appropriate to comment further at this time.

For details of requests for investigation by the police and the outcome, I refer the honourable senator to the answer provided by the Minister for Primary Industry to a question without notice asked by the Member for Grey (House of Repre- sentatives Hansard of 17 November 1981 page 2934).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 557) Senator McLaren asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry will recall the public outcry last year at the cruelty meted out to live horses destined for export to Japan and the subsequent tabling in the Parliament of guidelines governing future exports. I ask the Minister: Why were Dr Wirth, President of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, and six RSPCA inspectors refused permission to inspect a consignment of 60 horses being loaded at Tullamarine Airport last night aboard a DC8 aircraft operated by the American Flying Tigers company and destined for Japan? As Dr Wirth has been reported as saying that the aircraft was unfit for the transport of horses and that the stringent regulations gazetted after the previous sorry episode do not extend to air travel of horses, I further ask: Will the Government take urgent action to gazette regulations to cover all forms of transport of live animals from Australia?
The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following information:

I understand that a party of RSPCA officials arrived at the airport and were denied entry in accordance with airport regulations. A veterinary officer of the State Department of Agriculture was instrumental in having the RSPCA party permitted entry onto the airport loading area. Dr Wirth was extended an invitation to examine the horses as they were loading. The RSPCA officials departed from the tarmac before loading of the horses commenced.

The Government does not believe that it is possible to prescribe by regulation all husbandry matters relating to the transportation of animals. Such definition would be too extensive for practical use and would defy amendment in any real way. The Government believes that husbandry should be regulated by the preparation of standards or codes which allow the use of professional judgment in their interpretation. Such standards have or are being prepared and issued for most classes of animals and forms of transport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1981 (Hansard, page 729) Senator Mulvihill asked be, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice concerning the 1979 and 1981 elections for the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union:

ANSWER.PARA: Was Gosford the medium-sized post office outside the metropolitan area at which 380 ballot papers were illegally seized during the 1979 ballot? Was the unnamed candidate involved in this illegal seizure Mt Frank King? Are inquiries being made at the moment into happenings at the Newcastle mail centre involving the King-Battese-Hawkins election material?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am informed that the first the Australian Electoral Office heard of an alleged seizure in 1979 of 380 ballot papers was when the matter was raised in the Senate on 11 June 1981. By that time, the 1981 election process had begun. The view was taken that, in the light of allegations, whether substantiated or not, concerning an election two years earlier, the most appropraite course for the Electoral Office to follow was to seek the co-operation of Australia Post officials in tightening security arrangements for the despatch and return of 1981 election material. This was done.

Now that the 1981 election has been completed it would be quite appropriate to undertake detailed investigations into the allegations regarding the conduct of the 1979 election. However, Australia Post has advised that it has no knowledge of this alleged interference with electoral material in 1979 and unless there is specific information forthcoming which could assist, there is at present no basis for such investigations.

With respect to the incidents at the Newcastle Mail Centre involving King- Battese-Hawkins election material I am advised that there have been Australia Post enquiries but that the matter was not one which involved the Australian Electoral Office or the conduct of the 1981 election.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 (Hansard page 823) Senator Thomas asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning international subscriber dialling.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

International calling is very popular with an increasing proportion of customers-the average increase being about 30 per cent per annum-and there have been very heavy demands on Telecom by customers to provide automatic dialling for international calls. Responding to this demand Telecom has been introducing ISD on a multi-metering basis at suitably equipped exchanges since 1976, with the charges for these calls being recorded on subscribers' meters along with local and STD calls. However, because of the inability to provide details of these high cost calls, access to the ISD facility has been provided only where requested.

Advances in technology have now enabled Telecom to introduce a call charge record (CCR) system which will automatically record details of subscriber dialed international calls. With the introduction of this system at an exchange , ISD will be provided to all subscribers connected to that exchange, as a separate total for any ISD calls made will appear on their telephone bills.

The new ISD/CCR system is being introduced progressively at suitable exchanges and by June 1982 will be provided on about 1.4m services. Ultimately, as exchanges are updated with more modern equipment, ISD/CCR will be made available to all subscribers. Should any subscriber wish to take less than full advantage of the telephone service, there is a standard fee of $3 per annum which will ensure that access from the service is restricted in a prescribed way.

Telecom believes the provision of ISD/CCR as a standard facility on all telephone services is a logical further step in providing for the present day telephone needs of the community and one that will be welcomed by most customers because, in addition to giving speedy automatic access to overseas telephone subscribers, it gives the opportunity to make savings in call costs with the added advantage of individual call records.

ISD/CCR will not disadvantage customers who do not currently make overseas calls and it is Telecom's view therefore, that where a customer requires his service to be rendered non-standard to the extent of removing the capability to direct dial overseas calls, it is reasonable to apply a small charge to help offset the additional costs involved in modifying the service.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting: VIP Aircraft

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1981, (Hansard, page 850) Senator Townley asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask a question of the Minister representing the Prime Minister, or perhaps it should be addressed to the Minister for Defence because it relates to VIP aircraft. Is the Minister able to say who will be entitled to travel in, and what criteria will apply to, VIP aircraft during the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting? What is the anticipated cost of the use of VIP aircraft during and immediately after the Meeting for carrying heads of state around Australia?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following additional information, to that which was given at the time:

A number of visiting Commonwealth Heads of Delegations to CHOGM flew in their own aircraft. There were others, however, who came on commercial aircraft and their transport in Australia to and from the Melbourne Meeting and transport to other centres in Australia before and after the Meeting were tasks given in the main to the Royal Australian Air Force. The transport of Heads of Delegations to and from Canberra for the Retreat was also carried out by the RAAF, with some assistance from Department of Transport aircraft. The great success of the Commonwealth Meeting in Australia, a Meeting which brought a great many distinguished people to this country, was in no small part due to the efforts of the RAAF in assisting with air transport arrangements.

Costs, calculated in accordance with normal practice, for flying visiting Heads of Delegations, their parties and accompanying Australian officials in RAAF special purpose aircraft before, during and after the Melbourne Meeting were approximately $226,000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1981, (Hansard, page 986) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer again to the matter of Telecom Australia and the fact that many months ago the Auditor-General declared that there were more than 20 causes of error in telephone accounts. Some of these, of course, reduced the subscriber's costs but most increased the cost to the consumer. Is the Minister able to say whether most of those causes have yet been corrected? What is the state of play with Telecom giving subscribers an accurate account showing in particular the details of STD calls, including the date, length, and cost of the call, as is done in countries such as Canada and the United States?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Telecom has advised that to place into perspective the criticisms made in the Auditor-General's report on Telecom's metering and charging procedures, it needs to be borne in mind that considerably less than 1 per cent of the 9.5 million metropolitan telephone bills issued annually are queried by customers and only a small proportion of these are found to require adjustment. Most adjustments made follow the disclosure of human errors in reading of meters or errors in computation. During 1980-81 the number of telephone bills issued increased by 4.6 per cent to 9.53 million while the number of accounts queried increased by only 0.4 per cent. Adjustments were made to 0.04 per cent of accounts issued and less than 20 per cent of the adjusted bills were due to technical faults or suspected equipment malfunctions.

Telecom has advised however that it has been giving attention to the development of improved methods for supervising the performance of the metering system. Because of the extremely low incidence of metering faults in a very large and widespread network, there are no simple economic methods for quickly detecting the occasional fault the moment it occurs. Telecom has received tenders for a modern computer-based metering supervisory system which will improve supervision of the metering system and also allow improved handling of customer complaints.

Regarding the question of giving subscribers details of STD calls, the honourable senator will be aware no doubt that Telecom is progressively introducing a system known as Call Charge Recording (CCR) for international calls, which will enable subscribers to be given details of ISD calls made from their services. By June 1982 ISD/CCR will have been provided in 1.4 million services. Plans have also been announced for the provision of a CCR system for STD calls. This is a major undertaking and it is proposed that this service be offered on an optional basis. It is expected to be made available progressively from metropolitan exchanges commencing in 1984 and extended to some country areas from 1986.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1088) Senator Evans directed a question without notice to me concerning allegations contained in a National Times article on 27 September, 1981, and inquiring whether, during the month ended 7 September, 1981, officers of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and members of the Australian Federal Police had intercepted, recorded or scrutinised every telegram or telex message sent to anyone in the Coolangatta area of Queensland and inquired whether such action would contravene the provisions of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. I took note of the question and undertook to provide a considered reply.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
In accordance with long standing practice, I neither confirm nor deny the allegations contained, or referred to, in the question.

However, I point out certain requirements of the law. Thus, the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 provides that, where a warrant has been issued under sections 11 or 21, the Australian Telecommunications Commission is authorised to inspect telegrams lodged by, or on behalf of, or addressed to, or intended to be received by, the person specified in the warrant. The Commission is further authorised to make and furnish copies of those telegrams to the Director-General of Security or the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police as the case may be. Officers of the Commission's Internal Investigation Unit, being officers duly approved for that purpose, undertake the action authorised to be taken by the Commission pursuant to such warrants. Except in accordance with this procedure, it would be unlawful for an officer of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization or the Australian Federal Police to intercept, or to seek from the Commission to have access to, a telegram or a copy of a telegram.

Interception of a telecommunications service, including the interception of a telex message, when authorised pursuant to a warrant issued under sections 9, 10 or 20 of the Act, is carried out by an officer of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization or a member of the Australian Federal Police duly authorised for that purpose pursuant to section 12 or 22 respectively of the Act. The warrant must relate to a specific service and any other form of interception by such an officer or member would be unlawful.

I have had inquiries made of the relevant authorities in relation to the matters raised in the honourable senator's question. These inquiries have not disclosed any breach of the relevant provisions of the Telecommunications ( Interception) Act at the times and places referred to in the honourable senator 's question

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1158) Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister aware of the United Nations Agreement on the Importation of Educational, Scientific and Cultural Materials opened for signature at Lake Success, New York, on 22 November 1950? Has Australia ratified this agreement? Will the Minister list the outstanding United Nations documents awaiting ratification by Australia?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Agreement on the Importation of Educational, Scientific and Cultural Material is commonly known as the Florence Agreement. Australia has not yet ratified the Florence Agreement on account of continuing industry assistance and tariff policy difficulties.
Australia has signed, but not yet ratified, the following conventions and agreements in respect of which the Secretary-General of the United Nations performs depository functions:
2. Convention on the Prohibition of Military or any other Hostile Use of Environmental Modification Techniques
Adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 10 December 1976.
3. Constitution of the United Nations Industrial Development Organization.
4. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
Adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 18 December 1979.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November 1981 (Hansard, page 1926) Senator Robertson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice concerning air services operated by Garuda Indonesian Airways between Darwin and Indonesia and why Qantas was not operating on this route.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Under agreed arrangements between Australia and Indonesia, Qantas and Garuda are each entitled to operate two DC9 services per week on the Darwin-Denpasar route.
Garuda has been operating two services per week since 26 January 1981, and operated a third weekly service for the three week period from 5 December 1981 to 18 December 1981.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Proposed Petrochemical Development at Stony Point

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2193) Senator Jessop asked me a question without notice concerning the proposed petrochemical development at Stony Point in South Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In my reply I undertook to seek information in respect of that part of the question which referred to the leasing of Crown land in the Stony Point area. I now provide the following answer:

Information from the Department of Administrative Services indicates that the Commonwealth and the State of South Australia are negotiating on a land exchange proposal. The State will acquire some 2 490 ha of Commonwealth land adjoining its existing holdings at Stony Point. The land provided by the Commonwealth to the State will be used to provide an access corridor to the Stony Point facility. The State will provide a similar area of land to the Commonwealth in return.

Dow Chemical has decided to concentrate its studies of a proposed petrochemical plant in the Stony Point area rather than at Redcliff. The Asahi Chemical Industry Co Ltd, Mitsui and Toatsu Chemical Inc. have been considering involvement in a petrochemical plant in the region following the surrender of exclusive rights by Dow Chemicals in 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2257) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: When will Telecom install the system which will detail on subscribers' accounts the details of subscriber trunk dialling calls so that subscribers who query their accounts can have some basis for their argument against the might of Telecom which, from my observations, still does not give subscribers the benefit of the doubt over disputed accounts.
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Advances in technology have enabled Telecom to introduce at reasonable cost a Call Charge Record (CCR) system which will automatically record details of subscriber dialled international calls. It has, therefore, commenced a program to provide this system progressively at suitable exchanges and ultimately at all exchanges throughout Australia. With its introduction at an exchange, all subscribers served by that exchange gain access to ISD as a standard facility and on their subsequent telephone bills a separate total will appear for any ISD calls made. Telecom has indicated that by June 1982 the new ISD/CCR system will have been provided on about 1.4m services.

Telecom has undertaken extensive studies of the technical work to provide STD/ CCR and through market surveys has also looked at the question of subscriber needs. A large proportion of subscribers make few, if any, STD calls and their requirement is for the cheapest practicable service. Some subscribers require a lock on their telephone as a security against unauthorised use and there are those who require a range of cost control services, such as call analysis equipment, individual meters and other timing devices. There are also those who would like a full record of their STD calls. Then again, there are subscribers who would prefer the existing multi-metering system as it preserves the anonymous nature of the telephone service.

Against this background, and as the provision of STD/CCR on a universal basis would involve very heavy capital and manpower investment in network modernisation Telecom proposes to offer it as an optional service. As an optional service STD/CCR will be available from most metropolitan exchanges in 1984.

Extension of the program to the balance of metropolitan exchanges and to the country will follow but, at this stage, it will be 1986 at least before a start can be made to provide the optional service to country customers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2345) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Are there instances where television stations are refusing to pay licence fees for fixed links between stations and transmitters? If so, are these links being illegally operated? What is the attitude of the Government and the Minister for Communications to these illegal operations?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Yes, some television stations temporarily refused to pay licence fees. However , following discussions with the industry licence fees are now being received.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2344) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether the Minister's Department is aware of the arrest of approximately 60 East Timorese people in Jakarta a few days ago. Were those people about to leave Jakarta for Singapore and then Australia? Did they have visas to come to Australia? Is the Government doing anything to protect the interests of those people who have been arrested?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am advised that 15 East Timorese were arrested at Halim Airport in Jakarta on 4 November 1981, reportedly for attempting to leave Indonesia on forged Indonesian passports. All 15 held Australian entry visas stamped in Portuguese passports.
I understand that a further 17 East Timorese, some of whom may have intended travelling to Australia, were arrested on 14 November also reportedly for carrying forged Indonesian passports.

I note that 22 of the East Timorese were brought to trial, and on 23 December 1981 were sentenced to four months two weeks jail for illegally obtaining and using Indonesian passports. The sentences were to be reduced by the amount of time already spent in prison.

The Indonesian authorities have the right to enforce legal provisions relating to Indonesian passports and under the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations Australia can only exercise its consular responsibilities on behalf of its own citizens.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2344) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning postage rates.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There has not been any reduction in the number of mail articles posted in Australia as a result of the increase in postal charges which came into affect on 14 July 1981. In fact, a survey of the number of mail articles posted in Australia during the four month period July 1981 to October 1981 has revealed that mail business levels increased some 4.6 per cent on the 1980 figures for the same period. The total number of Australia Post's operative staff has remained relatively static in that time.

The question of providing a subsidy for postal services has been considered before, by the Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Post Office, and may be one of the issues addressed by the Australian Postal Commission Inquiry currently inquiring into the monopoly position of Australia Post.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2604) Senator Grimes asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning persons taking hospital only health insurance cover.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:
Firstly, I did not make the statement attributed to me by the honourable senator.

I assume that the honourable senator was referring to part of an address given by me to the recent Annual General Meeting of the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia in which I touched briefly upon the aspect of hospital only health insurance cover in the broader context of emerging trends since the 1 September 1981 changes to the health insurance arrangements. In voicing the concern of registered organizations about persons taking out hospital only cover and attending public hospital outpatient departments for medical treatment, I pointed out the potential effects on the public hospital system and the need for both Government and the health insurance industry to co- operate in closely monitoring the situation.

I also indicated my concern that the people promoting 'hospital only' insurance were not doing so to assist the public but were attempting to discredit the new initiatives taken by the Government and to confuse the public .

I have not in any way attempted to persuade people from taking hospital only insurance. However, in fairness to those who may have been disposed towards it, I have pointed out the shortcomings of such insurance, for example, delays that could result from pressure on public hospitals, lack of continuity of care by a private general practitioner who becomes familiar with a patient's medical history and a lack of the full range of medical (including specialist) services in some hospitals.
Obviously, to act responsibly in this matter, the Government must maintain a careful monitoring of the situation in the interests of maintaining an efficient health delivery and finance system.
It would require a strong imaginative effort to convert 'monitoring of trends' into a 'crackdown'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What criteria are applied to the size of a house made available for rent in Canberra.
(2) For what reasons would these criteria be varied.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Single persons are allocated a bedsitter or one bedroom flat, couples without dependants are allocated a two bedroom flat and two related/unrelated persons of the same or opposite sex may be allocated joint tenancy of a two bedroom flat. Two bedroom houses or flats are allocated to single supporting parents with 1 child. Couples with dependants to house and single parents with two or more dependants are allocated a three bedroom house. Four bedroom houses are allocated to families who have four children, two of each sex with an age differential of more than five years between the children of the one sex; three children with an age gap of more than seven years between children of ths same sex; three of their four children of the same sex. Families with more than four children may be allocated a five or six bedroom house. Generally, not more than 2 children are expected to share a bedroom.

(2) The criteria would be varied where there are extenuating medical or other similar reasons which would justify departing from the normal criteria; or where accommodation must be allocated immediately and there is nothing of the correct size available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Approximately what, on average, does it cost Telecom to erect a 16 kilometre telephone line to connect a rural subscriber to the telephone network.
(2) Where that subscriber does not wish to pay for the cost of the construction of that line can he opt to pay a surcharge on normal rent; if so, what is the surcharge.
(3) Did the surcharge increase with the latest Telecom price increases; if not, will increases in other areas increase the cross-subsidisation to rural areas within Telecom.

(4) How much of the average capital investment incurred in erecting a 16 kilometre line could be financed at current rates of interest (say 15 per cent) by the surcharge paid by subscribers referred to in (2), and what would be the remaining capital sum to be financed by Telecom.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The provision of subscribers' line plant in rural areas provides that an applicant living up to a radial distance of 16 kilometres from an automatic exchange is provided with a service for the payment of the normal connection fee and rental. Prior to 1 January 1982 those living beyond the 16 kilometre radius had the option of contributing to the cost of the distance in excess of 16 kilometres at the rate of $160 per half kilometre or paying an annual rental of $500. The honourable senator would no doubt be aware that a new charging policy was introduced from 1 January which substantially reduces line charges for existing customers whose telephone services are being converted to automatic working and new customers seeking connection to either an automatic or manual telephone service.
Having regard to the foregoing, the answers are-
(1) On average, the capital investment involved in providing a line 16 kilometres radially from an exchange is $12,500.

(2) An applicant located 16 kilometres radially from an automatic exchange would not be called upon to make either a capital contribution or pay the special rental mentioned in the above explanatory note.

(3) The special rental option of $500 was not increased in September 1981. The costs of installing and maintaining long lines will vary over time depending on the technology available. Hopefully the very long lines will become cheaper when digital radio concentrator systems are used. The extent of cross-subsidisation will therefore depend on the costs relevant to the long country services rather than the rental and conditions applicable to these services. Under the new charging policy, the special rental option will be terminated in 1986.
(4) Telecom bears all of the investment of a line of 16 kilometres length, ie, $12,500 on average.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telecom: Data Services and Telex Equipment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question, upon notice, on 19 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have waiting times for provision of (a) data services and (b) telex equipment by Telecom improved during 1980-81 and are they expected to improve further in 1981-82 and beyond.
(2) What records does Telecom keep on waiting times for those services and what are the figures involved for each year since 1970-71?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Waiting times for Datel services, as measured by the old statistical system improved in Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia and declined in New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania during 1980-81.

Adoption of the new statistical system for 1981-82 (see answer to part 2) does not allow direct comparison with previous years. However, Telecom considers that waiting times on average nationally have improved, and expects a further improvement during the balance of 1981-82. Waiting times should be at least maintained at the improved level beyond 1981-82.
(b) Waiting times for telex services improved in Western Australia and declined in the other States during 1980-81.
For 1981-82, to date there has been a substantial improvement in waiting times on average nationally and the situation is expected to further improve in the remainder of the year and beyond.
(2) The attached statement provides the statistics sought. No statistics of this nature are available prior to 1975-76. In relation to (1) (a) statistics are provided for Datel services.

Records kept for Datel services between 1975-76 and 1980-81 measured the delay in providing service from the date of issue of an order by Telecom. However, this has proved to be an unsatisfactory indicator of the standard of service being provided to customers because often a Datel service is not required by the customer for some months after the issue of an order.

Consequently, for 1981-82, Telecom has introduced a new statistical system which measures performance in meeting the provision of service within Telecom's standard delay times or the date the service is requested by the customer whichever is the later.
For telex services, the records kept measure the delay in providing service from the date of issue of an order by Telecom.
NSW Vic. Qld SA WA Tas. NSW Vic. Qld SA WA Tas. Aust.
* Connection time performance from issue of order to completion.
* Standard time to provide service or the customer requested date whichever is the later.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Recurrent funds for the 1982-84 triennium were not allocated to the SCV Melbourne in the State Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981 because no acceptable consolidation proposal in respect of the College had been received by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, as required by the Review of Commonwealth Functions. However, funds have been made available for the College in 1982 from the national unallocated grant on the understanding that consolidation will be actively pursued during the year. As an autonomous institution established under State legislation, SCV Melbourne is responsible for deciding the internal distribution of the funds provided to it. The extent of reductions in SCV Melbourne's teaching programs is also a matter for the College itself to determine in consultation with the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission.

Melbourne State College is the only college of advanced education in metropolitan Melbourne which provides a course designed primarily to train teacher librarians for primary and secondary schools. SCV Hawthorn offers a Graduate Diploma in Education course with a teacher librarianship strand; the course is designed primarily for prospective teachers of secondary technical and TAFE colleges.

The supply of specialised teachers is a matter for the education authorities in each State in consultation with the institutions providing teacher education courses. TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 635) Senator Colston asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory a question without notice seeking information regarding the fare collection on Canberra's ACTION buses.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for the Capital Territory has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Canberra's buses operate on a fare collection system designed to speed passenger loadings thus reducing delays and achieving a high level of productivity from drivers and vehicles. Passengers are encouraged to prepurchase rides off the bus. Passengers paying on the bus are required to place the exact fare in a farebox. Drivers carry a change float to provide change if required. A small but significant number of passengers are still seeking change on buses and this slows loading times to the inconvenience of all passengers.

To overcome this the Department suggested an exact fare system which included levying a charge for providing change. This was submitted to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly for consideration and to encourage public comment. The Assembly supported the system proposed but opposed the imposition of the administrative charge. Subsequent public reaction has been against not only the levy but also the exact fare system itself.

Given my commitment to encourage the use of public transport I will not impose a system to which the community is so obviously opposed. Accordingly, I have given a direction to my Department not to proceed with the introduction of the system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1625) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister, in view of the latter part of his answer, whether he will try to secure from the Prime Minister some undertaking about what, if any, diplomatic initiatives the Australian Government will be taking to see that the second part of the Camp David Accords , relating to Palestinian autonomy, is brought to the forefront of the thinking of both Egypt and Palestine and other associated powers so that it may be resolved as quickly as possible?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs, to whom the question was referred, has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In his statement to Parliament on 22 October concerning Australian participation in the Sinai peacekeeping force the Prime Minister stated that a solution to the Palestinian issue was clearly central to the future stability and peace of the Middle East. The Prime Minister went on to say that Australia would be looking to the United States to ensure effective progress in implementating the Camp David Accords as they relate not only to the Sinai but also to Palestinian autonomy. You may rest assured that the Australian Government remains concerned to do what it can to bring about a resolution of the Palestinian problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1981 (Hansard page 1625) Senator Hamer asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to his statement on the conditional decision to commit our Defence Force to the Sinai peacekeeping operation. Does the Government attach equal importance to the two arms of the Camp David Accords-the Israeli withdrawal from Egyptian territory in the Sinai and the solving of the problem of Palestinian autonomy? Has the failure to achieve a just and honourable solution to the Palestinian problem been the cause of great damage to the strategic position of the Western world in the key Middle Eastern area? In the autonomy talks to be held between now and next January between Israel and Egypt will a marked change of attitude on the part of both sides be necessary if any significant progress is to be made? When the Minister said that our involvement in the Sinai peacekeeping force was on the 'understanding that all the parties to the Camp David Accords press forward with a continuing peace process in the Middle East', does this mean that our force will not be committed to the Middle East unless there is some substantial progress towards a solution which is just and honourable to both sides of the Palestinian problem?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional comments to the answer I gave to the honourable senator's question:

The Government believes that it is important both that the Israelis withdraw from the Sinai and that there be a resolution of the Palestinian issue. A solution to the Palestinian issue is central to the future stability and peace of the Middle East. At the same time Israeli withdrawal from the final third of the Sinai is essential if progress is to be achieved on the wider Palestinian issue since failure of the Israelis to withdraw from the final third of the Sinai would seriously weaken the resolve of most of the countries of the region to settle the Middle East dispute by negotiation.

In his statement to Parliament on 22 October on Australian participation in the Sinai peacekeeping force, the Prime Minister stated 'the continued progress towards peace in the Middle East is of enormous significance to Australia. An outbreak of conflict would have repercussions not only for the region but also for the peace of the world which would affect us profoundly and in manifold ways. It would affect our allies and friends in ways which could not but impinge greatly on our international relationships with risks for the strategic balance of great moment to our national security. Australia's interest is in seeing what is probably the single most serious threat to world peace removed.'

With reference to your question about the autonomy negotiations concerned with the future status of the Israeli occupied West Bank and Gaza, I regret to say that there has still been little progress. There are many reasons for this. The Camp David Agreement does not make clear what was intended on the concept of autonomy, and this has not made it any easier to reach agreement. In addition, of course, there has been no agreement on the long term future of the Palestinians after the transitional autonomy stage of five years envisaged under Camp David.

Regarding your query about the terms of our commitment to the Sinai force, the Prime Minister said in his statement to Parliament on 22 October that 'our participation in the peacekeeping force would be on the understanding that all the parties to the Accords abided by word and deed with their provisions, and press forward with a continuing peace process in the Middle East'. Australia will be looking to the United States to exert and sustain the strongest pressure to ensure effective progress in implementing the Camp David Accords as they relate not only to the Sinai but also to Palestinian autonomy. Australia's participation in the Sinai Peacekeeping Force is not however formally linked to any particular steps in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2084) Senator Lewis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the Senate the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I have a question for the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. It is about the prominent labelling of packages as 'Made in Australia', when what is not infrequently meant is that the package is made in Australia but the product is imported. Sometimes a product has been laundered in some way or other through an Australian factory with some minor modification , and is then prominently labelled 'Made in Australia'. I am aware of a case in which a fully imported citizens band transceiver was given a very minor modification in Australia and prominently labelled 'Australian Made'. On examination it was found that 99 per cent of the product in fact had been made in South Korea. I ask: What are the limitations, if any, on the use of the label 'Made in Australia'? Is the Government considering any action to tighten the limitations on the use of the label or any other action which might otherwise protect both Australian producers of products actually made in Australia and consumers in Australia from this practice?
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act and the Commerce (Imports) Regulations made thereunder, and the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations made under the Customs Act prescribe certain marking to be applied to imported goods. Where imported goods bear markings in a language other than that of the country of origin, a statement of the country of origin must be attached. In addition, certain specific types of imported goods such as food and drink, textile products and shoes are required to bear a trade description which includes a statement of the country of origin.

Although there is no general requirement that imported goods supplied in the Australian market carry a country of origin marking, the Commonwealth Trade Practices Act 1974 prohibits misleading of deceptive conduct, including conduct related to country of origin markings, by corporations and certain individuals in trade or commerce. The Act allows the Federal Court to grant to any person injunctions to restrain such conduct, and on prosecution to impose fines of up to $50,000 on corporations and up to $10,000 on individuals who contravene its provisions.
The Trade Practices Commission has addressed this question of country of origin in its booklet 'Advertising and Selling: A business guide to consumer protection under the Trade Practices Act'.

The Commission has indicated that special care is necessary where the country of origin is made a feature of advertising or product description. It states that where goods are composed of parts or material originating in more than one country, or where goods are manufactured or assembled in one country from parts or material originating from another, any description of the origin should not be such as to mislead consumers.

If the honourable senator passes on details of the case he cites, or any other similar cases of which he may be aware, to the Trade Practices Commission, the Commission will look into the matter and take whatever action is appropriate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1160) Senator Coleman asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware of complaints that the maintenance sections of Telecom Australia have not received substantial supplies for some two months? Is he also aware that new services are not available in some States because new phones have to be dismantled for spare parts to maintain existing services? Will the Minister advise the Senate whether this deliberate choking off is a means of establishing that Telecom is inefficient, thus conditioning people for the sale of that authority to private enterprise?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Telecom did experience shortages of some items of maintenance equipment in the latter part of 1981. This was due primarily to industrial disputes affecting the manufacture and delivery of material. The industrial problems have since been resolved and deliveries of maintenance materials are proceeding. Some critical items of equipment were in short supply due to unprecedented demand. This equipment has been identified and a special allocation of funds has been provided to urgently improve the stock position.

It is not the policy of Telecom to dismantle new telephones to maintain existing services at the expense of new services. If this practice has occurred it would certainly have been in isolation and does not reflect the normal maintenance procedures currently operating within Telecom.
