QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What cost reduction opportunities has Telecom Australia been able to realise following suggestions in the McKinsey report:

'(a) Review procurement policies in regard to the number of suppliers of equipment so that the economies of higher volume can be obtained. In addition, we recommend strengthened market input into tender evaluations.

(b) Improve labour productivity at the subscriber end of the network. Specific policy changes include relating work force deployment more closely to work load, extending prewiring of new homes, and improving materials supply co-ordination in installation.

(c) Improve management of overheads. We recommend a review of the value added of each overhead function by identifying overhead costs more closely with services performed and by identifying options for reducing the level or frequency of services that are not cost effective.'
(2) What are the details of action taken with regard to each suggestion.
(3) What money has been saved as a result of each suggestion which has been implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1a) and (2) Telecom believes that the best interests of suppliers and of itself as a purchaser are met by conforming with Government standards of purchasing, in particular that its needs are subject to public tenders and that all who seek to do business with Telecom shall have an equal opportunity to do so. As a consequence, Telecom does not control the number of companies established in Australia who are capable of manufacturing telecommunications equipment and supplies.

Telecom seeks only to buy from more than one source where manufacturing capacity limitations require it, where better security of supply is required or where there is a need to ensure future competition.

There has been some rationalisation. In recent years the number of suppliers has reduced in some areas. For example, new generation ARE exchange equipment is being provided by two suppliers whereas existing crossbar is supplied by three. Channel modem suppliers have reduced from four to three.
Telecom has strengthened its commercial organisation and included a broad marketing base in the Commercial Services Department. Stronger market input into tender evaluations has resulted.

New equipment and services have been developed in line with the new technology available, with the scope and type of services provided being firmly based on market indicators. Forecasting models are used as an input to tender evaluation. For example, market factors were taken into account in Telecom's recent decision to purchase the 'Commander' small business system range.
(1b) and (2) Improvement in labour productivity by changes in policies relating to work force deployment and the prewiring of new homes is receiving attention by Telecom management.

The area most likely to benefit from work force redeployment is exchange maintenance which is the subject of ongoing industrial negotiations between Telecom and the relevant staff association under the auspices of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
National policy on prewiring of new homes is under review.

Where appropriate, initiatives are taken to improve the total mix of stock so that stocks of those items which are most commonly in short supply are increased as necessary. This is an ongoing exercise since the pattern of supply problems continuously changes. Where short term shortages occur, an allocation of additional funds is made to improve the supply of items in urgent demand. Material supply co-ordination is kept under close and regular review with the responsibility for control of critical items of stock decentralized wherever possible.
(1c) and (2) The strengthening of the commercial and marketing activities of Telecom mentioned above will result in improved management of overheads in relation to services and products.
In other areas overhead and administrative costs are kept under regular review and adjustments made to effect productivity improvements.

(3) The effect of any changes to policy procedures or practices associated with the recommendations of the McKinsey Report would be of a long term nature and the financial impact cannot be accurately quantified in the short term.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps have been taken by Telecom Australia since the receipt of the McKinsey report to implement its recommendations.
(2) In particular, has Telecom started to 'extend prewiring of new homes', as recommended in the report.
(3) How much has this already saved and how much will it save.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A number of major recommendations of the McKinsey report are relevant to Telecom's competitive position and financial structure and because of their strategic nature, will be considered by the Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications in Australia.

Some of the recommendations are currently being implemented and some details have been provided to the honourable senator in response to other questions asked by him in relation to the McKinsey report. Other recommendations are the subject of further study.
(2) and (3) As indicated in response to Question No. 1353 the policy on prewiring of new homes is under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 19 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made towards more closely 'identifying' unprofitable activities in rural areas and the extent of that unprofitability.
(2) Will the Minister for Communications provide any important information bearing on this question which is, or has been produced by, or made available to , Telecom Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Since its inception Telecom has aimed at providing a universal standard telecommunications service throughout Australia embracing continuous automatic service, subscriber trunk dialling and international subscriber dialling. The former Australian Post Office had similar objectives also. This objective is in harmony with the requirements of the Telecommunications Act which requires the Commission to have special regard to people residing or carrying on business outside the cities.

Inevitably with such an objective, given the thin population spread and large size of the country, there will be a substantial cross-subsidisation from profitable areas of the network to cover the high costs involved in providing modern communications to the rural and remote areas of Australia.

In a network providing a range of facilities for transmission of information it is not a simple matter to identify directly all items of expenses and earnings with individual categories of service. Telecom pays close attention to broad measures of the financial performance of major services and information on the performance is provided in the Commission's annual report together with considerable statistical data on telecommunications services generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2151) Senator MacGibbon asked a question without notice seeking information regarding the proposed National Semiconductor plant in Canberra. The Minister for the Capital Territory has supplied the following information in reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The feasibility study being undertaken by the National Semiconductor Corporation (NSC) relates to the feasibility of establishing a wafer fabrication facility in the Australian Capital Territory.

I understand that NSC has facilities in a number of countries, but at this stage only undertakes wafer fabrication in the United States of America (Santa Clara: California; Danbury: Connecticut; and West Jordan: Utah; a fourth plant is currently under construction in Arlington: Texas) and at Greenock, Scotland.

The proposed wafer plant will involve application of integrated circuits to raw silicon wafers by advanced photographic and chemical technologies. This is the highest technology part of silicon chip manufacture. The silicon wafers will then be exported to other NSC operations for subsequent testing, dicing, assembly and packaging.
The promotion of microelectronic applications for Australian industry will be a matter for negotiation between the Commonwealth and NSC.
The answer the Minister for Science and Technology provided to Question No. 2383, which appeared in the Hansard of 20 August 1981 in the House of Representatives is also relevant.
